Published Images
The People's Republic of China, May 1951.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Vietnamese, Cambodian, and Laotian representatives meet in China to plan a united front against the French. Here, senior delegates from Vietnam and Cambodia exchange gifts.

did.unittitle: The French aircraft carrier Arromanches steams in the Gulf of Tonkin during the struggle to maintain control over Indochina.
French coastal patrol vessels ply a river in Vietnam.
French and Vietnamese forces advance inland during Operation Camarque on Vietnam's central coast on August 25, 1953.
Washington, late March 1954.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: General Paul Ely (center), French Armed Forces Chief of Staff, shares a cordial moment with President Eisenhower (left) and Admiral Arthur W. Radford (right), chairman of the U.S. Joint Chiefs of Staff. (See also photograph 1-8)

did.unittitle: Refugee fishermen flee to the South from communist-controlled North Vietnam.
Immigrant from the North served to strengthen the already conservative populace of the South.
U.S. ambassador Donald Heath joins Saigon mayor Ngo Dinh Diem in 1954 in welcoming the 100,000th northern refugee to freedom in the South.
Vietnam, May 1954.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: President Ho Chi Minh with two children who presented him with flowers. "Uncle Ho" loved to be photographed with children, although in conducting national affairs he easily shed this avuncular veneer.

did.unittitle: Stern-faced victors and vanquished.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Following the French collapse at Dien Bien Phu in 1954, a French commander turns over his garrison to a representative of the Democratic Republic of Vietnam.

did.unittitle: President Diem enjoys a cruise on a river patrol vessel following the defeat of the Binh Xuyen sect in 1955.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Although Vietnamese man the vessel, American and British military observes are present in the stern.

did.unittitle: President Diem and General J. Lawton Collins discuss the Saigon situation at Independence Palace on May 13 1955.
Ho Chi Minh arrives in Warsaw, Poland, for an official state visit.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Beside him to his right is Polish Chief of State Alexander Zawadski.

did.unittitle: Ho Chi Minh curries favor with President Sukarno of Indonesia during a state visit on March 10, 1959.
A woman crushes rice as Vietnamese peasants have for centuries.
A member of the 9th Infantry Division and a Vietnamese scout talk with a peasant family during a mission south of Thou Tan Island.
A Montagnard elder says a prayer before a sacrificial altar during a ceremony where the various Montagnard villages pledge loyalty to the Vietnamese central government.
Church services in the village of Binh Hung, a locality with a large Chinese population.
A young girl from a mission school in Bien Hoa province sits in the lap of Charles M. Muscat.
Vietnamese orphans, whose parents were killed by Vietcong forces – one who lost a limb in an ambush, and two polio victims.
During the mid-1960s, uniformed students parade in Hanoi carrying a portrait of Ho Chi Minh.
A portion of the Mekong Delta between My Tho and Vinh Long.
The monsoon rains flood the streets of Chau Doc City in the Mekong Delta, 120 miles southwest of Saigon.
Civilians in Long An province assist regional forces in crossing one of that area's countless streams.
SP4 William Langley of the 11th Armored Cavalry peers through the elephant grass near Fire Support Base Henderson.
Movement across country proved difficult in the rice paddies.
The mountainous terrain near Fire Support Base Action, seen on October 20, 1969.
Mountains seen from a guard tower at Fire Support Base Debbie near Duc Pho.
A small village outside Tra-On in the Mekong Delta.
A French-style house in the city of Can Tho in the heart of the Mekong Delta.
A Buddhist temple in Can Tho.
Hué, the old imperial Vietnamese capital, was a typically curious mixture of the very old and very new.
Saigon, seen here on December 7, 1966.
The view up Le Loi Avenue in Saigon, The Hotel Caravelle is the tall building to the right.
Formerly, the Opera House during French rule, this building became the Chamber of Deputies after Independence and then a cultural center under the communists.
Independence Palace.
Interminable traffic jams made a lasting impression on Americans stationed in Saigon.
"Rush hour" in Hanoi in 1965.
Ho Chi Minh, president of communist North Vietnam, shown here in July 1957.
Maj. Gen. Tran Van Tra, Deputy Commander-in-Chief of the communist Liberation Army of South Vietnam.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: He was also a Central Committee member of the Lao Dong Party.

did.unittitle: Brig. Gen. Tran Do, Deputy Commander-in-Chief of the Liberation Army of South Vietnam.
General Vo Nguyen Giap (right), North Vietnamese vice-premier and minister of National Defense, chats with members of the People's Army in December 1965.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Lt. Gen. Van Tien Dung, chief of the General Staff of the People's Army trails behind.

did.unittitle: President Ngo Dinh Diem with American Maj. Gen. Matthew H. Deichelmann during Air Force Day ceremonies in Saigon in June 1958.
Nguyen Van Thieu, president of South Vietnam, answers questions at a press conference in June 1969.
Nguyen Cao Ky, premier of South Vietnam.
Dwight D. Eisenhower, President of the United States.
John F. Kennedy, President of the United States.
President of the United States Lyndon B. Johnson (right) confers with Dean Rusk, his secretary of State.
Robert S. McNamara, secretary of defense under Presidents Kennedy and Johnson
Johnson administration National Security Advisor McGeorge Bundy.
President Richard M. Nixon visits with troops during July 1971.
Nixon administration secretary of Defense Melvin Laird answers questions from the press.
Elliot L. Richardson, Melvin Laird's successor as secretary of Defense.
A Marine helicopter pilot airlifts South Vietnamese Army personnel during a strike against the Vietcong in May 1952.
Vietnamese soldiers train in the field during May 1962.
A South Vietnamese soldier shows the flag during operations against the Vietcong during the summer of 1962.
A Vietnamese infantryman searches for Vietcong insurgents during June 1962.
The search is successful and nets four glum Vietcong prisoners.

President John F. Kennedy (left) looks on while Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy (right) administers the oath of office to General Maxwell D. Taylor as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff on October 1, 1962.
An L-19 Army reconnaissance aircraft fuels at Vinh Long airstrip on February 21, 1963.
In late February 1963, a South Vietnamese soldier cleans his Thompson M-1A1 submachine gun.
American advisor 1st Lt. Joseph G. Cincotti instructs some troops in the use of map and compass prior to an exercise during March 1963.
Lt. Joe M. Clement, an advisor to the 7th ARVN Infantry Division, distributes leaflets and pictures to South Vietnamese civilians near the ARVN training area.
April 1963.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: American advisor Maj. Allan W. Galfund photographed these Vietnamese marines trudging wearily back to trap a Vietcong battalion in the Plain of Reeds area, deep in the Mekong Delta region.

did.unittitle: A monument erected near downtown Hué commemorates the death of Buddhist monks killed by President Diem's troops in June 1963.
Strike force billets at the Vietnamese Special Forces Camp in An Diem during the summer of 1963.
President Johnson and General William C. Westmoreland in the White House Rose Garden.
Saigon, July 21, 1964.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Navy Band of the Republic of South Vietnam plays during welcoming ceremonies for the USS Oklahoma City (CLG-5), which had assumed its duties as flagship of the Seventh Fleet two weeks before. On board was Vice Adm. Roy L. Johnson, Commander-in-Chief, U.S. Seventh Fleet.

did.unittitle: Correspondent David Horowitz of NBC News interviews Admiral Johnson, who has just arrived on his first goodwill visit to Saigon.
Destroyer Maddox (DD-731) on patrol in the Far East during 1964.
North Vietnamese Swatow gunboat under way off the coast of Vietnam, close to its top speed of 28 knots.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The armament of these Chinese-made craft included depth charges and 37mm and 14.5mm guns. They also carried surface-search radar.

did.unittitle: Capt. John J. Herrick (left), commander of the Ticonderoga during the North Vietnamese torpedo attacks on August 2 and 4, 1964.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: At right stands Cmdr. Herbert L. Ogier, captain of Maddox.

did.unittitle: Lt. Cmdr. Dempster M. Jackson, executive officer of Maddox, casts an indignant scowl toward the camera as he stands behind a protruding enemy round that struck the ship's Mark 56 fire director pedestal during the North Vietnamese attack on August 2.
USS Midway (CVA-41) steams in the South China Sea off Vietnam during the Gulf of Tonkin crisis.
A Douglas A-4C Skyhawk catapults from an air craft carrier during operations in the Gulf of Tonkin.
Action in the Gulf of Tonkin, August 5, 1964.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A Swatow gunboat and P-4 motor torpedo boat come under attack by U.S. carrier aircraft during operation Pierce Arrow retaliatory strikes that followed attacks on Maddox.

did.unittitle: A Sawtow lies dead in the water, leaking fuel, following an air strike by U.S. Navy aircraft on August 5.

American leaders who assessed the impact and implications of events in the Gulf of Tonkin – (left to right) Maxwell D. Taylor, who in June 1964 had replaced Henry Cabot Lodge as ambassador to South Vietnam; Dean C. Rusk, secretary of State; President Lyndon B. Johnson; and Robert S. McNamara, secretary of Defense.
The Caravelle Hotel in downtown Saigon.
Vietnamese police escort an American serviceman injured in the explosion that partially destroyed the 4th, 5th, and 6th floors of the Caravelle Hotel on August 25, 1964.
Armed with an M-1 carbine Infantry advisor Capt. Don Christensen leads an ARVN machine-gun crew through a rice paddy on August 27, 1964.
4 October 1964.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A South Vietnamese Ranger searches the body of a Vietcong guerrilla killed in a government operation against the communists near Ca Mau, 40 miles southwest of Saigon.

did.unittitle: Vietcong corpses gathered for burial at Ca Mau.
Commander Chon, River Force Commander, and Lt. Gen. John L. Throckmorton view a River Force demonstration in October 1964.
General William C. Westmoreland and Ambassador Maxwell Taylor visit Bien Hoa Air Base on November 1 in the wake of a Vietcong mortar attack.
The White House, December 1, 1964.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: President Johnson meets with Robert McNamara and Maxwell Taylor to discuss the situation in Vietnam.

did.unittitle: The Joint Chiefs of Staff on February 2, 1965.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Seated (left to right) are Admiral David L. McDonald, CNO; General Earle G. Wheeler, Chairman; General Harold K. Johnson, Army Chief. Standing are (left to right) General John P. McConnell, Air Force Chief; General Wallace M. Greene, Commandant USMC.

did.unittitle: Secretary of Defense Robert McNamara briefs newsmen on February 7, 1965 concerning Operation Flaming Dart.
McGeorge Bundy, Special Assistant to President Johnson for National Security Affairs, inspects damage to American compounds in Dar Lac province on February 7 in the wake of Vietcong attacks.
Marines of the 9th Marine Expeditionary Brigade splash ashore at Da Nang.
Marine defensive positions at Da Nang. Here men of F Company 2d Battalion, 12th Marines, man a 105mm howitzer position.
The Marine buildup continues as the men of Battalion Landing Team 2/3 hit the beach at Da Nang on April 10, 1965.
Under Secretary of State George W. Ball.
Two RF-101 Voodoos take off on a photoreconnaissance mission form Tan Son Nhut Air Base.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the wreckage of an aircraft at center.

did.unittitle: A low-flying RF-101 casts its shadow on a bombed –out bridge 15 miles north of the DMZ on April 22, 1965.
Operation Rolling Thunder begins.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A Martin B-57 Canberra releases one of its bombs over North Vietnam in March 1965.

did.unittitle: B-52 bombers, having flown 12 hours from Guam drop their loads of 750-pound and 1,000-pound bombs on July 7, 1965.
Craters made by B-52 saturation bombing on War Zone D.
Napalm/phosphorous bombs dropped by a Vietnamese Air Force A-1E Skyraider fighter-bomber devastate a Vietcong insurgent military camp hidden in the trees south of Can Tho in Phong Dinh province.
Low-level reconnaissance photograph taken by a U. S. Air Force plane in August 1965 reveals an SA-2 surface-to-air (SAM) missile battery prepared by the North Vietnamese.
After being awarded Distinguished Flying Crosses, F-4 pilots of the 45th Tactical Fighter Squadron celebrate the first MiG kills of the Vietnam War on July 7, 1965.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: From the left;1st Lt. George Larsen, Capt. Ronald C. Anderson, Capt. Kenneth D. Holcombe (partially hidden), Capt. Thomas S. Roberts, Maj. Richard Hall, Capt. Arthur C. Clark, and Capt. Wilbur Anderson.

did.unittitle: Prior to takeoff in his F-1000 fighter-bomber, 1st Lt. James D. Kempton of the 481st Tactical Fighter Squadron dons his flight suit at Tan Son Nhut Air Base in September 1965.
November 1965.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Lt. Col. Gerald Beisner Commanding Officer, 558th Tactical Fighter Squadron, prepares to climb out of the front cockpit of his F4C, while 1st Lt. Charles T. Jaglinski has already made an exit. Their squadron was equipped with the first camouflaged F-C4c to arrive in Vietnam.

did.unittitle: An F-100 Super Sabre drops a pair of 500-pound general purpose bombs on a Vietcong target in the Mekong Delta during air activity in late December 1965.
Crewmen on board Kitty Hawk (CVA-63) wheel three 250-pound bombs on the flight deck during loading operations.
Four aircraft carriers from Task Force 77 and their accompanying screen.
Primary Flight Control on Ranger.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Men observe flight operations during the kickoff of Rolling Thunder.

did.unittitle: An A-4C on Carol Sea (CVA-43) awaits the signal for takeoff during late March 1965.
An F-8 Crusader fires a Zuni rocket into a Vietcong target in the South.
The universal descriptive pantomime of the fighter pilot.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Cmdr. Lowell R. Myers describes his MiG-21 kill over Vinh Son while flying an F-8 Crusader.

did.unittitle: Men standing near the Landing Signal Officer's console on Constellation (CVA-64) watch intently as an A-4C descends toward the flight deck. Note the lowered tail-hook.
Medical personnel collect dead and wounded in the wake of a Vietcong attack on Bien Hoa Air Base on May 16, 1965.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An A-1E Skyraider is in the background. A-1s were workhorses, often providing closes air support and cover for downed pilots during rescue missions.

did.unittitle: Secretary of Defense McNamara arrives in Vietnam in late April 1965, greeted on his arrival by his South Vietnamese counterpart, Gen. Nguyen Huu Co. U.S. Deputy Ambassador U. Alexis Johnson stands at center.
A Navy hospital corpsman lends aid to a man wounded in the March 30, 1965, attack on the U.S. embassy.
Vietnamese and American civilians lie on stretchers after sustaining injuries during the Vietcong attack on the U.S. embassy in Saigon on March 30, 1965.

Ordnance, signal, and medical specialists of the Army's 1st Logistical Command disembark from General J.C. Breckenridge (AP-176), boarding an LCU in preparation for the short trip into the beach area at Vung Tau on July 12, 1965.
Men clamber off the LCU at Vung Tau. A LARC-5 lies in the background at right.
While touring the 3d Marine Division operating area near Da Nang during August 1965, Secretary of Defense McNamara and General Westmoreland visits with General Thi, I Corps Commander.
Former vice president Richard M. Nixon says good-bye to American and South Vietnamese officers before his departure from Da Nang.
Here on September 14, 1965, the 1st Cavalry Division (Airmobile) boards landing craft off Qui Nhon.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The View looks down the starboard side of Boxer (CVA-21).

did.unittitle: On October 1, 1965, Sgt. W.R. Melton of the 2d Platoon, D Company, 9th Marines, talks to villagers about Vietcong activity in their area.
Soldiers representing a cross-section of their native land decorate their Christmas tree at Tan Son Nhut Air Base in the waning days of 1965.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Left to right, the men are: PFC Raymond R. Schultz of Red Bluff, California; SP4 Glenn A. Rasmussen of LaGrange, Illinois; and SP5 Carlos Lopez of Brooklyn, New York.

did.unittitle: The elusive Vietcong – North Vietnam's primary asset in the war against the South and its allies.
Typical Vietcong items found in a North Vietnamese base camp.
A North Vietnamese soldier (left) and a Vietcong guerrilla dig in at a bunker position.
North Vietnamese Army regulars on parade in Hanoi during the 1960s.
This cache of Vietcong/North Vietnamese weapons captured by the 2d Battalion, Royal Australian Regiment during February 1968 illustrates the wide range of weapons used by the communist forces.
Vietcong small arms displayed at a defensive position near Lai Khe on January 8, 1968.
Captured weapons seized during fighting near Tan Son Nhut Air Base in Saigon in May 1968.
U.S. forces operating just off the coast of Vietnam recovered these supplies from a gun-running trawler.
Entrance to a Vietcong tunnel complex.
View of a bamboo punji pit designed to injure the ankle rather than to puncture the sole of the foot.
A bamboo whip, designed to be released by a trip wire.
A death fall improvised from a 55-gallon oil drum.
The Vietcong used a variety of everyday objects – in this case, a book to make booby traps.
These empty drink cans were filled with grenades.
A Soviet-built T54 tank sits along highway QL-9 after ARVN forces immobilize it in 1972.
A Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-17, similar to those used by the North Vietnamese Air Force.
The American infantryman was the mainstay of the allied military effort to maintain the independence of South Vietnam.
A soldier clutched his M-14 rifle during a search-and-destroy mission near Bien Hoa in October 1965.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the two magazines taped together.

did.unittitle: PFC Michael J. Mendoza fires his M-16A1 rifle during Operation Cook in Quang Ngai province.
A Marine sniper attached to the 4th Marine Headquarters Company aims at a target through his 3x9 scope mounted on a 30.06 sniper rifle.
SSgt. Herbert Suloff demonstrates grenade-throwing techniques for newly arrived troops of the 9th Infantry Division.
A soldier at Fire Base Abby fires an M-60 general purpose machine gun in January 27, 1970.
SP4 Donald Krug prepares to fire his M-79 40mm grenade launcher at an outpost on the outskirts of Saigon in December 1968.
A soldier demonstrates the use of an M-7 flamethrower during a Combat Indoctrination Course at Lai Khe.
During Operation Somerset Plain in August 1968, men of the 101st Airborne Division set up their M-19 81mm mortar on Landing Zone Tabat.
Members of the 505th Infantry, 82d Airborne Division, fire a round from their M-30 4.2-inch mortar at Fire Support Base Harrison.
Fragmentation hand grenades, claymore mines, and red and white flares belonging to a reconnaissance platoon of the 101st Airborne Division.
A gun crew of the 101st Cavalry Division (Airmobile) fires their M-114 155mm howitzer northeast of An Khe in Binh Dinh province.
An American M-48A3 medium tank. Note the xenon searchlight.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: During road-clearing operations a mine explosion blew off its tracks.

did.unittitle: 4th Cavalry M-551 Sheridan light tanks from the 25th Infantry Division at Cu Chi.

M-109A1 self-propelled 155mm howitzer at Fire Support Base Washington near Cu Chi.
Quadruple .50-caliber machine-gun mounted on a 2-1/2 ton truck being test-fired at Pleiku during August 1967.
A LARC of the 1st Logistical Command backs into the surf at Duc Pho.
An Army RPC (River Patrol Craft) noses onto the shore in Gia Dinh province.
T-28B fighter-bombers on the flight line at Bien Hoa Air Base
A U.S. Air Force 0-1 Bird Dog observation aircraft taxies out to the runway at Lai Khe.
In the dusk of early evening an AC-47 fires at a ground target.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This type of aircraft is the famous "Puff the Magic Dragon." Not the tracer at lower right.

did.unittitle: Ground crews direct U.S. Air Force A-1E Skyraiders from their parking areas at Pleiku in November 1966.
An excellent thee-quarter view of an OV-10 Bronco in flight over Southeast Asia during the last days of December 1968.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Bronco was used for reconnaissance and to direct air attacks, but it was also armed with guns and rockets to attack ground targets.

did.unittitle: At Da Nang Air Base, a U.S. Marine A-6 attack aircraft stands ready for takeoff on April 8, 1969.
The A-37 Dragonfly provided the South Vietnamese Air Force with much of its offensive punch in the last years of the war.
A camouflaged Martin B-57 Canberra bomber parked at Tan Son Nhut Air Base near Saigon in May 1967.

F-100 Super Sabre fighters with the 90th Tactical Fighter Squadron at Bien Hoa.
Its bomb load shackled in place, this F-105 Thunderchief stands ready for action on November 14, 1965.
Crews guide a USAF F-4C Phantom out of its revetment at Cam Ranh Bay in June 1967.
Fitted with a variety of camera equipment, the F-101 Voodoo served well in its tactical reconnaissance role.
A Lockheed C-130 transport at an air base in Southeast Asia.
Two Sidewinder air-to-air heat-seeking missiles mounted under the wing of an F-105 fighter bomber.
A2C William B. Brotton and SSgt. Raymond R. Janek load a Sparrow air-to-air radar-homing missile onto an F-4C of the 555th Tactical Fighter Squadron.
Naval ordnance personnel board an aircraft carrier hoist a Bullpup air-to-ground missile onto an A-4 Skylark.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The missile carried a 1,000 pound payload.

did.unittitle: A Shrike air-to-ground missile undergoes testing with the Navy during 1963.
Bombs and rockets arrive from the magazine of the aircraft carrier Ranger (CVA-64) off Southeast Asia.
The Navy's Walleye glide bomb was guided by television cameras.
The AH-1G Cobra attack helicopter was the mainstay of the U.S. Army's aerial offensive capability.
A U.S. Navy UH-1D in the Binh Thuy area.
Front view of the XM-21 weapon system mounted on a UH-1D helicopter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The pack consisted of a seven-round rocket pod and an M-134 high-rate machine gun.

did.unittitle: A CH-54A Flying Crane with cargo pod removed sits on the landing pad at Khe San where it served the 1st Cavalry Division (Airmobile).
A CH-47 Chinook helicopter prepares to leave after disgorging its cargo of men and supplies in the Cay Giep mountains.

An H-21 light cargo helicopter during airlift operations in the vicinity of Ap Truang Hoa, 70 miles southwest of Saigon.An H-21 light cargo helicopter during airlift operations in the vicinity of Ap Truang Hoa, 70 miles southwest of Saigon.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the crew chief at the door observing the ground below for enemy fire.

did.unittitle: With its 7.62mm miniguns for defense, the HH-53B Super Jolly Green Giant helicopter was used effectively in rescue and recovery operations over both South and North Vietnam.
Published Images
American officials and diplomats meet with South Vietnamese Prime Minister Nguyen Cao Ky during January 15, 1966.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Pictured (left to right) are: Prime Minister Ky; Dean Rusk, U.S. Secretary of State; and Henry Cabot Lodge, U.S. ambassador.

did.unittitle: January 25, 1966.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Artillery troops of the 1st Cavalry Division (Airmobile) deploy their howitzer near Bong Son during Operation Masher. Note the CH-47 Chinook helicopters.

did.unittitle: PFC George J. Pignatore, a medic with the 7th Cavalry, holds a compress gingerly against his chest, having been wounded during Operation Masher on January 25.
Terrified civilians in Bong Son undergo questioning by troops of the 1st Cavalry Division (Airmobile).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: At the time, troops were detaining large numbers of suspected Vietcong.

did.unittitle: A CH-47 Chinook disgorges a portion of the 1st Cavalry Division's 3d Brigade into a secured landing zone on a mountain ridge during the first week of January 1966.
Finally cornering a number of Vietcong guerrillas after three days of operations, soldiers of the 7th Cavalry fire into a Vietcong bunker near Bong Son.
Ten days into Operation Masher, PFC Lee A. Bilbrey finally gets a bath and a "helmet shower" after his unit was relieved from operations.

Radio operator PFC Ira B. Rolston sounds the call from a Vietcong bugle (captured during the la Drang Valley fight) for his platoon to advance down the mountain toward their valley objective during Operation Masher.
President Johnson and Premier Ky talk informally during a conference of American and South Vietnamese leaders held in Honolulu during February 1966.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: President Thieu is seated on Johnson's left, while Admiral U.S. Grant Sharp sits across the table facing the president.

did.unittitle: Crew Chief SP4 James M. Ralph of the 229th Helicopter Assault Battalion fires his M-60 machine gun into a Vietcong position marked minutes earlier by a red smoke grenade, on March 16, 1966.
Confusion reigns in Saigon after the Victoria Hotel was bombed on April 1, 1966.

PFC Frederick Culp of the 1st Infantry Division holds his weapon above water while crossing a river during a search-and-destroy mission east of Saigon, near Long Tranh, in the wake of the Victoria Hotel bombing.
On April 14, 1966, Buddhists move away from a temple to begin a parade through the city in celebration of the government's decision to permit free elections in the near future.
September 11, 1966.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The South Vietnamese vote to elect an assembly to draw up a constitution for their country. Here, President Thieu departs after voting at the polls in the City Hall in downtown Saigon.

did.unittitle: A Vietnamese policeman and soldier monitor activity at the entry to a polling place located at a primary school in Saigon.
Lance Cpl. Charles Hill assists Sgt. Lee Jankes as he fires his M-60 machine gun at North Vietnamese troops on Hill Hui-Cray-Tre during Operation Prairie near the DMZ on 30 September 1966.
Marines of the 3d Division approach a church while on patrol during Operation Prairie near the DMZ on October 27.
Troops of M Company, 3d Battalion, 3d Marines, embark on board a CH-46 Sea Knight after making a sweep through the DMZ during Operation Prairie.
President Johnson visits Vietnam. He, General Westmoreland, and President Thieu pay their respects during the playing of the Vietnamese National Anthem on October 26, 1966.

Men of the 1st Infantry Division exit a CH-47 Chinook helicopter, climbing down a rope ladder on January 8, 1967, the first day of Operation Cedar Falls, the first allied corps-sized offensive effort of 1967.
A soldier's grimace during his 100-foot descent from a CH-47 testifies to the difficulty of that task.
Operation Junction City., late February 1967.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Troops in an M-113 armored personnel carrier stop at a bridge in Tay Ninh Province.

did.unittitle: PFC Craig Yockey from Fresno, California, of the 5th Cavalry, uses his time off during Operation Junction City to make friends with Davey Detail, the unit's mascot.
Members of the 101st Airborne Division wait to unload their vehicles from LST-178 on May 2, 1967, during Operation Oregon.
Airborne troops trudge onto the sand near Duc Pho, commencing Operation Oregon.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the variety of equipment and armament carried including the M-16 rifle and M-60 machine gun.

did.unittitle: Inland and west of Duc Pho, a UH-1B helicopter lifts men from a platoon of the 1st Cavalry Division (airmobile) into an area where a suspected Vietcong outpost is located.
Men of Troop B, 1st Reconnaissance Squadron, 9th Cavalry, 1st Cavalry Division (Airmobile), during Operation Oregon.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: One points in the direction of a supposed suspected Vietcong position. Smoke canisters hang from the radio carried by the soldier at left. These were used to mark troop positions during air attacks and helicopter extractions.

did.unittitle: Members of a reconnaissance platoon observe the results of concentrated artillery fire on a suspected enemy position west of Duc Pho.
During Operation Oregon, soldiers from the 25th Infantry Division question a group of passive villagers about Vietcong that are suspected to be in the vicinity.
Men of the 25th Infantry Division wade across a shallow stream during Operation Baker on June 109, 1967.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This and the next four photos were taken by SSgt. Howard C. Breedlove, who accompanied the troops on the operation.

did.unittitle: Troops advance cautiously through a bombed-out village in Quang Tri province during Operation Baker.

2d Lt. Michael J. Pulaski (3d Platoon leader, Company A 2d Battalion, 35th Infantry, 3d Brigade, 25th Infantry Division) briefs his squad leaders on the patrol routes they will take during their search for communist forces.
PFC Harlan Slusser leaves a suspected enemy bunker after completing his search during Operation Baker.
Lieutenant Pulaski's platoon moves out and advances over a dry rice paddy.
A Sea Stallion helicopter from Marine Heavy Helicopter Squadron 463 brings an emergency resupply of 105 mm howitzer ammunition for the guns of 11th Marine.
On August 31, 1967, a river patrol craft on the right and a monitor on the left protect a construction "convoy" as it travels down the Song Vam Co Tay River to Tan An.
With construction supplies unloaded from the river boat, a soldier takes time to relax with this harmonica.

Vice President Hubert Humphrey, General Westmoreland, and Lt. Gen. Robert E. Cushman, Marine commander in Vietnam, salute the men of the 3d Marine Division during ceremonies and presentation of decoration on November 1, 1967.
Operation Bang Dong, November 32, 1967.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Members of the 7th Infantry, 199th Light Infantry Brigade, prepare to search boats that were traveling down a wide canal.

did.unittitle: Maj. Paul J. Gilmore (left) and 1st Lt. William T. Smith (right) of the 480th Tactical Fighter Squadron pose for an air force photographer in front of F-4C 64-0752 on the occasion of their being the first U.S. Air Force crews to shoot down a MiG-21.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the victory star over Smith's head.

did.unittitle: Hanoi, June 29, 1966. Oil storage facilities go up in flames in the wake of an American bombing attack.
An air hero of two wars – Korea and Vietnam – Col. James Jabra prepares a postflight report documenting his fighter-bombing mission over Vietnam on July 18, 1966.
A reconnaissance photograph shows three Russian-built MiG-17s behind protective revetments at Phuc Yen field, 20 miles northwest of Hanoi.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: U.S. pilots were frustrated that they were not permitted to attack the airfields.

did.unittitle: A North Vietnamese MiG-17 disintegrates under 20mm cannon fire from an F-105D of the 34th Tactical Fighter Squadron on August 13, 1966.
Gregory "Pappy" Boyington, top-scoring Marine ace of Pacific War fame, poses for a photograph with the men of his old squadron.
Plumes from the explosions of 750-pound bombs dropped by F-105 Thunderchiefs blossom skyward from the Xuan Mai Army Barracks and Supply Center during an attack on April 19, 1967.
F-105 Thunderchief pilots delivered their ordnance onto Hanoi's railyard car repair and storage facility, 2-1/4 miles northeast of the city center during May 1967.
Col. Robin Olds, a fighter pilot whose career extended back to the Second World War, examines ordnance mounted under the wing of his F-4C prior to a mission over Vietnam in 1967.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This aircraft is loaded for an air-to-ground mission. Often, the F-4s would load up with air-to-air missiles to fly MiG cover for the air-to-ground missions.

did.unittitle: Col. Jack M. Broughton Deputy Commander of the 355th Tactical Fighter Squadron, congratulates F-105 ("Thud") pilot Maj. William J. Bailey, who has just returned form his 100th mission over Vietnam.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Bailey donned a portion of his World War II flight gear to mark the occasion.

did.unittitle: Maj. Ralph L. Kuster of the 13th Tactical Fighter Squadron races toward an enemy MiG-17 at 200 knots closure speed during a wild dogfight over North Vietnam on June 3, 1967.
An F-100 cuts loose a salvo of folding-fin rockets into a Vietcong position in South Vietnam during July 1967.
North Vietnamese military personnel and civilians savor the moment as they parade a recently shot down American aviator into captivity.
Manacled together, two American fliers are put on display before angry, jeering North Vietnamese during July 1967, prior to their delivery to authorities for interrogation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Supported by his compatriot, the man at right appears dazed and injured.

did.unittitle: His broken right arm and multiple burns eliciting no sympathy from the crowds, Lt. David C, Rehman is paraded before a hostile North Vietnamese public.
American prisoner of war Navy Lt. Paul Galanti provides a very much coached and coerced film interview.
Empty shell casings from the 8-inch guns of Newport News (CA-128) litter the heavy cruiser's forecastle during bombardment in support of I Corps Marines in the DMZ during the latter months of 1967.
On board the aircraft carrier Canberra (CAG-2), sailors in the plotting room work out a firing solution for a target on the Vietnamese shore.
Smoke and flame belch from the 6-inch guns of Galveston (CLG-3) as six more shells hurtle toward a target in Vietnam.
Welcome to Vietnam.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Newly arrived troops disembark from an aircraft at Cam Ranh Bay's 14th Aerial Port.

did.unittitle: Arrivals from Tan Son Nhut Air Base ride by bus to the 90th Replacement Battalion at Long Binh Post.
Troops arrive from their bus ride at the 90th Replacement Battalion reception station.
Processing begins at Long Binh with a stack of forms.
Men of the 1st Cavalry Division (Airmobile) draw equipment from the Central Issue Facility of the 266 Supply and Service Battalion at Long Binh.
A Navy Seabee muscles a load of concrete during construction at Chu Lai.
Cam Ranh Bay's South Beach, seen here in a view looking north in June 1966.
A panorama of the gasoline tank farm facility at Cam Ranh Bay.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: When American first joined the war, there were almost no runways in the region that could support American aircraft. A massive building effort was necessary.

did.unittitle: The deep water port and property disposal operation at Da Nang.
Military Police escort travelers through the village of An Phu.
A convoy moves along the road leading to Duc Pho from Chu Lai.
An aerial view of Fire Support Base Sedgwick of the 25th Infantry Division located near Cu Chi, seen on August 11, 1969.
Land clearing operations at Fire Base Eunice.
Sand-bagged buildings at Fire Support Base Black Hawk.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the barbed wire obstruction in the distance.

did.unittitle: View of Fire Base Jerre showing dugouts and tents used as living quarters in December 1969.
The open-air briefing "room" at Fire Base Sabre.
Thomas Brides of the 119th Light Infantry prepares a meal for the men of his unit at Fire Support Base Eagle.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Admiring his handiwork are (left to right) SP4 Larry Simple and SP4 Willie Rose.

did.unittitle: Sgt. Ed Densen of the 27th Infantry, 25th Infantry Division, opens a pack of C-ration cocoa at the end of the day's work during a search-and-clear operation near Fire Support Base Kien on August 10, 1970.
SSgt. William George hefts a turkey drumstick onto the plate of SP4 Roy Wiley of the 1st Cavalry Division (Airmobile) during a meal on Thanksgiving 1967.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wiley's equipment was typical of the "grunt": "steel pot" helmet with camouflage cover, M-16 rifle, load-bearing equipment, and protective mask.

did.unittitle: An ARVN mess cook prepares a batch of small fish for conversion into nuoc mam sauce, a standard element of the Vietnamese diet.
Vietnamese support troops of the 50th Political Warfare Battalion enjoy their noonday meal in their battalion's newly constructed dining hall in Saigon.
GOOD MORNING VIETNAM!!

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: SSgt. Richard A. Van Dorn, Radio Production Chief of Da Nang Armed Forces Radio, "spins the wax" during a musical program on February 1, 1968.

did.unittitle: Letters from home cheer the men during mail call at Landing Zone Stud, a forward base of the 1st Cavalry Division (Airmobile), on March 30, 1968.
A chaplain of the 82d Airborne Division tends his flock at Camp Eagle during April 1968.
Men of the 101st Airborne Division take time out from Operation Van Buren in late January 1966 for religious services in the field.
At Ben Cat, about 50 miles north of Saigon, a corpsman of the 1st Medical Battalion administers a transfusion to a wounded man.
AUH-1D takes off to airlift an injured member of the 101st Airborne Division near the DMZ.
The 93d Evacuation Hospital at Long Binh in the fall of 1967.
Interior of the Tuy Hoa evacuation hospital on July 15, 1967.
Capt. Bernice Scott and Lt. David Van Voorhis of the Army Nurse Corps remove field bandages from a seriously wounded soldier sent to the 2d Surgical Hospital for treatment.

Christmas in Vietnam, red Cross aides Joyce MacCaonnackie and Khaki Barden join Lt. Daniel L. Baldwin of the 9th Infantry Division in serving Christmas dinner for troops on the field on December 13, 1967.
Armed Forces Radio disk jockey Chris Noel performs on camera for the troops during a Christmas Special in 1967.
Sgt. Craig Anderson of the 7th Marines savors a Christmas card received from home on December 19, 1969.
Bob Hope, a Christmas institution for three generations of American Servicemen overseas, teams up with the Golddiggers at Long Binh during Christmas 1968.
Members of the 101st Airborne Division enjoy the antics of Hope and company at Camp Eagle on the day before Christmas Eve 1970.
Seated on their duffle bags, 7th Cavalry soldiers wait at Vung Tau Airfield for transportation to the R&R Center at that facility.
Soldiers relax on Vung Tau Beach at the R&R Center where there appears to be only one problem – no women!
A drug raid in Da Nang by Vietnamese civilian authorities nets a room full of drug paraphernalia, opium, and marijuana.
Buddhist family shrines set up in the streets of Hué.
Film and office equipment in the rear of the U.S. information Service Building in Hué, destroyed by Buddhist demonstrators on May 26, 1966.
A group of marchers hold aloft pr-American signs in English.
Phu Nom Signal Communications Site located in the Cholon section of Saigon.
In the Tan Son Nhut area north of Saigon, personnel at the Combined Document Exploitation Center translate copies of captured enemy documents.
American soldiers packing propaganda leaflets into "bombs," which will be dropped in strategic areas of North Vietnam.
Using a microphone, a member of the 403d ARVN Political Warfare Company speaks to villagers of Ap Trung, 7 miles northwest of My Tho, about what they can do to keep Highway 4 secure.
An ABC television news crew unloads their equipment at "The Rock Pile" (Khe Sanh) on October 29, 1967.
At Khe Sanh, the 101st Airborne Cavalry set up the "Khe Sanh Saloon," a briefing tent and reading room for the news correspondence.
PFC Stephen Gaye of the 11th Light Infantry Brigade's S-4 Section conducts English classes for Vietnamese children at Duc Pho during mid-January 1968.
Children at the Holy Cross Church School in Bac Hai hamlet clutch candy and C.A.R.E. school packets during a Tet New Year's party hosted by the 199th Light Infantry Brigade on January 28, 1968.
A member of the 39th Infantry, 9th Infantry Division, carries a sick Vietnamese woman through a muddy rice field to a central medical staging area.
ARVN troops advance against communist positions in Saigon during the 1968 Tet Offensive while large sections of the city burn, set afire by Vietcong insurgents.
Nineteen Vietcong infiltrated the U.S. embassy grounds in Saigon after blasting this hole in the wall surrounding the compound.
Navy corpsmen wearing flak jackets evacuate an American soldier wounded during the attack on the U.S. embassy on January 31, 1968.
The burned-out wreck of a C-47 aircraft lies on the apron at Tan Son Nhut Air Base, A victim of rocket and mortar fire.
Soldiers move up an M-113 armored personnel carrier and an M-48A3 tank in Saigon during the height of the Tet Offensive.
A member of the 1st Battalion, 18th Infantry Division, pauses at a memorial during a search for Vietcong forces in Saigon's French military cemetery during February 1, 1968.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Members of the 119th Light Infantry Brigade established a refugee camp at Long Binh for Vietnamese driven from their home during the Tet Offensive.

did.unittitle: February 2, 1968.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An armored personnel carrier passes buildings that American forces damaged when they rooted the Vietcong from their hiding places in Bien Hoa.

did.unittitle: Clad in hospital pajamas and flak jacket, patient SP4 Norm W. Singleton checks a Vietnamese employee's identification card at the entrance to the 3d Field Hospital during 1968.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note that he carries an M-4 rifle.

did.unittitle: Hué during the Tet Offensive. Supported by tanks, Marines move to clear buildings in street fighting near Hué University on February 3, 1968.
Leathernecks of B Company, 1st battalion, 1st Marines, aid trapped fellow Marines while under heavy machine-gun fire during fighting in Hué.
February 4, 1968.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Gunnery Sgt. F. A. Thomas of the 5th Marines finds a bit of GI humor in a toy car amidst heavy fighting during the battle for Hué.

did.unittitle: Cpl. Gary D. Keller of the 1st Marine Division fires his M-60 machine gun through a bathroom window on February 6.
5th Marine PFC A.D. Crum of New Brighton, Pennsylvania, receives a field dressing from Navy Corpsman D.R. Howe on February 6.
A Marine from A Company, 1st Battalion, 1st Marine, moves out under heavy machine-gun fire in Hué during intense street fighting on February 9.
A portion of Hué's destroyed marketplace, seen on February 14, 1968.
Men of the 2d Battalion, 5th Marines, relax in front of a bullet-scarred building and light up cigarettes during a lull in the battle for Hué on February 18, 1968.
A weary Marine collapses in a heap on the front of his Ontos armored vehicle during a lull in the fighting in Hué on February 23, 1968.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Ontos carried four 106mm recoilless rifles.

did.unittitle: Seen on February 28, a bridge lies collapsed in the Perfume River in Hué, blown up by North Vietnamese sappers earlier in the offensive.
Walter Cronkite of CBS News interviews a Vietnamese professor of the University of Hué on February 20, 1968.
Marines blast away with a 105mm howitzer at the North Vietnamese forces surrounding Khe Sanh in January 1968.
An interior view of one of the many defensive fighting trenches held by Marines at Khe Sanh.
A forward observer at Khe Sanh looks for signs of the enemy activity in the distance.
MSgt. Charles Wunderlich of the 82d Airborne Division's 3d Brigade reads a newspaper on February 14, 1968, during his unit's flight to Vietnam.
Newly arrived troops of the 505th Infantry, 82d Airborne Division, stand watch during the search of a Vietnamese house near the divisional base camp on February 25, 1968.
Burdened with dufflebags and equipment, soldiers of the 82d Airborne Division exit the rear of a C-141 transport at Chu Lai Marine Corps Air Station in mid-February 1968.
Crewmen on board an Essex-class aircraft carrier prepare a Ch-47B Chinook of the 271st Aviation Company for its flight into Vietnam on February 25, 1968.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The helicopter has been pulled off the elevator and forward on the flight deck where the rotors will be installed. Note the cover catapult on the deck.

did.unittitle: Maj. John P. Obermire leads the 271st Aviation Company out of their LCS landing craft onto the beach at Vung Tau.
Clark Clifford, who on March 1, 1968, replaced Robert McNamara as secretary of Defense. (see photo 8-47)
General Creighton W. Abrams, who replaced Westmoreland as commander, MACV.
Saigon firemen pick up body of a dead Vietcong soldier following an attack on that city during May 6, 1968.
From atop a tank located on the southwest perimeter of Tan Son Nhut Air Base on May 7, soldiers fire a .50-caliber machine gun into a Vietcong position inside the Old French Cemetery.
Vietnamese Air Force troops lift a wounded comrade into a trench near the center of the Old French Cemetery during the heavy fighting off Plantation Road on May 7.
Bodies of three enemy soldiers litter the street just off Plantation Road during the battle that raged in and around the Old French Cemetery.
Fires set by Vietcong snappers burn out of control on the Newport side of the Tu Duc Bridge in Saigon during May 8, 1968.
An M-48 tank of the 25th Infantry Division backs into blocking force position on a Saigon street during the North Vietnamese and Vietcong attack on the city on May 8.
Spanning the Saigon River, the "Y" Bridge linked the suburbs of Cholon and Gia Dinh province with Saigon.

Members of the 47th Infantry proudly display a flag captured during a house-to-house search of the areas south of the Kinh Doi Canal and the "Y" Bridge during final mopping-up operations outside Saigon on May 13, 1968.
C-123 aircraft of the 12th Air Commando Squadron flying in formation spray defoliant chemicals on a jungle area east of Saigon on June 7, 1968.
Jungle areas following defoliation operations.
The nuclear-powered aircraft carrier Enterprise (CVA (N)-65) steams in the waters off Indochina.
PFC Tracy Gray rams an artillery round into the tube of a 105mm howitzer, assisted by gunner PFC John L. K. Alston during 9th Infantry Division operations in the My Cong River complex in June 1968.
Troops of the 131st Engineering Company unload their cargo from a landing craft onto the beach at Vung Tau on September 21, 1968.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mormacaltair, a Military Sea Transport Contract Freighter, stand by offshore in the distance.

did.unittitle: The political changing of the guard. President-elect Richard M. Nixon's incoming secretary of Defense, Melvin R. Laird, confers with his outgoing counterpart, Clark M. Clifford, on December 13, 1968.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The portrait in the background is that of former secretary James V. Forrestal.

did.unittitle: Lt. Col. Cecil G. Foster, commander of the 390th Tactical Fighter Squadron, counts his blessings as he stands up through a hole in the win fog his F-4 Phantom damaged by antiaircraft fire during a mission in August 1968.
Two A-1 Skyraiders of the 6th Special Operations Squadron fly protective cover for an HH-3E helicopter of the 37th Aerospace Rescue and Recovery Squadron.
Bandaged and disconsolate, U.S. Air Force Lt. Col. J.L. Hughes is escorted through a park in Hanoi in May 1969.
Veterans of two previous wars, the battleship New Jersey (BB-62) fires its main battery into a North Vietnamese position near the Vietnamese coast during 1969.
Veterans of two previous wars, the battleship New Jersey (BB-62) fires its main battery into a North Vietnamese coast during 1969.
Monitors of the 2d Brigade, Mobile Riverine Force, 9th Infantry Division patrol the Song Ba Lai River on April 14, 1968.
A Riverine Force crewman trains his M-60 machine gun at a suspicious object on shore while traveling at high speed up the Song My Tho River near Dong Tam on 29 January 1969.
Aerial view of the barracks ship Benewah.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note its brood of monitors and landing craft nested alongside.

did.unittitle: On the fantail of Benewah (APB-35) sailors man a 40mm quadruple mount while on patrol in the Glad Due area during April 16, 1968.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the empty shell casings visible in the gun tub at lower left.

did.unittitle: A SEAL team's outboard-motor assault boat speeds down a branch of the Mekong River with its squad of commandos.
SEAL Team Leader Lt. (j.g.) Robert Kerrey , later a U.S. senator, was awarded the Medal of Honor for action against Vietcong forces in South Vietnam.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Kerrey's team attempted the capture of an enemy political cadre located on an island near Nha Trang.

did.unittitle: A combat team of the 4th Infantry Detachment (War Dog Provisional) sets out on the trail of a fleeing enemy on February 18, 1969.

In response to a Vietcong attack on Long Binh Post, members of the 1stt Squadron, 11th Armored Cavalry Regiment, move out in their M-113 armored personnel carrier to pursue the Vietcong, after taking a short break in a Vietnamese a short break in a Vietnamese cemetery during February 23, 1969.
PFC Charles W. Lowery of the 52d Artillery Group arms a 155mm projectile with a fuse at this unit base in Pleiku on March 6, 1969.
Secretary of Defense Melvin Laird greets a squad of Marines of the 1st Marine Division following his arrival in Da Nang during his visit to the I Corps area on March 9, 1969.
Secretary of State William P. Rogers listens while members of the 3d Reconnaissance Battalion, 3d Marine Division, explain the mission of reconnaissance patrols in the north sector of I Corps.
Members of the 77th Artillery, 25th Infantry Division, direct their 105mm howitzer fire from Fire Support Base Sedgwick in support of an Infantry operation during May 2, 1969.

South Vietnamese General Cao Van Vein presents the Vietnamese Cross of Gallantry and the civil Action Honor Medal to Maj. Gen. Harris W. Hollis, former commanding general of the 9th Infantry Division at Dong Tam on July 5, 1969. Elements of the 9th Division took part in a stand-down and redeployment during July.
An American color guard lowers and folds the flag at Fire Base Danger as part of the stand-down of the 4th Battalion, 39th Infantry Division.
Dong Team during the 9th Division's stand-down.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A truck of the division's 2d Brigade carrying communications equipment form the Ben Tre Base Camp enters the town, preparing for the unit's withdrawal.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A CH-47 Chinook helicopter takes off from Dong Tam, bound for Bien Hoa Air Base, while participating in the withdrawal of the 9th Division from Vietnam.

did.unittitle: With high hopes for an American "Generation of Peace," President Nixon greets U.S. ground forces during his trip to the Far East on July 30, 1969.
By October 1969, many units were in the midst of the much-welcomed redeployment.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Troops of the 1st Cavalry Division (Airmobile) board an aircraft at Bien Hoa Air Base.

did.unittitle: Fronted by helmets, rifles, and boots symbolic of fallen comrades, a brigade chaplain of the 82d Airborne leads a ceremony of remembrance at Phu Lai Veterans day, November 11, 1969.
SSgt. James Craig of the 2d Squadron, 11th Cavalry, gingerly inspects a 22-pound Chinese mine during clearing operations near Quan Loi on December 26, 1969.
The mine-clearing team returns cautiously to Camp Eunice, 83 miles northwest of Saigon.
Averell Harriman, ambassador-at-large and head of the American delegation to preliminary talks on Vietnam, briefs the press in Paris, France, before the 1968 presidential election.
Abbie Hoffman talking to University of Pittsburgh students (1962).
Students protest at the University of Pittsburgh (1962).
Service for Kent State students being held in front of the University of Pittsburgh (1962).
Ambassador David Bruce, chief U.S. negotiator at the Paris Peace Talks, greets South Vietnam's president, Nguyen Van Thieu.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: U.S. Ambassador to Saigon, Ellsworth Bunker, stands behind.

did.unittitle: Henry Kissinger (left) and Hanoi's senior representative Le Duc Tho (right) engage in animated conversation during a break in the peace talks at a villa in the Paris suburbs on November 23, 1972.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The two men had met for the first time on February 20, 1970, at a clandestine meeting in Paris.

did.unittitle: Vietnamese Air Force students work on the rotor of a UH-1D helicopter during a course on helicopter maintenance at Fort Eustis Virginia in 1970.
Richard G. Scalf and Thomas R. Parrott, both medics with the 1st Battalion, 22d Infantry, take time for a game of chess at Fire Support Base Louis.
Men of the 1st Brigade, 14th Infantry, check map coordinates during Operation Wayne Thrust on January 7, 1970.
James L. Fisher of the 35th Infantry is prepared for action on the perimeter of his company command post ion northwest Vietnam during Operation Wayne Thrust.
The 155mm howitzers of C Battery, 92d Artillery, lay down a barrage at Fire Base Abby on February 7, 1970.

A communist flag, an AK-47, a poster of Ho Chi Minh, and a French 7.66mm pistol were among the items captured near the Song An Lae River by American forces operating out of Fire Base Louis, 1 mile north of An Khe.
On their Return to Kontum in Vietnam on June 27, 1970, soldiers of the 11th Cavalry hold up a sign found during the incursion into Cambodia.
Capt. Charles T. Guthrie briefs American soldiers and South prior to a sweep during a search-and-destroy mission on February 27, 1970.

During April 1970, Assistant Team Leader Robert C. Todd of Company D, 5th Special Forces Group, mans a .30-caliber machine gun on the bow of an air boat, while a student from the Vietnamese Mobile Force pilots the craft.
On April 20, 1970, a member of A Company 1st Battalion, 1st Marines, carries an M-60 machine gun on a search-and-clear operation in the Charlie Ridge area, 15 miles southwest of Da Nang.

Participating in a multibattalion sweep through the Picken Forest region 25 miles southwest of Da Nang, men of G Battery, 3d Battalion, 11th Marines stay close to their 105mm howitzer as a CH-53 helicopter lands to resupply their ammunition stores on July 16, 1970.
Cambodian refugees prepare to disembark from LSU-501 of the South Vietnamese Navy, which brought them from Cambodia on July 23, 1970.
A Kit Carson Scout of the 8th Psyops Team 173d Airborne Brigade broadcasts from Landing Zone English to nearby villages as part of the Chieu Hoi program.
"Wolfhounds" from the 27th Infantry, 25th Infantry Division, cross a stream 10 miles southeast of Nui Ba Den during search-and-clear operations near Fire Support Base Kien.
Soldiers follow their equipment and board a C-130 transport at Qui Nhon Airfield on October 30, 1970.
The "Busiest Man on the C-=130."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Using a chain lock, Loadmaster T.J. Donegan secures cargo for a shuttle run. When not loading or unloading cargo, loadmasters filled out a myriad of forms for all items and personnel carried on their aircraft.

did.unittitle: A CH-47 Chinook from the 14th Aviation Company lifts off with a sling of fuel drums during a resupply effort to units in the field.
A soldier with a camouflaged face sits alone with his thoughts during a break in the action late in the war.
A UH-1D helicopter from the 61st Assault Helicopter Company lands to pick up members of a patrol from the 173d Airborne Brigade.
On a search-and-destroy mission during Operation Bushmaster, men of the 501st Infantry, 101st Airborne Division, go out on patrol in support of an attached ARVN Ranger company during August 1971.
SP4 Roman Capone, 16th Infantry, 1st Infantry Division cleans his M-60 machine gun as his unit redeploys from Vietnam on February 18, 1970.
Men of the 101st Airborne Division hand over Fire Support Base Tomahawk to the ARVN 5th Regional Forces and render honors to the South Vietnamese flag as it is raised over the base November 15, 1971.
A captain form the 101st Airborne clutches the American flag after it had been lowered over the Fire Support Base Birmingham during stand-down ceremonies in early February 1972.
Gear and equipment belonging to men of the 101st Airborne awaits transport from Fire Support Base Birmingham after the South Vietnamese took control of the base.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the crossbow stacked with the M-16 at right.

did.unittitle: American Division personnel clean M-16 rifles prior to wrapping and shipping at the Multiple Items Processing Point at Da Nang.
Tracked vehicles await loading on board the freighter W.B. Waterman at Da Nang's deep water port.

A happy group of soldiers from the 101st Airborne Division undergo a last search by military police and customs inspectors on January 20, 1972, prior to boarding the aircraft that will fly them out of Vietnam.
Having cleared the last check point, the men of the 101st Airborne Division quicken their pace into the passenger terminal at Bien Hoa.
The Joint Chiefs of Staff meet in Washington on January 5, 1972.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: They are (left to right): Admiral Elmo R. Zumwalt, chief of Naval Operations; General William Westmoreland, Army chief of staff; Admiral Thomas H. Moorer, chairman; General John D. Ryan, Air Force chief of staff; General Robert E. Cushman, Jr., Marine Corps commandant.

did.unittitle: The 16-inch guns of the guided missile cruiser Oklahoma City pound away at North Vietnamese positions, tanks, and troops along the coast in Quang Tri province during the April 1972 communist offensive.
ARVN M-48 tanks take position near the Dong Ha River overlooking Highway QL-9 on April 10, 1972.
Smoke rises from along the Dong Ha River following air strikes by A-1E Skyraiders on April 11, 1972.
Vietnamese civilians driven from their homes seek sanctuary in the refugee center located in Quoc Hoc.
Americans used air power to evacuate civilians from the path of the offensive.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Here, evacuees from Kontum run toward a waiting UH-1D helicopter in Kontum's Teneze Compound.

did.unittitle: View of a B-52 bomber forced to land at Da Nang in April 1972.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Facilities in South Vietnam were not big enough to accommodate B-52 traffic. They operated out of bases such as Guam and used aerial refueling to extend their range.

did.unittitle: Two prominent protestors, Jane Fonda and her husband, Tom Hayden, at a rally held in the fall of 1972.

Naval aviator and pilot Lt. Randall M. Cunningham and his radar intercept officer, Lt. (j.g.) William P. Driscoll, describe to Secretary of the Navy John Warner and Chief of Naval Operations Elmo Zumwalt the action in which they scored a rare triple MiG kill on May 10, 1972, to become the only U.S. Navy aces of the war.
Two F-4D crews of the famous 555th ("Triple Nickel") Tactical Fighter Squadron pose for the camera after a dogfight in which they destroyed two MiG-21 fighters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: They are (left to right): Weapons System Operator Capt. Stephen L. Eaves and pilot, 1st Lt. John D. Markle; Weapons System Operator Capt. Charles D. DeBellvue and his pilot, Capt. Richard S. Ritchie/DeBellvue team, destined to become the only U.S. Air Force aces in Vietnam.

did.unittitle: Post-strike photography of June 26, 1972, documents the result of an air strike by aircraft from Kitty Hawk (DVA-63) on the Yen Lap railroad bridge northeast of Haiphong in North Vietnam.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the cratered bridge approach and dropped bridge span.

did.unittitle: A B-52 bomber takes off from Andersen Air Base in Guam.
A reconnaissance photograph taken on December 27, 1972, shows petroleum tank cars destroyed by American B-52s in the Kinh No railyard 7 miles north of Hanoi.

The first group of American POWs to be released during Operation Homecoming muster and report prior to their release to U.S. representatives at Gia Lam International Airport near Hanoi on February 12, 1973.
Dependents of Marines stationed at Naval Air Station Miramar wait for repatriated prisoners of war to arrive.
Family gathers on Sunday during Operation Homecoming on February 18, 1973.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The extended family of Capt. James P. Walsh celebrates Mass in the chapel at the U.S. Naval Hospital in St. Albans, New York, while Chaplain James P. McKay presides.

did.unittitle: Operation Homecoming was a two-way street.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Here, North Vietnamese POWs await exchange and final release at Bien Hoa Air Base in late February 1973.

did.unittitle: An army major representing the United States and members of the Provisional Revolutionary Government of North Vietnam arrive in Bien Hoa for the POW release.
Members of the U.S. Photographic Team Pacific document the release of ARVN POWs at Loc Ninh.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The photographers (left to right) are 1st Lt. Joseph T. Broghamer, SP6 Grant T. Lingle, SP4 Leroy Massie, and Sgt. Richard S. Hiwa, Jr. (the photographer credited with the previous two photos).

did.unittitle: The guided missile destroyer Henry B. Wilson (DDG-7), participant in the evacuation of American personnel from Phnom Penh during Operation Eagle Pull.
The flight deck covered with CH-53 and CH-46 helicopters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Hancock (CVA-19) sails off the coast of Cambodia preparing for the evacuation of American personnel from Phnom Penh on April 10, 1975.

did.unittitle: Phnom Penh seen on April 12 by Marine photographer D.L. Shearer from the left gunner port of a CH-53 helicopter as it descends toward an impromptu landing zone a soccer field.
Navy personnel wait anxiously on Hancock's flight deck fro Marine helicopters to complete their return trip from Phnom Penh on April 12.
Marine Sgt. Chuck McCormick captures a touching moment on film during the evacuation of Phnom Penh, as a fellow Marine holds a refugee baby.
The first wave of CH-53 helicopters of HMH-463 return to Hancock with the first group of evacuees from Saigon during Operation Frequent Wind on April 29, 1975.
A South Vietnamese pilot lands his Huey helicopter on Hancock's flight deck during the evacuation of Saigon on April 29.
South Vietnamese, American employees, a French nun, and other foreign personnel from Saigon line up on the starboard side of Hancock's flight deck.
An elderly Vietnamese woman sits on Hancock's flight deck and ponders her future.
A U.S. Navy photographer catches Air Vice Marshal Nguyen Cao Ky and Lt. Gen. Ngo Quang Truong being accompanied aboard an aircraft carrier following their evacuation Saigon.
The navy photographer shows a high proportion of adult males among the refugees crowding the decks and superstructure of the SS Pioneer Contender.
While fires at Tan Son Nhut Air Base burn in the distance, a CH-53 at lower right prepares to set down in a landing zone in Saigon.
An aircraft burns at Tan Son Nhut Air Base as communist forces close in on the city of Saigon.
A dozen aircraft lie abandoned at Tan Son Nhut, unable to take off because of the threat of communist SA-7 missiles nearby.
With the communist forces only miles away, Marine helicopters land in a parking lot in the northern outskirts of Saigon.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note troops deployed among the parked vehicles.

did.unittitle: A Marine CH-53 sets down on a black-topped baseball field used as a landing zone in the northern section of Saigon to pick up waiting refugees on April 29.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Troops in the distance provide security.

did.unittitle: Marines of the 1st Battalion, 4th Marine Regiment, keep a watchful eye out while guarding the landing zone.
Refugees are buffeted by rotor wash as they hurry to board.
Hancock steams for Subic Bay Naval Base on May 1, 1975, with a full load of helicopters.
South Vietnamese refugees from Saigon debark Hancock to await transportation to Grande Island U.S. Naval Base, Subic Bay, Philippines, on May 3, 1975.
Enterprise lies docked at Subic Bay on May 4, 1975 while awaiting the return of its helicopter contingent.
Two young Vietnamese girls seem hesitant to leave the bus that has taken them to Camp Pendleton, California.
Mrs. Virginia Smith (right) and her daughter Sherry (left) talk to Chu Thi Nhan, a friend of Mrs. Smith's son, Norman, who was on his way to the United States from Vietnam.
Interviewed by the French Press Service on May 6, former South Vietnamese vice president Nguyen Cao Ky sits impassively during a news conference at Camp Pendleton.
Do Hai and his wife Pham Tai stand outside their Camp Pendleton quarters with the couple's six children and their sponsors from the First Lutheran Church of Vista, California.
Marine Private R. D. Shesky of the 1st Marine Division provides a better view of what is going on for a young refugee in Refugee Camp #5 at Camp Pendleton.
On May 21, 1975, Brig. Gen. Paul G. Graham, Base Commander at Camp Pendleton, shows First Lady Betty Ford a copy of the Vietnamese newspaper being printed by the refugees.
Entertainment for the newcomers to America.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Herb Alpert and the Tijuana Brass heat up a lazy afternoon during a concert at Camp Pendleton on June 10, 1975.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Within this subseries, the images are arranged alphabetically by book title. Under each title the photographs are separated into published and unpublished images. The published images are arranged exactly as they appear in the books and are followed by the unpublished images. In addition to images considered for the pictorial, the D-Day photographs contain images gathered for the ABC documentary "D-Day: A Soldier's Story." A large portion of the unpublished photographs are filed under The Way It Was, simply because it was one of the last Pearl Harbor-related books written or edited by Goldstein that included photographs. All the photographs not directly tied to a specific book are located under the category "miscellaneous unpublished images," which is arranged by topic. Researchers wishing to view images of the daily activities of soldiers serving in the European theater should consult the photographs from the Curran and Finkel scrapbooks. The Finkel photographs also include aerial shots of Paris, Normandy, and the Rhine that were taken during bombing expeditions.

unittitle.title: D-Day Normandy: The Story and the Photographs

President Franklin D. Roosevelt signs the American declaration of war in December 1941.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His Arm band denotes mourning for his mother, who had died that autumn. Note Sam Rayburn's signature on the declaration.

did.unittitle: King George VI, in admiral's uniform, makes an inspection tour of the heavy cruiser, USS Augusta (CA-31) at Portland, England, just after 1400 on 25 May 1944.
