scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The tank crews fully expected to have to come onto the beached in several feet of water, hence they modified the air intakes with breather hoods to prevent water from being pulled into the engine, This particular vehicle has a strange mixture of U.S./British markings.

did.unittitle: Army jeep "Dam Yankee" is towed ashore after floundering in the surf on 12 June.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the black driver and the censored vehicle unit data on the front bumper. Just like the tanks, this vehicle is also fitted with an amphibious breathing tube.

did.unittitle: An Army M-7 Priest self-propelled, 106mm howitzer, "Big Chief," From Battery B, 42nd Field Artillery, waits to go onboard an LCT at Dartmouth, England, on 1 June 1944.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Breather hoods are just visible in the rear, and a sign on its front says that the vehicle is supposed to load onto LCT-234. The sign in the background, "Simonds, Ales, Wines, and Spirits," suggests that this building might be perhaps a haunt of American servicemen

did.unittitle: Hedgerow "plow" affixed to the front of an M-5A1 Stuart light tank.
Equipment carried by a parachutist rifleman.
Parachutist equipment for a rifle grenadier.
Emergency parachute rations.
Rear Adm. Wilkes (left) and Capt. Chauncey Camp (right) watch a dawn landing exercise at Woolacombe, England, on 31 October 1943.
Landing craft swing out form shore, en route to Woolacombe form landing rehearsals during 31 October 1943.
Crewmen in slickers and life vests bail frantically to clear water from a broached LCVP during the Woolacombe exercises.
Troops splash through the surf at Woolacombe as they disembark from an LCVP.
An Army staff sergeant and captain – both quite wet – watch impassively as the Woolacombe landings unfold.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The captain totes an M-1 carbine, and the sergeant wears an inflatable life belt – standard equipment in the landing craft.

did.unittitle: An American soldier reads a signboard erected at Slapton Sands on 29 December 1943 during the evacuation.
Street scene in Slapton Sands during the civilian evacuation.
A young English girl during the evacuation.
The broad beached near Slapton Sands.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the grassy slopes similar to those encountered in Normandy.

did.unittitle: LST-322 disgorges a portion of its cargo into a Rhino ferry off Slapton Sands.
Convoy of LCTs plies the waters off Slapton Beach, 10 January 1944.
Black soldiers roll off a Rhino ferry and land their jeep.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The technician 5th grade at center is apparently attached directly to the 1st Army.

did.unittitle: Landing practice 17 Mach 1944.
LCI-323 at left appears to be dead in the water, while the covey of LCVPs approaches the strand.
An L-4 Piper observation plane passes overhead after the LCVPs maker their dash for the beach.
The landing takes place.
An infantryman's-eye view of the beach obstructions at Slapton Beach.
Two member s of a Navy communications unit scan the horizon out to sea for messages from the ship approaching the shore.
(Left to right) Lt. Gen. Bradley, Rear Adm. Hall, Maj. Gen. Gerow, and Maj. Gen. Huebner consult while observing the invasion rehearsals off the English coast.
Destroyer Thompson (DD-627) refuels from Arkansas during pre-invasion exercises on 21 April 1944.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the wire, or "hawser," at right securing Thompson to the battleship's port beam and refueling line at center.

did.unittitle: LST-289, its stern blown away by a torpedo launched in a German E-boat attack on 28 April 1944, lies at Dartmouth, England.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An LCM is alongside.

did.unittitle: LST-289's badly damaged stern.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the ship's steel-hulled LCVP's and the cockeyed, single 40 mm mount.

did.unittitle: Battleships Texas (right) and Nevada lie at anchor in Belfast Lough.
General Eisenhower addresses crew members on the afterdeck of Texas.
Ike and Kirk tour Quincy at Belfast Lough.

Anesthetist HAIc Jesse Taylor (left) concentrates on the "patient" while Capt. A. Weiland (right), with the assistance of Lt. Joseph Barbella, prepares a plaster bandage for the patient's right forearm. PhM2c. Edward Schork looks on.
Members of the Army's 82nd Airborne Division display their skills in a demonstration jump.
Dignitaries including Churchill and Eisenhower watch a practice parachute drop in England on 23 March 1944.
Members of the 101st Airborne assemble a gun dropped during training exercises in Berkshire, England.
Bombs plummet to earth from a 9th Air Force medium bomber during the railroad and bridge busting campaign.
Bomb detonations temporarily obscure the bridge somewhere in northern France.
9th Air Force bombers attack yet another bride in northern France.
Smoldering remains of an additional critical bridge.
Lt. Gen. Patton inspects the engine of a P-51 at the 354th Fighter Group in the British Isles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: At far right is the group commander, Col. George Bickell.

did.unittitle: 9th Air Force reconnaissance photo shows beach obstructions near Cherbourg one month prior to the invasion.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the Germans standing and, in some cases, running among the obstacles.

did.unittitle: Normandy, 0140, 6 June 1944.
Road intersection in northern France, early morning, 6 June 1944.
Quartermaster Depot G-22 at Moreton-on-Lugg, Hertfordshire, England.
General Depot G-23 at Histon, England.
Lt. Col. D. MacArdle admires the handiwork displayed on the back of Sea 1c Edwin parker's jacket during the loading operations just prior to D-Day.
Lt. Comdr. Dwight Shepler sketches an LST in the background.
Correspondent George Hicks records interviews with men onboard an LST before the Normandy invasion.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the electronics gear in the foreground.

did.unittitle: Men of Force B (Backup Force) line up on the docks in Plymouth, England, to commence loading operations on 1 or 2 June 1944.
Two Force "B" LCVPs in Plymouth come alongside a larger ship to transfer their men on board.
Assault Force "O," lying at Portland Harbor, England, readies itself on 2 June 1944 for the voyage to Omaha Beach.
Members of the 116th Infantry Regiment, 1st Battalion, depart from the beach in a fully laden LCVP, bound for USS Thomas Jefferson (APA-30).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note inflatable life belt on soldier at right.

did.unittitle: Troops transfer from an LCVP to LCI(L)-539.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Rations are piled on the LCI's deck.

did.unittitle: Soldiers board an LCI(L).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the AA mount.

did.unittitle: Trucks destined for Omaha Beach back into LST-51 at Portland Harbor, England, on 2 June 1944.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The truck backing in is a British Bedford with American wheels.

did.unittitle: View from LST-51 as it backs away from its mooring at Portland Harbor on 2 June 1944.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: LST-75 is in the background at left, with a barrage balloon flying above it.

did.unittitle: Laden with troops bound for Utah Beach, an LCVP approaches a nest of LCIs belonging to Task Unit 125.5.3.
An Army captain guides vehicles assigned the Force "U" on board LCT-821 at Dartmouth, England, on 1 June 1944.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note M-7 Priest self-propelled howitzers among the cargo.

did.unittitle: An Army Field Kitchen Unit rolls onboard LST-506. Note cartoon painted on the side of the kitchen unit.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Just to the left rear of the kitchen, a sailor named "Dick" looks on.

did.unittitle: Utah Beach-bound M-16 gun motor carriage boards LST-47 at Dartmouth, England, on 1 June 1944.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note famed "quad-.50s" mount in half-track at left and the nickname "Der Fuehrer's Express."

did.unittitle: View of loading from hold of LST-47.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "Der Fuehrer's Express" backs in.

did.unittitle: Lying in the River Dart, LST-47 (no doubt with "Der Fuehrer's Express" safely tucked away on board).
Chaplain Meyer holds Jewish services on board Ancon, flagship of Force "O" in early June 1944.
Catholic Chaplain Deery conducts Mass on Ancon.
Protestant services in progress on Ancon on 3 June 1944.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Seated in the front row, Generals Gerow and Huebner seek reassurance from Navy Chaplain R. McConnell. Note V Corps patch on shoulder of man at right.

did.unittitle: Catholic service on a Coast Guard-manned LCI.
Dorthea L. Dix (APA-67) of Assault Force "O-3," Comdr. William Leahy commanding, lies at anchor on 5 June, following the postponement of 4 June 1944.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Embarking a portion of the 16th Infantry Regiment of the 1st Division, this unit would be the first in Omaha, on Beaches Fox Green and Easy Red.

did.unittitle: An LCVP plies its way toward a transport on 5 June 1944 off the coast of England.
Army Chaplain Edward Waters holds services on a pier.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note profusion of inflatable life belts and the soldier "Jersey" wit a -drawing of a jeep on the back of his jacket in the foreground.

did.unittitle: An Anglican priest pronounces a benediction upon the crew of HMCS Algonquin on 5 June 1944.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A destroyer in Force "J" of the Eastern Task Force, Algonquin was destined for the Canadian Juno Beach landings in Normandy.

did.unittitle: On 5 June 1944, Coast Guard Coxswain Don Brewer finds time to send home one last letter before the invasion.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note pictures of wife or sweetheart and the pipe tobacco on the shelf behind him and the pinup on the wall.

did.unittitle: Shortly before embarking on C-47 transports, members of Col. Leroy Lindquist's 508th Parachute Infantry, 82nd Airborne Division, receive V-Mail blanks in order to send one last letter to wives, sweethearts, or the folks at home.
Other members of the 508th check equipment at their temporary airfield at Saltby, England.
Eisenhower talks to troops of the 101st Airborne Division shortly before their departure.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Purpose of the "23" sign on the man at right is a mystery.

did.unittitle: Members of the 101st Airborne Division, with camouflage on their helmets and face darkened, read one last letter from home.
Lt. Gen. Brereton, commanding general, 9th Air Force, bids farewell to members of the 101st Airborne.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the very roughly and, likely, hurriedly painted invasion stripes on the fuselage of the C-47 in the background.

did.unittitle: Soldier at left in the previous picture manages a smile for the camera.
Medical evacuation teams prepare to load up for Normandy on the evening of 5 June 1944.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note Their Red Cross armbands and aircraft invasion stripes.

did.unittitle: Army troops on board a Force "U" LCT stand ready for the ride across the English Channel to Utah Beach.
A Coast Guard-manned LST departs from England on the voyage to Normandy.
A convoy of LCIs sails across the English Channel toward Normandy on D-Day.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A barrage balloon protects each LCI from low-flying aircraft.

did.unittitle: Heavily laden Rhine ferry RHF-3 makes the final leg of the journey toward the invasion beaches, while a Coast Guard rescue boat is in the distance.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The name "Hell's Angels" appears on the barge at right.

did.unittitle: Arkansas bombards the French coastline in support of the landings at Omaha Beach.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the immense cloud of black smoke from the battleship's main battery of twelve 12-inch guns.

did.unittitle: Bombardment in the vicinity of Pointe du Hoc, as seen from the battleship Texas.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the church steeple and the buildings high atop the bluffs. This village is likely St. Pierre-du-Mont.

did.unittitle: Farther down the coast, an American destroyer passes between Texas and the coast line.
Destroyer USS Harding (DD-625) stands guard over landing craft making their runs onto Omaha Beach.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the destroyer's main battery turned to port and the explosion in the center if the picture. Smoke rising behind the coastline lends further evidence of the bombardment.

did.unittitle: Georges Leygues or Montcalm provides gunfire support for the invading troops.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A Gleaves-class destroyer in the background at left.

did.unittitle: The troops go in.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Landing aircraft lumber past Augusta, flagship of the Western Naval Task Force. That Augusta's main battery is not turned shoreward was likely not a consolation to the men in the landing craft.

did.unittitle: With heavy smoke on shore drifting to the east, LCC-449 and LCg-424, British vessels under the U.S. flag, lend support to the landing operations on Omaha Beach.
Two landing aircraft, LCI-490 and LCI-496, prepare to make the last dash to the beach.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note heavy smoke on shore.

did.unittitle: LCVPs crowded with infantry from Assault Force "O-1" press toward Beaches Fox Red and Easy Green.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The LCVP at far left is from the transport Samuel Chase (APA-26)/ Note the large waves the landing aircraft churned up and the ubiquitous smoke on the beach.

did.unittitle: An LCVP from Samuel Chase charges ahead despite the explosion of a hand grenade on board after a German machine-gun bullet finds its mark.
The view from inside and LCVP heading toward Omaha Beach.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The men's attention seems to be directed at something happening off the craft's port side.

did.unittitle: American soldiers of the 1st Infantry Division reopen the Western Front against Hitler's Wehrmacht.
Somewhat later in the morning, troops disembark fro LCI-553 onto Omaha Beach.
A portion of Assault Force "O-1" splashes ashore from landing craft onto Easy Red or Fox Green.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: LCVP at left is from the Samuel Chase.

did.unittitle: Troops disembark from LCU-412 via ladders on either side of bow during the afternoon of 6 June 1944.
Soldiers wade ashore from another LCVP.
LCI-538 unloads the Force "B" reinforcements, who started landing at about 1630 onto Omaha Beach.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Obstructions in the surf can be seen behind the troops.

did.unittitle: Force "B" troops in their wet uniforms plod ashore burdened with weapons and equipment.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: One of the soldiers directly in front of LCI-538 carried an M1A1 rocket launcher with flash detector attached.

did.unittitle: The soldier carrying the rocket launcher has just passed to the left, as another man wearing an inflatable life belt trudges toward the camera.
Another platoon splashes through the surf during late afternoon of D-Day.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The soldier at left has another M-1A1 rocket launcher.

did.unittitle: LST-21 unloads British trucks and tanks including a Sherman nicknamed "Virgin" at left.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note that the Royal Navy sailor on the barge at left wears same type of horizontal band on his helmet as do U.S. navy personnel.

did.unittitle: Part of Assault Group "O-3," 16th Infantry regiment, 3rd Battalion, assembles on a narrow strip on the gravelly beach at Fox Green, Omaha.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This photo was taken near Colleville-ser-Mer.

did.unittitle: A 3rd Battalion man, cold, wet, and exhausted, huddles under a blanket on Fox Green.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: (An Army photographer named Hall took this and the next four poignant photos.)

did.unittitle: Third Battalion casualties await evacuation to England.
Five soldiers from the 1st Division, 16th Infantry Regiment, 3rd battalion.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Who would not go home.

did.unittitle: An American medical officer bandages the hand of a soldier near Colleville-sur-Mer, Omaha Beach.
An obergefreiter (corporal) from Gen. Kraiss's 352nd Division has his hand bandaged by an American captain.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The white piping on the German's shoulder straps denotes infantry.

did.unittitle: American equipment litters Omaha Beach on the afternoon of 6 June 1944.
American assault troops set up a command and information post beside a silent enemy pillbox.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the fragmentation damage next to the exterior of the pillbox.

did.unittitle: Just out of the surf, a wounded soldier from Force "B" receives a plasma transfusion.
Crossed rifles lie beside an American who perished on Omaha Beach in the 6 June 1944 assault.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the obstruction on the beach and the life belt around the soldier, who had taken shrapnel in his right leg.

did.unittitle: The scene on either Fox Green or Easy Red, Omaha Beach, in the aftermath of the 6 June assault.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Bodies and a large pile of inflatable life belts are at upper right.

did.unittitle: A landing craft unloads supplies (possibly from the BB Texas) for the Ranger battalions on Point du Hoc.
U.S. Army Rangers scale the rough terrain of Pointe du Hoc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An extension ladder is visible on the face of the cliff.

did.unittitle: Rangers show off the line and ladders used to scale the heights on Pointe du Hoc.
With his shoulder patch proudly proclaiming his status as a Ranger, the soldier at right reloads a clip for his M-1 carbine.
Lt. Comdr. John Knapper of the battleship Texas and a companion examine a German pillbox on Point du Hoc on 6 June, possibly during efforts of that ship to resupply the Rangers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Knapper had served aboard Texas since joining it as an ensign in 1939. Note the belted German ammunition at left and a dead Ranger covered up at right.

did.unittitle: Nevada (BB-36) bombards Utah Beach with its 14-inch guns in support of the 7th Corps landings.
Nevada's forward guns belch smoke and flame during the bombardment.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the camouflage paint on the gun barrels.

did.unittitle: During the morning of 6 June 1944, a shell from the German counter battery fire on Utah Beach explodes on St.-Marcouf Island.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This and the next view were photographed from the heavy cruiser Quincy (CA-71).

did.unittitle: Minesweepers working to clear shipping channels explode mines in the waters across Cardonnet Bank.
Gleaves-class destroyer throws 5-inch shells into the beach fortifications at Normandy.
Expended 5-inch/.38 caliber cartridge cases litter the deck of USS Hobson (DD-464).
Force "U" is under way.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Bayfield lowers its LCVPs into the water. Nevada just to the left of Bayfield.

did.unittitle: Lt. Abe Condiotti, U.S. Naval Reserve (USNR), credited with commanding the first boat to hit Utah Beach about 0630 on 6 June 1944.
American soldiers with full equipment leap into the surf and wade toward Utah Beach near Les Dunes de Madeleine.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This particular load includes a number of medics. The horizontal lozenge on the back of the helmet denotes an NCO so that the men could recognize their leaders from the rear. Handles of a stretcher protrude into the photo at left.

did.unittitle: The camera looks up just as the NCOs in the previous picture exit the landing craft.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A number of vehicles have already landed.

did.unittitle: Viewed form a landing craft, a weapons carrier charges ashore at Utah Beach.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the machine gun on the weapons carrier and the other vehicles on the beach.

did.unittitle: Members of the American landing party assist survivors of a sunken landing craft.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: One of the survivors at center with an inflatable life belt helps pull to shore a comrade, who looks somewhat the worse for the wear and may be wounded. An NCO and a beach landing-party member assist another survivor (left); one soldier (left center) refuses to put down his M-1 rife; and a third survivor (right) trudges ashore wearily on his own power.

did.unittitle: First aid being administered to soldiers on Utah Beach.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The survivors have collapsed on the beach and are covered with blankets. The soldier still clutching his M-1 now stands off at left. Note LCM-29 unloading in the background.

did.unittitle: Men of the 8th Infantry Regiment, 4th Division, move out over the seawall at Utah Beach.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Men rest or take cover behind the wall, where most have stored their equipment.

did.unittitle: A German soldier with his hobnailed boots and a coverall over his uniform lies dead beside a pillbox near Les Dunes de Madeleine.
Men of the 8th Infantry Regiment, 4th Division, occupy a French village just off Utah Beach.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The lead man is still wearing his inflatable life belt.

did.unittitle: Other men of the 4th Division (probably 3rd Battalion, 22nd Infantry Regiment) occupy a farmyard near Les Dune de Varreville, two miles northwest of Utah Beach, after clearing German snipers from the buildings.
The troopers shown above take a breather in the milk house of the same farm after clearing out snipers.
A heavy weapons unit of the 358th Infantry Regiment, 90th Division, pauses during its advance inland from Red Beach.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The 90th Division patch on the sergeant in the foreground has been censored out. Note the German minefield sign at right. A mortar man heads the column of the left-hand side of the road. The man standing in the road behind the sergeant is part of the beach landing party, as designated by the semicircle painted on his helmet. This is a rare photo of this division on 6 June 1944. This regiment and the 343rd Field Artillery battalion were the only contingents of the 90th Division to land on 6 June 1944. The rest followed on 7-8 June 1944.

did.unittitle: A Coast Guard rescue boat pulls alongside two sailors who have abandoned their sinking landing craft.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: They are wearing full life vests, rather than the life belts used by Army personnel. A line goes to the sailor nearest the boat, and the second sailor waits with a rope in hand to throw out to the second sailor.

did.unittitle: The second of the two sailors comes aboard.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the belt securing the rescuer to the boat.

did.unittitle: An LCM littered with debris evacuates casualties to a larger vessel.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The seriously wounded are being loaded onto a platform that will be raised onto the deck of the transport.

did.unittitle: The crew hoists the platform with casualties from the LCM on board the transport.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: They are among the first casualties to be evacuated on 6 June 1944. Empty Navy litters in the foreground await the wounded.

did.unittitle: LCI-85, struck by German shell fire, comes close aboard Samuel Chase to off-load casualties.
Casualties from the invasion on board an LST hospital ship are transported back to England.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Stretcher-borne casualties await assignment to a bunk.

did.unittitle: A seriously wounded serviceman sleeps while a tube drains fluid from his nose into a basin on the deck.
A buttock wound forces this glum serviceman to rest on his stomach.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the piping along the bulkhead of the LST.

did.unittitle: Four Americans of the 82nd Airborne Division enter St.-Mere-Eglise in the early morning shadows of 6 June 1944.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The sergeant at left is armed with a Thompson submachine gun, Model M-1 with a 30-round box magazine. These simplified weapons differed from the M1928 version in that they would not accept the large drum magazine so often associated with the gangster era of the 1920s and 1930s. Also the front handle was replaced by a simple wooden grip.

did.unittitle: A deserted street in St.-Mere-Eglise following the 82nd Airborne assault, 10 June 1944.
Two mounted members of the 82nd Airborne Division patrol the streets of St.-Mere-Eglise on 7 June 1944.
Two French refugees try to communicate with an American paratrooper.
Clutching their belongings, the same two refugees at right center press on through the village.
A member of the 82nd Airborne assists two refugees who return with their belongings to St.-Mere-Eglise on 8 June 1944.
A captain of one of the 82nd Airborne's medical detachments holds a cigarette for a comrade wounded during the fighting on 6-7 June 1944.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The man at left is probably taking down information regarding the wounded man.

did.unittitle: Dead German paratroopers from Oberst von der Heydte's 6th Fallschirmjager Regiment are lined up and arranged for burial.
C-47s of the 9th Transport Command tow in gliders past troops fighting on Utah Beach, near Les Dunes de Madeleine.
Brig. Gen. Gavin, the 82nd Airborne's bridgehead commander and assistant commander of the division, studies a map of Normandy with his chief of staff, Maj. Wilherd Harrison (right).
A 9th Air Force B-26 Marauder returning to England of 6 June 1944.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This photo was taken near Lion-sur-Mer, Sword Beach, in the British landing area. Note LCTs unloading below and the bewildering patchwork quilt of the bocage behind the beaches.

did.unittitle: Bomb group routing map form the 9th Air Force on 6 June 1944.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the path from the English airfields to Normandy and the "last resort" target identified.

did.unittitle: The 9th Fighter Command P-51C Mustangs of the 354th Fighter Group pull up and away from their airfields in England during 6 June 19044.
Capt. Don Beerbower (second form the left) is awarded the Silver Star for action in the skies over Normandy.
9th Air Force fighter pilot 2nd Lt. Robert Kelso of Jackson, Michigan, mounts his P-47D Thunderbolt during the early days of the invasion.
U.S. naval aviators of Cruiser Scouting Squadron 7 (VCS-7) are briefed before flying gun-spotting missions over the Normandy beachheads.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reading (left to right): unidentified, Wing Comdr. Robert Hardiman, RAF, commanding Allied spotting pilots; Ens. Robert Adams, USNR; Maj. Noel East, British Army Intelligence; Lt. Harris Hammersmith Jr. USNR; Capt. John Ruscoe, Royal Artillery, gunnery liaison officer.

did.unittitle: Curtiss SOC Seagulls left behind in England by U.S. Navy observation pilots. Maintenance men service aircraft to keep the machines ready for action.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A lone Vought OS2U Kingfisher lies at far right in the distance.

did.unittitle: Lt. Robert Doyle shakes hands with his wingman, Ens. John Mudgem after their return from a gun-spotting and strafing mission.
Two patrol craft maneuver off the starboard beam of Ancon while standing by off Omaha Beach during the landings of 7 June 1944.
Joint Operations Room on board Ancon.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The message on the blackboard at right reads, "Again we have been asked to do the impossible. Let's do it as usual."

did.unittitle: A pensive Gen. Eisenhower sips a cup of coffee somewhere in the English Channel off the coast of France, probably aboard the minelayer HMS Apollo.
"You name is, boss, we'll hit it."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Crews on the battleship Arkansas deliver a message to their skipper, Capt. Frederick Richards. Note details of range finder at right. At left on the forecastle, crewmen limber up with a medicine ball.

did.unittitle: One of the invasion beaches photographed from a 9th Air Force reconnaissance aircraft.
Another reconnaissance aircraft photograph s a German motorized column struggling to move up to the Normandy front.
AN aerial shot of the vehicles (tanks or DUKWs) coming ashore, the men clustered on the beach, and the landing craft at center.
An improvised wire-mesh road provides a thoroughfare fro supplies moving up.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the rocky, gravelly nature of the ground and the markers for the beach.

did.unittitle: A French peasant gives information to a corporal of the 29th Division during the push inland on 7 June 1944 near Vierville-sur-Mer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The two soldiers at left are armed with an M-1 carbine and Thompson submachine gun.

did.unittitle: Minesweeper USS Tide (AM-125) burns after striking a mine near the invasion beaches.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: PT-509 (at left) and Pheasant (AM-61) at right stand by Tide which lies at center.

did.unittitle: Members of the 101st Airborne Division charm the locals in Ste.-Marie-du-Mont.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: All the young girls are at the center of attention.

did.unittitle: C-47s and the 9th Transport Command fly low over Utah Beach during the effort to resupply troops of the 82nd and 101st Airborne divisions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Another group of C-47s is at the lower left.C-47s of the Troop Carrier Command, 9th Air Force, tow gliders over the bomb-packed shores.

did.unittitle: C-47s of the Troop Carrier Command, 9th Air Force, tow gliders over the bomb-packed shores.
9th Air Force gliders clutter fields during Airborne landings in support of the Normandy invasion.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sherman tanks are on the road in the middle distance, and C-47s circle overhead.

did.unittitle: Swooping down low, a C-47 prepares to drop out supplies to the Americans waiting below.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Parachutes from the previous drop appear at top.

did.unittitle: A C-47 dropping supplies and equipment.
Parachutes blossom, no doubt to the great relief of those on the ground.
Airborne personnel below scurry to retrieve supplies left behind in the parachute drop.
Roaring past the cameraman at low altitude, a C-47 picks up a Waco glider in Normandy.
Troops of the 101st Airborne receive directions from Military Police (MPs) stationed at a crossroads.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The gliders in the background are of the British Airspeed "Horse" type.

did.unittitle: A wrecked American glider that crashed in an orchard near Ste.-Marie-du-Mont on 7 June 1944.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the invasion stripes on the wings and serial number visible on the tail.

did.unittitle: Dead American soldiers lie near their glider.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A gas can and rations ("Field Ration K – Breakfast Unit") are also strewn about.

did.unittitle: Crash-landed Allied glider near Hiesville, about four miles southeast of Ste.-Mere-Eglise, on 7 June 1944.
Elements of the 101st Airborne press toward the village of St.-Marcouf during 8 June 1944.
With the rest of his squad pressing forward, a technician 5th grade looks to the rear, past the cameraman.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The soldiers carry a mix of M-1 carbines and rifles. The soldier at far right advances with a fixed bayonet.

did.unittitle: Paratroopers mingle with French civilians at St.-Marcouf.
Soldiers stay near trees and edge of the road, ready to take advantage of cover if necessary.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The village sign has been censored.

did.unittitle: Portions of a machine gun detachment advance into town.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The man at left carries a machine gun, while the man behind him carries a supply of ammunition. The soldier in the background makes ready to come onto the road, perhaps after exploring the rear to the right of the road.

did.unittitle: A detachment form the 101st Airborne Division with a tracked vehicle occupies the first of many French villages and towns to come.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the soldiers' 101st patches, which the omnipresent censor missed.

did.unittitle: Some 101st Airborne members proudly display their newly won war trophies – a small German national flag and German helmet.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the hand Grenades and all of the equipment the paratroopers carry.

did.unittitle: Troops pouring into the beaches included this detachment f the 5th Engineer Special Brigade, seen here splashing through the surf at Fox Green, Omaha Beach, on 8 June 1944.
"Yanks everywhere."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Seen at Red Uncle, Utah Beach, on 8 June 1944. Note the beach identification sign and landing craft in the distance. The truck at left prepares to move up the road cut through the dunes. A wire-mesh road has been laid to facilitate traffic moving up and down the beach.

did.unittitle: The destroyer escort USS Rich (DE-695) detonates a second mine amidships after losing 50 feet of its stern three minutes before.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The ship's 1.1-inch quadruple AA mount aft, just before where the first mine sheared off the stern, is still visible.

did.unittitle: A black medic administers first aid on Omaha Beach on 8 June 1944.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Apparently he is removing bits of Shrapnel from the patient's face and neck.

did.unittitle: A casualty being helped aboard an LCVP for evacuation to England clutches a carton of Chesterfield cigarettes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The broad band around the helmets of those assisting designate Navy personnel. A man in the background wades back toward the beach.

did.unittitle: His Chesterfields tucked safely away, the wounded man in the pervious photo rests in the landing craft while being transported away from France.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the Navy men wearing life vests. The wounded soldier immediately in front of the loading ramp has a German helmet as a souvenir, and the man at lower left shields his eyes form the sun.

did.unittitle: Senior U.S. officers watch landing operations from Augusta, flagship of the Western Naval Task Force, in the morning shadows of 8 June 1944.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Left to right: Rear Adm. Kirk, commander of Western Naval Task Force; Lt. Gen. Bradley, commander of American Ground Forces; unidentified; Capt. Arthur Struble, Kirk's chief of staff; and Maj. Gen. Hugh Keen.

did.unittitle: Bradley clambers up a "Jacob's ladder" while coming on board a warship, 8 June 1944, to confer with Gen. Montgomery and Adm. Ramsay, overall commanders of the land and sea operations in Normandy.
Montgomery climbs on board for the Bradley-Ramsay conference.
U.S. invasion force commanders inspect Omaha Beach on 8 June 1944.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Kirk is at left. Hall, wearing a helmet, is under the beach marker. Bradley stands at right.

did.unittitle: USAAF officers of a bulldozer battalion from the 9th Aviation Engineer Command confer during the construction of the 9th Air Force's emergency landing field near the invasion beaches.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Left to right: Capt. Raymond Carlen and Lt. Col. John Livingston talk with Maj. Gen. Ralph Boyce, deputy commander of the 9th Air Force, and Col. Philip Cole.

did.unittitle: Construction crews lay out Hessian mat material on an emergency landing trip just a few miles behind the front lines.
Crew of a 9th Troop Carrier Command C-47 – the first such aircraft to land on the beachhead in France during 8 June 1944.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the crudely painted invasion stripes.

did.unittitle: "Rick O'Shay II," the first P-47 to land on the first runway in Normandy, is armed with a bomb.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: All 9th Air Force fighter groups were officially referred to as fighter-bomber groups, reflecting the more diverse mission that would be required in the coming months.

did.unittitle: A DUWK traverses an entry through the dunes at Red Uncle, Utah Beach, on 9 June 1944.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the beach marker at left.

did.unittitle: Army surgeons work on casualties at a medical clearing station near the beaches during 9 June 1944.
Distinguished Service Crosses were awarded to leaders of the 101st Airborne on 9 June 1944.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Left to right: Maj. Gen. Taylor, division commander; Lt. Col. Patrick Cassidy, commanding 1st Battalion, 502nd Parachute Infantry Regiment; Capt. Frank Lilyman, commander of 101st Airborne Pathfinders; and Chaplain john Maloney.

did.unittitle: Armed with an M-1 Thompson submachine gun, a paratrooper of the 101st Airborne stands guard on 9 June 1944, over a German burial detail digging graves for their own dead.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Taken during the 101st Airborne drive on Varentan, 9 June 1944. The prisoners likely come from the 1058th Grenadier Regiment, 91st Division, taken during the fighting at St. Come-du-Mont.

did.unittitle: Liberty ships Charles Morgan down by the stern off Utah Beach on 10 June 1944.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: LST-474 is alongside rendering assistance.

did.unittitle: An ACS (landing craft, support) modified for hydrographic duties, serves as a survey boat on 10 June 1944.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the survey flag, the stripes on the helmets of the sailors, and a transport lying in the distance.

did.unittitle: A platoon of black troops, armed with rifles and carbines, surround a farmhouse in an effort to clear snipers from the area near Vierville-sur-Mer on 10 June 1944.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: They are led by Capt. Samuel Broussard of Breaux Bridge, Louisiana, shown at the corner of the building. The vertical stripe identifies him as an officer.

did.unittitle: Capt. Broussard climbs down from the ladder after searching the farmhouse.
The dead German sniper has been picked off by an advancing black assault unit.
NavNavy beach battalion members dive fro cover during a German strafing attack on 11 June 1944.y beach battalion members dive fro cover during a German strafing attack on 11 June 1944.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The horizontal helmet band identifies these men as Navy Personnel.

did.unittitle: The same strafers attack a Rhino ferry.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The man lying on his side at left appears to have been hit.

did.unittitle: U.S. Navy command post on one of the invasion beaches.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the helmet bands, signal lamp, a bull horn, and the heavily sandbagged structure.

did.unittitle: A Navy hospital corpsman takes time to send a letter home, using a V-Mail form.
V-Mail form provided to Navy servicemen so that they might notify home newspapers or radio stations of their role in the invasion.
Prime Minister Churchill journeys to the invasion beaches.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: He chats with Gen. Brooke on the deck of the destroyer HMS Kelvin. Note Churchill's ever-present cigar and the machine gun at center behind the two men.

did.unittitle: Gen. Smuts gazes toward the coast of France during the voyage to Montgomery's headquarters.
Gen. Montgomery steps off the launch bringing Churchill, Smuts, and Brooke to Montgomery's headquarters.
American Army and Navy Chiefs pay their first visit to the beachheads of France on 12 June 1944.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Rear Adm. Kirk disembarks (at left) from the DUKW, followed by Generals Marshall, Arnold, and Eisenhower.

did.unittitle: The "Big Brass" in Normandy (left to right): General Arnold, Admiral King, General Eisenhower, and General Marshall.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: One wonders what has their attention at right.

did.unittitle: M-4 Sherman tank "Cannon Ball" lies mired on Omaha Beach, 12 June 1944.
An Army Dodge 4X4, 3/4-ton truck, nicknamed "Sadie," comes ashore on Utah Beach during the 12 June 1944 landings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The stenciling on the front bumper has been censored, but the truck likely carries troops of the 90th Infantry Division.

did.unittitle: Low tide leaves a pontoon causeway high and dry on 12 June 1944. Note the breakwater of sunken vessels on the horizon.
With LST-325 stranded at low tide, workmen construct a sand ramp at left to permit unloading.
Troops of the 101st Airborne push forward on 12 June 1944, through Carentan, the first French town taken by the Allied armies in Normandy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the highway signs on the restaurant on the corner. The jeep at left tows an antitank gun.

did.unittitle: Destroyer USS Nelson (DD-623) in dry dock at Portsmouth, England, showing torpedo damage sustained on 13 June 1944.
Nelson proceeds toward Boston under heavy tow on 26 August 1944 following temporary repairs at Londonderry, Northern Ireland.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Towline extends from the bow.

did.unittitle: 1st lt. Merle Kirstein from Des Moines, Iowa, uses a metal detector to ferret out any antipersonnel mines that may still lie buried in a minefield.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the German Minen sign and the mines awaiting disposal.

did.unittitle: Seen from an American LST, evacuations – American wounded and POWs – are under way.
Stretchers bearers take the first of two wounded servicemen onto a waiting LST. This photo was apparently taken at low tide.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the dozer behind the jeep.

did.unittitle: Destroyer HMS Scorpion, which bore visiting Adm. Stark, commander, U.S. Naval Forces, Europe, across the English Channel on his inspection tour of the invasion beaches on 14 June 1944.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This picture was taken just before Stark boarded.

did.unittitle: Adm. Stark and Rear Adm. Kirk on board Scorpion en route to Normandy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Kirk's short sip-up makes him easy to identify in a large number of photos.

did.unittitle: Rear Adm. Kirk boards Augusta (CA-31) during Stark's visit to Normandy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the heavy cruiser's graded camouflage, rivet heads on the side of the ship, and the boarding ladder.

did.unittitle: PT-199 chops its way through the waters off Normandy, speeding Adm. Stark and his party toward their destination.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note British hospital ship at left.

did.unittitle: Adm. Stark on his inspection tour of the beaches; Rear Adm. Kirk sits in the back seat.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The two other officers are unidentified.

did.unittitle: Scene at Omaha Beach on 14 June 1944, at a newly constructed airfield overlooking the beach near St. Laurent.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A P-38J or L with invasion stripes, likely being employed in convoy cover, lies parked on the very end of the runway.

did.unittitle: On 14 June 1944, a forlorn P-47D rests on an invasion beach where it crash-landed during the early phases of the landings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The site is probably Utah Beach, as there are no high bluffs or cliffs behind the beach in the background.

did.unittitle: A flood of men and vehicles continues to pour into Omaha Beach.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the DUKW at right, the jeep and trailer at center, and the grading equipment at left, and a barrage balloon still floating above the beach.

did.unittitle: Another 50 yards down the road lies a clearing station and information station.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The influx was presumably the 2nd Division, whose lead elements disembarked on 12 June 1944.

did.unittitle: Transports and landing craft off Omaha Beach, 14 June 1944.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A nest of LCMs lies moored to the transport at right. Note the LCVP at left and its smaller comparative size to the LCMs, which were designed to land vehicles.

did.unittitle: LST-133 Down by the stern and beached off Normandy on 15 June 1944, after striking a German mine.
PFC Rocco Festa, of the 2nd Division's Headquarters and Military Police Company, tries his hand at French as he awaits transfer to a landing craft on 15 June 1944.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This was no idle diversion, for an MP's contact with the civilian population would be considerable.

did.unittitle: Chaplain John Donovan, attached to the 1st Army's 51st Field Hospital, chats with 2nd Lt. Paula Krull on Omaha Beach, 15 June 1944.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: She was one of the first frontline nurses to arrive in Normandy.

did.unittitle: Panorama of a Navy beach master unit during the post invasion buildup, 15 June 1944.
U.S. small craft recovery and repair unit on 15 June 1944.
Panoramic view of Omaha Beach around mid-June 1944.
A jeep rolls out of LST-282 onto an LCT during its transfer to the invasion beaches 15 June 1944.
Army truck lumbers off an LCM onto a Rhino causeway.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the man at left perched on a bollard.

did.unittitle: Vehicles proceed down the Rhino causeway toward Omaha Beach
Black Seabees labor to secure wire-mesh roadway material on to the sands of Omaha Beach.
An American M-3 half-track leads a column of vehicles about to exit the causeway onto Omaha Beach, completing its transfer from England to France.
After its construction in Portsmouth, England, a Phoenix caisson with an AA mount is towed into position across from one of the British invasion beaches.
U.S. Army tugs coax a Phoenix caisson across the English Channel for placement in one the artificial harbors off Normandy.
Caissons placed in position and sunk as part of the breakwater for the Mulberry artificial harbors.
An American Liberty ship stands ready to be scuttled and become a portion of an artificial Gooseberry breakwater off one of the invasion beaches.
Line of ships in the distance form Gooseberry breakwater.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: German obstructions are piled up on Omaha Beach following their removal.

did.unittitle: Aerial photo of Mulberry under construction at one of the American beaches.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Gooseberry breakwater does not show in the photo.

did.unittitle: Waves batter a Mulberry harbor during the Great Storm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The ship at right is the old British battleship Centurion, sunk to serve as a breakwater and as an AA emplacement.

did.unittitle: Landing vessels, battered by the storm, crash into the piers.
Twisted remains of the beachhead bridge at Omaha Beach following the storm.
An aerial view of Cherbourg, taken 21 June 1944, approximately a week before its capture by the Americans.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The breakwaters, projected harbor, and the bocage beyond the city's outskirts are all visible.

did.unittitle: Center of the town of Valognes on 24 June 1944, in the wake of the 313th Infantry Regiment, 79th Division.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the jeep nicknamed "Always Ruth" and the trucks and power equipment already at work clearing the rubble.

did.unittitle: USS Quincy (CA-71) lobs a salvo from number III turret past the cruiser HMS Glasgow (right).
Nevada, of Force Group 1, shells German shore batteries near Cherbourg.
Guns of Nevada's number IV turret belch flame and smoke during the bombardment of targets west of Cherbourg.
Seen from the cruiser's bridge, German shells splash off Quincy's bow during the bombardment.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note 20mm AA mounts on the bow.

did.unittitle: The duel with "Battery Hamburg."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enemy fire falls far short during the Texas's battle with the four German 288mm guns located near Fermanville, six miles east of Cherbourg.

did.unittitle: A German 240mm dud that struck Texas at 1234.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Rear Adm. Bryant and Capt. Charles Baker stand guard over the trophy.

did.unittitle: Germen shells fall within 200 yards of Texas, now joined by Arkansas, the ship from which this photograph was taken.
Cherbourg during 26 June 1944, seen from one of the concrete pillboxes overlooking the city.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An Army major is in the foreground, and the harbor facilities are off in the distance.

did.unittitle: Generalleutnant von Schlieben steps ashore in England as a POW subsequent to his surrender on 26 June 1944.
American blow up a pillbox during the final assaults on Cherbourg during 28 June 1944.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the concertina wire in the foreground.

did.unittitle: Near one of the city's fortifications, German POWs from Cherbourg await transfer to POW camps on 28 June 1944.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The American guards at left appear curiously nonchalant.

did.unittitle: German troops march through the streets of Cherbourg and into captivity for the duration of the war.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the carbine carried by the American captain at the head of the column and the man armed wit a pistol on the right.

did.unittitle: A French civilian stands at attention alongside the American battalion commander during the playing of "The Star Spangled Banner" in Cherbourg on 28 June 1944.
7th Corps commander, Maj. Gen. Collins, describes to Lt. Gen. Bradley how the corps took Cherbourg.
Maj. Gen. Barton, commander of the 4th Infantry Division during the Cherbourg campaign, receives a kiss from a young French woman.
View of Gare Maritime, the railway ferry terminal in Cherbourg harbor, showing the work of German demolition teams.
Cherbourg Railway Station, where a collapsed section of roof pins a freight car to the track.
A damaged German gun emplacement in the fortifications near Cherbourg harbor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Camouflage netting hangs in ruins.

did.unittitle: View of Slipway Number 1 on 4 July 1944, looking toward basin napoleon III. The old cannons are used as bollards.
Incomplete German V-1 launching site near Cherbourg on 12 July 1944, with a view of the rear of the launch ramp.
Front view of the V-1 launch ramp; note staff car at right.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Camouflage netting at left appears to be hiding some additional construction materials.

did.unittitle: Two British minesweepers detonate German mines in the waters off Cherbourg just before a convoy of supply ships enters during 2 July 1944.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Fort L'Ouest is in the background.

did.unittitle: American Army engineers work to disable a live mine found underneath the docks at Cherbourg.
An American 2-8-0 "Consolidation" locomotive swings out from the SS Seatrain Texas and is placed upon rails on 13 July 1944.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This was part of the effort to replace French rolling stock destroyed during the fighting and by German demolition teams, whose work Hitler later commended as "exemplary."

did.unittitle: A U.S. medical corpsman gives candy to a French girl injured in the invasion.
A German 88mm gun protrudes from a battered pillbox on Omaha Beach. This photo was taken on 4 August 1944.
Damage to the muzzle break of the gun in photo 8-2.
A soldier holds up his Strateline ruler to document damage to this German turret in the Utah Beach fortifications.
Children playing with debris left behind by the retreating German Army.
A dead American soldier rests in a temporary grave, awaiting disinterment and reburial in the large cemetery.
French peasants pay their respects to an American who met with his death far from home.
Army officers examine papers left behind in a pillbox along the Normandy coast.
PFC Michael Rolish takes a rare moment to relax and take off his shoes.
A German NCO is brought in at the point of a bayonet.
German POWs bear a stricken comrade to a landing craft waiting on the beach at Normandy.
German soldiers being searched and questioned in an encampment on the Normandy beachhead.
Resting in an enclosure on Utah Beach, German prisoners await transport to camps in England.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This photo was taken on 6 June 1944.

did.unittitle: Captured Germans "feast" on K rations on Omaha Beach during 9 June 1944.
A forlorn group of German POWs trudges to the transports that will carry them to England.
Italian and German prisoners on board Texas being taken to camps in England during June 1944.
German POWs disembark from an LCT at a port somewhere in England.
Montgomery's personal C-47 rests on the hardstand at a fighter base in Normandy on 19 July 1944.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: As the sign indicates, this was a special parking place for aircraft belonging to four-star generals.

did.unittitle: Montgomery meets with Eisenhower following the initial campaign.
During this meeting Eisenhower chats with one of the RAF pilots of his fighter escort for the flight to France.
A sergeant and a technician 5th grade study French with two members of the Women's Army Corps (WACs) while crossing the English Channel during 15 July 1944.
The first WACs to arrive in France disembark from a transport and pile into an LCM on 15 July 1944.
Field nurses of the 13th Field Hospital, the first to arrive in Normandy, enjoy one of many meals in the field.
Military life begins to return to normal, 17 July 1944.
Soldiers eat and listen to the latest news on their Philco radio outside their pup tents on the Normandy beachhead, 12 June 1944.
Cpl. Charles Vaughn a barber from Lush, Wyoming, opens up shop in Normandy.
Two USO performers, Stephanie Dale and Josephine Del Mar, step out of the "ladies only" facilities at the show on 25 July 1944.
American soldiers crowd around an improvised stage at the first USO camp show in France on 26 July 1944.
Army nurses and servicemen line up on 8 August 1944 for an almost first-run movie, Casanova Brown, starring Gary Cooper and Teresa Wright.
Navy Seabees take a break in their routine for some refreshments.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the fresh flowers on the vehicle's counter at right.

did.unittitle: Jewish services proceed in Normandy quite unhindered on the shores of Hitler's "Fortress Europe."
American troops present arms in tribute to their fallen comrades who lie buried in a temporary cemetery on the beachhead at Omaha Beach, 12 June 1944.
On 25 June 1944, Chaplain Paul McGovern leads a group of combat engineers in prayer during a memorial service at the temporary cemetery on Omaha Beach.
French civilian sand some German POWs work on construction of the permanent cemetery on Omaha Beach, 4 August 1944.
In the background of the previous photo, French workers set crosses upon the graves of the slain American soldiers.
Ste.-Mere-Eglise Cemetery, 1 June 1945.
Aerial view of the Normandy Cemetery, 28 May 1957.
Two men pay tribute to the fallen.
Extras
D-Day Documentary
D-Day Documentary

unittitle.title: Fading Victory: The Diary of Admiral Matome Ugaki, 1941-1945

did.unittitle: Published Images
The Pacific Theater; Credit: Hydrographic Office, U.S. Navy
His Imperial Majesty Hirohito, Emperor of Japan (UPI Photo)
Ugaki's family in 1936, when he was a captain.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: To his left is his wife Tomoko. Hiromitsu, his son, stands behind Ugaki. The seated young man is unidentified. (Courtesy of Masataka Chihaya)

did.unittitle: Portion of Ugaki's preface to his diary. (Courtesy of Masataka Chihaya)
Ugaki's entry for 7 December 1941. (Courtesy of Masataka Chihaya)
Admiral Isoroku Yamamoto, Commander in Chief, Combined Fleet. (Gordon W. Prange collection)
Admiral Isoroku Yamamoto, Commander in Chief, Combined Fleet; inset. (U.S. Navy)
Admiral Yamamoto with members of the Combined Fleet staff and the subordinate fleet commanders.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: First row, sitting: VADM Mitsumi Shimizu, VADM Hosokaya, VADM Nobutake Kondo, Adm. Yamamoto, VADM Shira Takasu, VADM Chuichi Nagumo, VADM Nishizo Tsukahara, VADM Shigeyoshi Inouye. (Gordon W. Prange collection)

did.unittitle: Rear Admiral Takijiro Onishi, founder of the kamikaze special attack force. (U.S. Navy)
Vice Admiral Chuichi Nagumo, commander in chief of Pearl Harbor Task Force. (Gordon W. Prange collection)
Capt. Shiegnori Kami, staff officer, Naval General Staff. (Gordon W. Prange collection)
Rear Admiral Ryunosuke Kusaka. (Gordon W. Prange collection)
Admiral Yamamoto (seated fifth from the right) and staff of Combined Fleet.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Ugaki is seated to Yamamoto's right. (Gordon W. Prange collection)

did.unittitle: Vice Admiral Jisaburo Ozawa, commander, Southern Expeditionary Fleet; later commander in chief, Third Fleet (U.S. Navy)
Admiral Osami Nagano, chief, Naval General Staff. (U.S. Navy)
Rear Admiral Takeo Kurita (Gordon W. Prange collection)
Vice Admiral Mitsumi Shimizu. (Gordon W. Prange collection)
Rear Admiral Tamon Yamaguchi, commander in chief, Second Carrier Division. (Gordon W. Prange collection)
Captain Yasuji Watanabe, plans officer, Combined Fleet. (Gordon W. Prange collection)
Admiral Teijiro Toyoda, foreign minister, Third Konoye Cabinet. (Gordon W. Prange collection)
Admiral Soemu Toyoda, commander in chief, Combined Fleet, in the later years of the war. (Gordon W. Prange collection)
Captain (Baron) Sadatoshi Tomioka, chief, First Section, Naval General Staff. (Gordon W. Prange collection)
Type 97 attack plane of the second wave pulls up and away from Shokaku's flight deck in the early morning light of 7 December 1941. (U.S. Navy)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This photo is from a color portrait taken by official photographer Walter Frentz during Peiper's visit to the führer's headquarters at Wolf's Lair. The original color paint shows dark circles under Peiper's eyes, evidence of either fatigue or stress suffered on the Russian Front or perhaps a vitamin-C deficiency.

The war correspondent backtracks approximately fifteen steps to get a better photograph of the antitank gun.
The American prisoners from the 99th Infantry Division trudge to the rear on the road between Lanzerath and Merischeid.

A Königstiger with its 88mm gun pointing skyward clanks down the road toward Lanzerath while U.S. 99th Division POWs pass in the opposite direction.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the checkerboard divisional patch on the sleeve of the private first class at far right.

did.unittitle: More POWs trudge down Rollbahn D toward Merlscheid.
German soldiers from the 18. Volksgrenadier-Division, 5. Panzer-Armee, near Roth rummage through the camp of the U.S. 14th Cavalry Group, which was attached temporarily to the 106h Infantry Division.
The correspondent follows two other soldiers into camp.
An SS infantryman examines an abandoned U.S. M45 quadruple machine-gun mount belonging to the 413th AAA Battalion, attached to the First Army
U.S. enlisted billets at Roth.
Abandoned olive-drab tents contrast against the gray December sky.
Captured U.S. rations high in a German Kübelwagen.
The ignominy and impersonal brutality of war. Luftwaffe personal loot American corpses at a crossroads in Honsfeld; note the barefoot American at far left.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The German soldier at left appears to be putting something in his pockets.

did.unittitle: American casualties from the fighting in Honsfeld facedown in the mud.
Triumphant Luftwaffe soldiers take a short breather. Note gas mask canisters carried by the soldiers at right and the bandoliered MG42 ammunition worn by the soldier at left.
An SdKfr 251 half-track proceeds through Honsfeld on its way toward Büllingen.
American dead near their 76mm antitank gun in Honsfeld.
Likely having just departed Honsfeld, two SS-Kradschützen press forward on their motorcycle.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the "cat-eye" cover on the headlamp.

did.unittitle: Seated in his Schwimmwagen, a company commander of SWS-Panzer-Aufklärungs-Abteilung 1 (Kampfgruppe Knittel), possibly Obersturmführer Walter Leidreiter of 2. Kompanie, checks his map.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the road sign knocked askew and the American "202 ORDDEPOT FWD" placard placed atop the signpost. The Schwimmwagen was an amphibious version of the Kübelwagen.

did.unittitle: Vehicles from Kampfgruppe Hansen make a left turn toward the town of Recht. In front is a Steyr 1500 truck.
Loaded down with Luftwaffe Fallschrimjäger, Tiger II "222" from Kampfgruppe Peiper clatters northwest and straight through Kaiserbaracke on the way to Ligneuville.
Half-tracks of Kampfgruppe Knittel clank through Kaiserbaracke, bound for Ligneuville.
Cigar between clenched teeth, Ochsner poses in his Schwimmwagen beside the Malmédy and St. Vith road signs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Previously published versions of this and the two subsequent photos have often purported (in error) to show Obersturmbannführer Joachim Peiper.

did.unittitle: A cooperative Ochsner, his driver, and Oberscharführer Persin check their map for the eager Kriegsbericher.
Chomping on what is probably one of Ochsner's cigars, the Schwimmwagen driver, a Rottenführer, mugs for the folks at home.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This photo makes it obvious that the man at the left is not Peiper. Peiper had finer features, a thinner face, and a cleft chin.

did.unittitle: Loaded down with a host of Fallschirmjäger, a Tiger II rolls through the vicinity of Ligneuville between Rollbahnen D and E.
Luftwaffe personnel on the Königstiger accept a light for their cigarettes from an Unterscharführer on a motorcycle.

Sturmbannführer Gustav Knittel (right) commander of SS-Aufklärungs-Abteilung 1, and the commander of his staff company, Obersturmführer Heinrich Goltz, checks maps at Vaulx-Richard on the aftermath of 18 December.
A ruddy-faced Goltz glances uneasily at the camera, while Knittel, with binoculars, remains absorbed in his map board.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Knittel's interwoven shoulder boards proclaim his rank of major in the SS. Goltz wears a leather overcoat over a camouflage smock and tunic while Knittel is in a waist-length leather jacket.

did.unittitle: Knittel, binoculars in hand, and Goltz gaze up at the sky, likely having heard the arrival of the Panzer spearheads' worst enemy -- the U.S. fighter-bombers of the Ninth Air Force.
Two SS NCOs, an Unterscharführer (left) and a Hauptscharführer (right), help themselves to a box of American cigars.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Both men are in autumn-pattern smocks over field-gray tunics with their collars pulled up and out to display insignia of rank. Note the column of vehicles in the distance.

did.unittitle: Infantry atop a Panzerspähwagen SdKfz 234/1 armored car rush westward during the breakthrough of the American lines.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The inverted triangle left of the antenna is a hatch cover that folds down over the 20mm gun turret. Note evergreen camouflage.

did.unittitle: How many Gernadiere does it take to move a captured American jeep?

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Probably directing the effort, the Hauptscharführer from photo 4-50 stands at center behind the radio-equipped jeep. Note the mix of overcoats and occasional camouflage smocks. A few of the soldiers have turned their hats around backward or pulled their earflaps down.

did.unittitle: An SS antitank platoon (see the men in the middles distance) armed with Panzerschrecken or "bazookas," traverses muddy, snow-covered roads during its advance into Belgium.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A Kübelwagen and armored car are just visible in the background at left.

did.unittitle: Three SS Grenadiere, two armed with Mausers, press south alongside the road leading to Poteau while a photographer stands outside a barbed-wire fence to record the action.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Another Kreigsberichter stands at right with a motion picture camera. The photographer next will move down past the evergreen tree at far left. Note the abandoned U.S. jeep just beyond the correspondent and the M8 Greyhound armored car at left, barely visible through the fog.

did.unittitle: Upon reaching the M8, an SS man climbs through the barbed-wire fence away from the road and snags his coat.
Safely through the fence, two Grenadiere attack some twenty yards south of the road.
The attack moves forward and to the left, toward a small grove of trees.
The Grenadiere press forward past the wrecked jeeps and half-tracks of the 14th Cavalry Group.
An Untersturmführer (left) and Rottenführer rest from the day's labor under a U.S. M8 Greyhound armored car.
Across the road from the M8's safe haven lie other U.S. vehicles, burning and abandoned.
The Rottenführer of photo 4-59 retreated up the road some distance so that he may be seen "advancing" to the south.
The Rottenführer emerges from the smoke with his decorations and badges clearly visible.
Posing again, the Rottenführer orders an imaginary attack across the road to the northwest.
A jumble of U.S. vehicles clogs the road to Poteau.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the machine gun mounted atop the M3 half-track.

did.unittitle: The Grenadier at left in photo 4-61 steps into the camera's sight to lean an attack but in the wrong direction, or northeast, back toward Recht.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Although staged, this is a superbly composed shot of an enlisted man and his equipment -- a shelter quarter tied onto his back, an entrenching tool and map case suspended from his belt, and an MP43 (or StG44) assault rifle in his hand.

did.unittitle: The infantryman from the previous photo advances toward Poteau from the same position but now in the correct direction.
Looking south toward Poteau, the orientation of the U.S. armored car's turret (right) documents the likely direction of the initial attack that precipitated the American panic.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The marking on the M8 at right, "1A 18C," indicated that the armored car belonged to the 18th Cavalry Reconnaissance Squadron, which was assigned to the First Army. Note the vehicle's tires are equipped with snow chains.

did.unittitle: View looking back up the road toward Recht.
A Luftwaffe Unteroffizier armed with a captured M1 carbine advances south along the road embankment.
Recruited as actors, SS infantrymen press to the north, "advancing" the wrong way down the road toward Recht instead of Poteau.
A handsome, heavily armed Grenadier tousled hair sticking out from under his helmet, pauses for the camera.
Reset and try again.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The soldiers back up for another staged advance toward Recht.

did.unittitle: Enough acting -- it's time for a smoke break!
More cigarettes for the men of the SS-Panzergrenadier-Regiment 1.
SS troops savor the fruits of victory on the road to Poteau. (left to right) SS men 2,1,4,3, and 5.
Their break over, the soldiers begin to advance, this time, at least, in the right direction.
At the photographer's behest, three Grenadiere launch an impressive if very much staged, attack to the north.
SS man 3 gets on last close-up for the home front and one last opportunity to loot American treasure, yielding a tin of rations (as prized as American cigarettes) from an armored car.
SS men 2, 1, and 3 accompany the photographer back to his vehicle, "advancing" as they go.
SS men 2 and 1 continue the advance against the backdrop of burning American vehicles.
Troops move north at the scene of the skirmish depicted in photos 4-54 and 4-55.
Two officers, one of whom is possibly the commander of the company currently in the area, pass the photographer.
The troops stage one last advance to the south while exiting from the scene.
A Jagdpanzer IV/70 bypasses the American logjam ahead by moving off onto the south side of the road.
Two self-propelled guns are moved into firing position.
Obersturmbannführer Otto Skorzeny, 150. Panzer-Brigade and leader of Operation Greif, shown here as a Hauptsturmführer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This photo is one of several portraits of Skorzeny by Hitler's photographer, Heinrich Hoffmann. Although it has been published several times, this is the first instance where it has been used unretouched, showing Skorzeny's original rank. It was common practice for German war heroes to be "promoted" to their current rank in official photography. Note the prominent Schmisse, or dueling scar, on Skorzeny's left check.

did.unittitle: A Sturmgeschütz from Hauptmann Scheff's Kampfgruppe Y that the Americans found abandoned at Geromont.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the white star painted on the sides and front. The 291st Combat Engineers removed a bobby trap from the vehicle on 15 January 1945.

did.unittitle: After the explosion of an incendiary grenade that Skorzeny's retreating commandos had planted, a booby-trapped SdKfz 250 light half-track from the 150. Panzer-Brigade burns in Regne, Belgium.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: As with the brigade's other vehicles, this one was painted olive drab and adorned with the obligatory white star.

did.unittitle: An American military policeman (MP) checks the papers of a Belgian civilian near Bastogne on 21 December.
A German soldier, partially clad in American clothing, lies dead in Hotton, Belgium.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The hapless man's dog tags have been pulled out from his tunic, presumably as evidence of his misdeeds.

did.unittitle: Found guilty of espionage, Greif commandos (left to right) Wilhelm Schmidt, Günter Billing, and Manfried Pernass await their execution on 23 December.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: MPs secure the trio to shooting posts erected near the wall of the building behind. Schmidt cannot look at the firing squad. The bespectacled Billing stares unblinking ahead. Pernass, not net tied to the post, looks to his leader, perhaps for inspiration of encouragement.

did.unittitle: As MPs tie up Pernass, pulling his hands behind him, the convicted spy continues to look expectantly toward Billing.

With Pernass blindfolded and secured to the shooting post, Capt. Joseph Eiser, medical officer of the 633d Clearing Station, affixes a target for the firing squad (a four-inch white circle pinned over the heart).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A grim-faced MP stands close by. Note that are no bullet holes in the wall behind Pernass.

did.unittitle: Started Signal Corps photographer Cpl. Edward A. Norbuth flinches, blurring the photographic image, as the volley from the firing squad crashes into the three prisoners and the wall behind. Four riflemen were assigned to each convicted spy.
Gefreiter Wilhelm Schmidt pays the price of a failed mission.
Oberst Freiherr Friedrich-August von der Heydte, shown here as a major in 1943.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A veteran parachutist and a certified German hero, von der Heydte commanded I./Fallschirmjäger-Regiment 3 during the legendary, if ill-fated, airborne assault on Crete.

did.unittitle: A Junkers Ju-52 in winter camouflage wrecked when it attempted to land near Asselborn in northern Luxembourg.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Although not associated directly with Stösser, this aircraft was from one of the transport groups supporting the operation. This particular aircraft and another have often been erroneously attributed to Kampfgruppe von der Heydte, when, actually, both aircraft landed in an attempt to service a German field hospital near Asselborn.

did.unittitle: An American patrol from Company F, 3d Battalion, 1st Infantry Regiment, probes the Belgian woodlands in search of German paratroopers on 18 December 1944.
Men of the 3d Battalion, 18th Infantry Regiment, bide their time near Sourbrodt, Belgium, and wait for their comrades to flush Fallschirmjäger from the woods nearby on 19 December.
Near Sourbrodt, Pvt. Harry N. Newton of Detroit, Michigan, examines supply containers dropped by the Luftwaffe for Operation Stösser paratroopers.
American soldiers hold up German parachutes near Sourbrodt on 19 December, mute testimony to Operation Stösser.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Silk parachute material accompanied at least one Ardennes veteran back to the States. Capt. Arthur D. Wenger, chaplain in the 76th Division and father to one of the authors, used the silk to make pajamas. Unfortunately, the dye in the silk had no more staying power than von der Heydte's paratroopers; the pajamas ruined a set of bedsheets the first night Wenger wore them.

did.unittitle: Receiving medical aid from Capt. Albert J. Haft and Lt. Col. John R. Woodruff, Oberst von der Heydte lies on a stretcher after he surrender to 99th Infantry Division troops.
Map -- Peiper's Fateful "Detour" to Ligneuville
This view shows the U.S. convoy's final approach to the Baugnez crossroads, moving up the hill east from Malmédy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Abandoned vehicles from Battery B, 285th Field Artillery Observation Battalion, still litter the side of the road.

did.unittitle: View at Baugnez looking due west down the roads that fork (left) to Hedomont and (right) down the hill to Geromont and Malmédy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The lead vehicle in the U.S. convoy was just about to make a right turn out of the photo at left toward Ligneuville and St. Vith. The truck at right, driven by Sgt. Alan M. Lucas, was actually the second vehicle in the convoy behind Lieutenant Lary's jeep. Note the house at left center, also visible in the previous photo. The ambulance at far right was driven by Pvt. Roy B. Anderson.

did.unittitle: This view greeted the vehicles of Kampfgruppe Peiper as they approached Baugnez perhaps one hundred yards from the crossroads.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A shed belonging to Henri LeJoly lies on Highway N23 (the road to Ligneuville) at left. The U.S. column was just behind the line of trees at right.

did.unittitle: Commander of I./SS-Panzer-Regiment 1, Sturmbannführer Werner Pötschke, shown earlier in his career as a Hauptsturmführer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Perhaps a convenient scapegoat, Pötschke was killed in Hungary during March 1945 and thus could tell no tales or provide any rebuttal regarding the massacre.

did.unittitle: The killing field.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Bodarwé café and the U.S. convoy lie some distance behind the photographer. Highway N23, Kampfgruppe Peiper's exit route from the scene, runs toward Ligneuville between the rows of trees at left. Also visible at left is the shed of Henri Lejoly, a Belgian witness to the massacre. National Archives 111-SC-226664, 111-SC-22663, 111-SC-226508, 111-SC-226507

did.unittitle: The burned-out ruins of Madame Adèle Bodarwé's house and café seen from the east.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Peiper's Kampfgruppe would have advanced straight toward the café in the distance behind the trees at center.

did.unittitle: Henri Lejoly, civilian witness to the massacre, played a far from heroic role.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
