scopecontent.p: In the Bodarwé café at the time, he waved a welcome to the Germans and a little later pointed out the hiding place of some Americans. Even so, the Germans prepared to kill him because he had witnessed the massacre, but after a time let him go. National Archives 111-SC-226667

did.unittitle: View from the east window of the house in photos 5-19 and 5-20, with the Bodarwé café at left and the corner of the massacre site at right.
Highway N23, the road by which Kampfgruppe Peiper continued its advance to Ligneuville.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the N23 signpost at left and the shattered branches of the trees, perhaps damaged by German shellfire.

did.unittitle: Men from Company C, 291st Combat Engineers, pose at Baugnez for a group photograph on 16 January 1945.
Black soldiers from the 3200th Quartermaster Service Company, led by 2d Lt. F.J. Fraser (second row, far right) National Archives 111-SC-226884
An engineer walks past the head of the U.S. convoy toward the massacre field, which is just out of the photograph at left.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Jeeps head down the road to Hedomont, likely carrying more engineers. The "1A-285FOB B-2" marking on the GMC two-and-half-ton truck denotes second vehicle of Battery B, 285th Field Artillery Observation Battalion, assigned to the First Army. A Sherman tank stands next to the house in the background.

did.unittitle: Using mine detectors, engineers work to locate the slain American soldiers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This scene is viewed looking south from the road to Hedomont.

did.unittitle: After sweeping away the snow, an engineer uncovers the corpse of an American Soldier.
The grisly task of locating the American bodies continues, with the second and third bodies uncovered.
Looking northeast toward Bodarwé's café, the photographer snaps the main group of Americans massacred at Baugnez.
Two American bodies lie approximately one hundred yards from the massacre site.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The view is along south side of the road to Hedomont, looking west toward the crossroads.

did.unittitle: Two black soldiers carry a victim to a waiting transport vehicle.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Private Anderson's ambulance is at left. National Archives 111-SC-226653

did.unittitle: An army in retreat.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Vehicles belonging to the 99th Infantry Division withdraw to the west through the town of Wirtzfeld during 17 December 1944. Vehicles markings indicate that the truck is from the 372d Field Artillery Battalion, the 99th Infantry's heavy 155mm battalion. An M10 tank destroyer covers the withdrawal.

did.unittitle: Likely from Kampfgruppe Peiper, A PzKpfw IV lies turret upended, put out of action by a tank destroyer in Wirtzfeld -- one hopes by the M10 in photo 5-37!
American infantry of Company G, 23d Regiment, 2d Infantry Division, dig in along an embankment on 17 December.
Men of the 26th Regiment, 1st Infantry Division, move up to meet the German thrusts threatening the town of Büllingen on 17 December.
The 26th Infantry Regiment's 1st Battalion advances to repel German attacks near Butgenbach during 17 December.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the destroyed railroad bridge in the background and the sign at left that cautions drivers about craters in the road.

did.unittitle: Two Panthers of I./SS-Panzer-Regiment 12 in Krinkelt were eliminated by U.S. bazooka teams on 17 December.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note that the side armor plating has been blown loose.

did.unittitle: A Hitlerjugend crewman of Panther "126" surrenders to the Americans south of Krinkelt on 17 December.
On 19 December the remains of a gasoline dumps that the Americans set on fire as a roadblock north of Stavelot.
Troops of the 325th Gilder Infantry, 82d Airborne Division, move up the road near Werbomont, Belgium, on 20 December in heavy fog.
M36 tank destroyers plunge through the gloom near Werbomont in support of the 82d Airborne Division.
On 21 December, M10 crewman from the 823d Tank Destroyer Battalion of the 30th Division pose beside their vehicle in Stavelot, Belgium, for Signal Corps photographer V.C. Calvano.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The photo commemorates their destruction of four tanks belonging to Kampfgruppe Peiper.

did.unittitle: Stavelot, 21 December.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A dead SS Leibstandarte infantryman serves as a reminder of Kampfgruppe Knittel's drive through the town on 18 December. The American reoccupied the town three days later.

did.unittitle: An army convoy stops to rest in the snowscape of the Ardennes during 22 December.
Snow covered St. Vith during the American effort to retake the town on 24 January.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Allied bombing while the town was in German hands resulted in the moonlike landscape seen here. Few buildings were left intact. National Archives 111-SC-265513

did.unittitle: At XVIII Corps headquarters in Harzé, Belgium, Lieutenant General Hodges pins a Silver Star on Brig. Gen. Robert W. Hasbrouck for gallantry in action during the defense of St. Vith. 111-SC-279922
Maj. Gen. William H. Morris (center), commanding general, 10th Armored Division.
Guns of the 969th Field Artillery Battalion dig in to support the 101st Airborne Division.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Here men work to unload 155mm howitzer shell cases from the ammunition truck at left.

did.unittitle: 110th Infantry Regiment "orphans" from Maj. Gen. Norman Cota's 28th Infantry Division share worried expressions in Bastogne on 19 December.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The soldier at left is armed with grenades and an M1 carbine. A broadside addressed to Bastogne's inhabitants is attached to the bulletin board behind the soldiers.

did.unittitle: Troops of the 506th Parachute Infantry, 101st Airborne Division, move out from Bastogne.
Heavy artillery evacuates Bastogne during 20 December.
Men of Company B, 630th Tank Destroyer Battalion (sans M36s), armed only with rifles, dig in at their roadblock near Wiltz.
Major Rolf Kunkel, Kampfgruppe leader, 26. Volksgrenadier-Division, shown here earlier in the war as a young Leutnant.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Kunkel commanded his division's Aufklärungs-Abteilung 26.

did.unittitle: Brig. Gen. Anthony C. McAuliffe, acting commander of the 101st Airborne Division and commander of the Bastogne garrison.
Col. Joseph H. Harper, commander of the 327th Gilder Infantry of Bastogne.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: He is shown here on 14 December 1951, when he was assigned to the 4th Infantry Division.

did.unittitle: Map -- The siege of Bastogne, 23 December 1944.
One of 241 C-47s from IX Troop Carrier Command drops supplies for Bastogne one mile west of the town on 23 December.
C-47 "Ain't Misbehavin'" after crash-landing near Bastogne.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: If the occupants of the small camp at right were present during the successful crash-landing, they certainly received the surprise of their lives. Invasion strips, almost weathered away, adorn the C-47's fuselage.

did.unittitle: Men of the 101st Airborne, many of them wounded, attended Christmas services even as the city is under siege.
Christmas dinner at Bastogne for officers of the 101st Airborne. McAuliffe is seated fourth from the left.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Ned Moore, his acting chief of staff, is seated at the left corner of the table. On the lower right corner sits Joseph Harper. The 101st Fairborn's commander, Maj. Gen. Maxwell Taylor, is not present.

did.unittitle: Airborne troops jump rope to keep warm on Christmas morning.
A most welcome Christmas present falls from a group of nineteen C-47s.
Soldiers, likely from Grenadier-Regiment 77, lie dead on the frozen ground where they fell on Christmas Day.
Oberst Wolfgang Maucke, Kampfgruppe leader, 15. Panzergrenadier-Division.
Bomb damage to Bastogne, 26 December 1944.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: After Christmas, Tech/5 Krochka stayed on the job with his box camera, taking this and the next two photographs.

did.unittitle: In a civilian cemetery the day after Christmas, members of the 101st Airborne Division bury their dead.
Two 101st Airborne members drag a parapack of badly needed medical supplies through the snow near Bastogne.
Two hapless Belgian civilians totter past a burned-out 10th Armored Division half-track near Bastogne on 27 December.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Combined with the frigid, ice-covered terrain, carcasses of destroyed vehicles convey an air of forlorn desolation in the perimeter surrounding Bastogne.

did.unittitle: Maj. Gen. Hugh J. Gaffey (right), commanding general, 4th Armored Division.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This photo was taken after the war on 18 May 1945 in Neustadt, Germany. Major General Cota (left) of the 28th Infantry Division seems unimpressed by Gaffney, who by that time commanded the XXIII Corps. Perhaps he was bored by the mundane discussion that centered on the transfer of local German government functions to local units.

did.unittitle: Map -- The relief of Bastogne, 26 December 1944.
Tanks and vehicles of the 4th Armored Division advance toward Bastogne during the breakthrough.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Men line the ditch at right, keeping watch over the convoys' flank.

did.unittitle: Clad in snowsuits, armored infantrymen cross a broad, snow-covered plain on 27 December, pressing ever closer to the Bastogne garrison.
Clattering past a column of POWs, an M3 half-track from the 4th Armored Division races toward Bastogne.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The M3 mounts a water-cooled .30-caliber Browning machine gun.

did.unittitle: Signal Corps photographer Pfc. D. R. Ornitz takes several well-composed, if grisly, photographs of American dead near Chaumont, Luxembourg, as Bastogne-bound half-tracks of the 4th Armored Division clatter toward their objective.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Though taken from slightly different angles and locations, these photographs together provide a wide-angle view of the road.

did.unittitle: Ornitz crosses the road, looks back, and takes a picture of another American corpse as an M3 rolls toward Bastogne.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The jeep at left center was likely disabled in the Battle of Chaumont, the same action that felled the Americans nearby.

did.unittitle: With Bastogne relieved, vehicles from the 4th Armored Division sit parked in its main square on 28 December.
Lieutenant General Patton chats with Brigadier General McAuliffe after awarding him the Distinguished Service Cross on 28 December.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: To their left is Lt. Col. Steve Chapuis, hero of the battle of Champs east of Bastogne. He, too, would soon receive the Distinguished Service Cross.

did.unittitle: Troops of the 101st Airborne march out of Bastogne on 29 December to do battle with the Germans somewhere on the city's perimeter.
On 30 December, a 4th Armored Division tank retriever prepares to haul out a Sherman tank disabled by German shells outside Bastogne.
Burned-out buildings surround the debris-strewn main square in Bastogne on 30 December.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: American MPs erected a new sign warning against leaving vehicles unattended. Note the disabled M3 half-track at left.

did.unittitle: Bombed-out citizens of Bastogne huddle together in a horse-drawn wagon, which likely also carries most of their possessions.
Guards of the 502d Parachute Infantry Regiment turn back civilians attempting to exit the Bastogne pocket northwest of the city on 30 December.
Tanks and armored infantry of the 6th Armored Division attack German troops north of Bastogne on 31 December.

Alongside members of the 101st Airborne, soldiers of the 777th AAA Battalion, which was attached to the 6th Armored Division, struggle to keep warm beside a fire on the outskirts of Bastogne on 31 December.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An M3 half-track is behind them.

did.unittitle: Combat engineers from the 26th Armored Engineer Battalion, 6th Armored Division, began the task of clearing rubble from Bastogne's debris-choked streets on 1 January.
On New Year's Day, Cpl. Martin Konopka and Pvt. Charles Kelly of the 489th AAA Battalion, 4th Armored, display a wild boar as proof that they could hit their mark, albeit on a ground target.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: But it was the mayor's shotgun that made the kill.

did.unittitle: A Defunct convoy of derelict gasoline trucks litters the roadside on one approach to Bastogne.
Published Images
On 23 December 1944 in Manhay for the first time since the opening of the German offensive, troops of the 3d Armored Division see the contrails of Allied aircraft.
An A-20 Havoc of the 115th Photo Reconnaissance Squadron used flash and flares to take this aerial photo showing a convoy of German vehicles north of Houffalize, Belgium, on the night of 26 December.
Ninth Air Force mechanics work on a P-38 fighter at a base in Belgium.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The two men at right are rigging pipes from a heater to warm up the P-38's right engine.

did.unittitle: Bearing cheery holiday greetings for the führer, bombs await clear weather for delivery in time for Christmas.
P-47 Thunderbolts of the 365th Fighter Group at a Ninth Air Force base in Belgium warm up and await takeoff for missions against German armored columns.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Two aircraft are taking off in the distance.

did.unittitle: One more FW-190 and Luftwaffe pilot would not be available for the final defense of the Fatherland.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Maj. James Dalglish of the 354th Fighter Group scores over the Bulge.

did.unittitle: A German ammunition truck bound for the front explodes in a blinding flash under the guns of Lt. Robert D. Law of Colorado Springs, Colorado.
Lt. Frank W. Chwateck attack four German tanks that attempted to negotiate snow-covered roads at a Belgian crossroads on December.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In the center frame, Chwateck's incendiary .50-caliber bullets have just hit the lead tank.

did.unittitle: A German Brückengerät K replacement bridge sits in the icy waters of a stream near Stavelot, Belgium, after it collapsed under the weight of a Jagdpanzer IV, which lies in the water at the left. While the USAAF made invaluable contributions during the Ardennes Offensive, destroying this German replacement bridge, as claimed in the Signal Corp's caption, is not one of them.
Maj. Gen. Willard S. Paul (right), commanding general, 26th Infantry Division, chats with Lieutenant General Patton (center) and Maj. Gen. Manton Eddy (left) in France on 3 November 1944.
Patton and Maj. Gen. Horace l. McBride, commanding general, 80th Infantry Division, enjoy an animated discussion.

Humbled Grenadiere from the 914. Grenadier-Regiment, 352. Volksgrenadier-Division, line up in front of their captors near Merzig, Luxembourg, on 24 December, after their battle with the U.S. 319th Infantry Regiment, 80th Infantry Division.
The day after Christmas, American soldiers from the 702d Tank Battalion inspect a PzKfpw V Panther heavy tank from the führer-Grenadier-Brigade.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: It was knocked out during heavy fighting at Heiderscheid, Luxembourg. Photographer H. Miller, possibly a German armor enthusiast, took this and the following two photographs.

did.unittitle: Curious Americans in Heiderscheid inspect a Sturmgeschütz IV that was abandoned by the führer-Geranadier-Brigade.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: One man sits atop, one peers down the muzzle, and a third, Lt. L.M. Barrington, peeps into the driver's compartment.

did.unittitle: Another Sturmgeschütz and a wrecked SdKfz 251 half-track stand on the outskirts of Heiderscheid.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The torn body of a Fuhrer-Grenadier lies close by at right.

did.unittitle: POW Emil Gronen likely from the führer-Grenadier-Brigade, receives medical attention from the army nurse Lillian Wilson in the 60th Field Hospital in Heiderscheid.
An 81mm mortar crew the 101st Infantry Regiment, 26th Infantry Division, hurls mortar rounds at German positions near Bavigne, Luxembourg, on New Year's Eve.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Soldiers with ready rounds in hand stand by at right and left, while a private first class at far right communicates with a spotter. The man standing guard at the rear with an M1 carbine illustrates how that lighter weapon was typically used.

did.unittitle: On 1 January infantrymen in snowsuits from the 11th Regiment, 5h Infantry Division, press German positions in the Bulge's southern sector near Haller, Luxembourg.
A 105mm howitzer from the 19th Field Artillery Battalion, 5th Infantry Division, stands ready in a well-dug-in and camouflaged position near Haller.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The smokestack rising through the last camouflage net at left likely provides the barest minimum of creature comforts to the gun crew.

did.unittitle: German casualties of the 212. Volksgrenadier-Division on frozen fields south of Echternach on 26 December.
Advancing over frigid snow-covered hills near Bettange, troops of the 35th Division advance against the 5. Fallschirmjäger-Division and elements of the 15. Panzergrenadier-Division on 28 December.
Maj. Gen. Paul W. Baade, commanding general, 35th Infantry Division.
On 31 December, men from the 345th Infantry Regiment, 87th Infantry Division, in Moircy, southeast of St. Hubert, Belgium.
Maj. Gen. Frank L. Culin, commanding general, 87th Infantry Division.
Humain, Belgium, on 28 December.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A U.S. 76mm antitank gun lies knocked out, a victim in the battle for Humain.

did.unittitle: Three Panthers from Generalmajor von Elverfeld's 9.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Panzer-Division, destroyed by the U.S. 2d Armored Division, rest in silent formation near Humain.

did.unittitle: Pvt. Riley Tillman stands ready to ply his trade of blowing up bridges near Marche, Belgium, in the event of a German breakthrough during 30 December.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Tillman was a member of the 1st Combat Engineer Battalion, assigned to the 84th Infantry Division.

did.unittitle: On 30 December, a camouflaged M10 tank destroyer assigned to the 84th Infantry Division lies in wait for unsuspecting German tanks from the 116. Panzer-Division in Hotton, Belgium.
Knocked out by units of the 75th Division, a Panther from Hitlerjugend sits at the Belgian crossroads of Grandmenil on 30 December.

The battered town of Stavelot in the Amblève River valley as seen from the positions of the 30th Infantry Division and looking east across the river to those of the 18. Volksgrenadier-Division on the bluffs beyond, on 30 December.
Last rites for the victims of German atrocities in Stavelot. Massacre victims would be buried in a common grave on 30 December.
Sturmbannführer Ernest Krag, SS-Aufklärungs-Abteilung 2, 2. SS-Panzer-Division.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His Kampfgruppe led the way to Manhay.

did.unittitle: Maj. Gen. James A. Gavin, commanding general, 82nd Airborne Division.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His division would anchor the American's left flank against Bittrich's attack.

did.unittitle: Sturmbannführer Eberhard Telkamp, SS-Panzer-Regiment 9, 9. SS-Panzer Division.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: His tank would spearhead the attack against the U.S. 82d Airborne Division.

did.unittitle: Waiting for German armor to come clattering down the road, a 3d Armored Division soldier guards the approaches to Manhay with his rocket launcher on 23 December.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: He would have only one day to wait.

did.unittitle: Tanks of the 116. Panzer-Division-PzKpfw IV "611" at left and a Panzer at right -- undergo scrutiny by men of the 3d Armored Division at Hotton on 26 December, three days after turning back a German attack on the town.
A young SS private, probably from Das Reich, undergoes interrogation in Manhay on December, one day before his comrades "liberated" the town, albeit temporarily.
With tousled hair and a head injury, the infantryman casts a troubled, uncertain stare at photographer Lt. S. Noble.
Another SS Grenadier, this one a Sturmmann, seems somewhat indifferent to Noble.
Manhay after the Americans recaptured it, shown on 30 December.
Pvt. Clarence Severtsgaar scans the horizon from the turret of his M36 tank destroyer near Manhay on 27 December.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The photo shows clearly the open-top turret common to all U.S. tank destroyers. Ration boxes are strewn around the dug-in position. From the shadows and the bright sunlight, it is apparent that the tank destroyer has set up on the edge of the woods.

did.unittitle: In a wooded area near the Bastogne corridor in the early day of January 1945, Pvts. John P. MacFarlane and Loyd W. Lockwood of the 35th Infantry Division man a .30-caliber Browning machine gun.
The lonely grave of an anonymous German paratrooper of the 5. Fallschrimjäger-Division lies in the woods east of Bastogne in a sector that the U.S. 30th Division retook.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the paratrooper's helmet, his Mauser rifle, and the crude wooden cross.

did.unittitle: In position with the 11th Armored Division, troops relax after a meal in a barn near Odenville, Belgium.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: One soldier (center) appears to be writing a letter home.

did.unittitle: Taken prisoner by the 50th Armored Infantry Battalion of the 6th Armored Division in Magaret, two young men from the 12. SS-Panzer-Division cast vacuous glances at their captors.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the Grenadier at right has tucked his tunic into trousers held up by a knotted cord in lieu of a belt.

did.unittitle: An American soldier searches members of the 12. SS-Panzer-Division.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Sturmmann (center) wears the Hilterjugend divisional cuff title on his tunic. His SS sleeve eagle has been removed, perhaps by an American souvenir hunter.

did.unittitle: Pvt. Forrest Parker and Sgt. Elmar Hurar indulge in the much-welcomed mindless diversion of the Sunday comics in the 26th Infantry's sector at Goesdorf, four miles south of Wiltz, Luxembourg.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A .30-caliber machine gun is in position behind the two soldiers. In the Dick Tracy panel facing the camera, Tracy rushes into Gravel Gertie's shack in search of "The Brow."

did.unittitle: An M10 tank destroyer of the 712th Tank Battalion, 90th Infantry Division, advances past the snow-covered ruins of Berle, Luxembourg, on 12 January.
On 14 January, graves registration personnel from the 26th Infantry Division collect both American and German dead in the aftermath of fighting near Wiltz, Luxembourg.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the chains on the rear tires of the jeep.

did.unittitle: An aerial view of Wiltz on 22 January after its recapture by the 26th Infantry Division and the 6th Cavalry Group.
German graves in Wiltz on 22 January.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A victim's helmet rests atop one of the crosses.

did.unittitle: Americans detain a captured German medic.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Clad in a red-cross, he carries his supplies in two U.S. field glass cases.

did.unittitle: Two German Opel trucks are upended along a roadside near Marbourg, Luxembourg on 31 January.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The second truck is at left, back in the fog. Note the first truck's Wehrmacht-Heer license plate, identifiable by its "WH-" prefix.

did.unittitle: Pvt. Joseph Klem of the 357th Infantry Regiment, 90th Infantry Division, prepares to munch on his noonday ration at Binsfeld, Luxembourg.
On 6 February, Signal Corps photographer Tech/4 Aaron Lubitsch pauses alongside a building bearing a German slogan in Troisvierges, Luxembourg, about eight miles due east of Houffalize Belgium.
In Clervaux, Luxembourg, a brand-new Panther tank sits intact, out of gas, and with turret hatch open.
A thaw during the first week of February inundates a German military cemetery at Clervaux.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Many of the crosses have fallen askew in the soft, wet earth.

did.unittitle: A Sherman tank of the 2d Armored Division passes a snow-covered PzKpfw V Panther in a roadside ditch near Grandmenil, Belgium.
German army POWs line up with Soldbücher in hand after the 82d Airborne Division captured them near Basse-Bodeux, Belgium on 3 January, just as the U.S. counter-offensive got under way.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The soldier in the front of the line wears an Army decal on his helmet.

did.unittitle: This young infantryman, another prisoner captured by the 82d Airborne near Fosse on 4 January, wears a snowsuit with a waist belt and 7.92mm ammunition pouches.

Sherman tanks from the 3d Armored Division pause in their advance along the northern edge of the Bulge in the Manhay-Houffalize sector near Baraque de Fraiture on 7 January and wait for a German tank to be cleared from the road ahead.
Maj. Gen. Maurice Rose, in command of the 3d Armored Division.
Brig. Gen. Cliff Andrus, commanding general, 1st Infantry Division.

Captured by 1st Division soldiers during the fighting near Steinbach, a Luftwaffe Obergefreiter from the 3. Fallschirmjäger-Division glares at Signal Corps photographer Sgt. Bill Augustine in Weywertz, Belgium on 15 January.
Another Obergefreiter is far less appreciative of Augustine's photographic efforts, shielding his face from the camera.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An Unteroffizier stands in the background at right.

did.unittitle: An SS private surrenders to the 3d Armored Division.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Grenadier wears a familiar complement of uniform parts -- service tunic, camouflage smock, and greatcoat.

did.unittitle: Foy, Belgium, just after the arrival of the elements 506th Parachute Infantry, 101st Airborne, on 16 January.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Horses have strayed into the road at right. An ambulance from the medical unit is parked beside the horses' water trough at left.

did.unittitle: Four miles east of Malmédy near Faymonville on 16 January, a T1E1 mine exploder works to clear the road of mines, while an M3 half-track gingerly follows close behind.
Army photographer Garrell approaches the town of Houffalize, Belgium, from the west on January.
Garrell rides down the main road into shell-torn Houffalize.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The sign board warns advancing soldiers that the road ahead is unmarked.

did.unittitle: Racing over snow-covered roads, tanks of the 7th Armored Division push on toward St. Vith.

Air liaison officers of the Ninth Air Force -- (left to right) Maj. Albert Triers, Maj. William Abbot Jr., and 1st Lt. Richard Zinkowski -- inspect a PzKpfw V, one of many tanks and other vehicles that the IX Tactical Air Command and the advancing 7th Armored Division had destroyed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Panther seems to be parked in front of Hôtel des Ardennes, as if would-be German guests had stopped to check in.

did.unittitle: Soldiers of the 7th Armored Division guard three German officers captured on the way into St. Vith.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The officers at left are rather neatly attired and relatively well turned out, while the man at right appears somewhat disheveled, wearing a crumpled, dirty snowsuit.

did.unittitle: Snowsuit-clad members of a rifle squad (possibly assigned to the Sherman tank in the background) from the 7th Armored Division warily observe the windows above them in the debris-strewn streets of St. Vith on 23 January.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The wall at left appears ready to topple onto the men below.

did.unittitle: Advancing through heavy snow and incoming German shellfire, infantrymen of the 75th Division move forward near St. Vith on 23 January.
On 27 January, American troops pass a PzKpfw IV-chassised Flakpanzer Wirbelwind that was abandoned Kampfgruppe Peiper near Buchholtz during the first days of the offensive.
Men of the 325th Glider Infantry, 82d Airborne Division, commit themselves to the final advances on Herresbach on 28 January, the date of the village's liberation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The men drag a heavily laden ammunition sled through the snow. While some have on snowsuits, others do not.

did.unittitle: A Sherman tank of the 740th Tank Battalion, attached to the 82d Airborne only the week before, crunches through heavy snow near Herresbach.
Soldiers trudge one behind the other in boot-deep snow just prior to the fall of Herresbach on 29 January.
Snow drifts over the pews and floor of a shattered church in Krinkelt, Belgium, on 1 February, retaken earlier by the 2d Infantry Division.
On 3 January, machine gunners of the 10th Infantry, 4th Armored Division, cover an advancing tank in the Bastogne corridor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the photographer's shadow at right, cast by the early morning light.

did.unittitle: An ambulance of the 501st Medical Battalion, 101st Airborne Division, lies wrecked near the outskirts of Bastogne, another victim of a German artillery shell about 9 January.
Aerial photo of the village of Bizory, northeast of Bastogne, as the U.S. 6th Armored Division advances.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the telltale tank tracks in the snow.

did.unittitle: Maj. Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor turns over control of Bastogne to VIII Corps commander Major General Middleton on 18 January.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An MP sergeant with a camera stands at left.

did.unittitle: Major General Taylor, commanding general, 101st Airborne Division.
Maxwell Taylor's receipt for Bastogne -- battered but serviceable and "disinfected."
Upended vehicles of Team Cherry, wrecked during the siege of Bastogne, have been pushed into a ditch on the road to Longvilly northeast of the city.
Supply convoy of the 90th Infantry Division rolls through the streets of Bastogne on 22 January.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This picture, taken by Sgt. C. F. Anders, is perhaps the photograph most frequently associated with Bastogne and the Battle of the Bulge.

did.unittitle: A soldier suffering compound fractures in both legs from gunshot and shrapnel wounds awaits the attention of surgeons in the 111th Evacuation Hospital in Luxembourg.
Army medical personnel of the 51st Field Hospital operate in primitive conditions near Aisne, Belgium.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: They are (left to right) Tech/4 James Polite, Lt. Helen Johnson, and Capt. I.R. Hayman. Gas bottles and anesthesia equipment sit in the foreground.

did.unittitle: Battle casualties from the Bulge crowd a post-operative tent near Aisne.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The pyramidal tent offers shelter to patients from whom quarters are not yet available.

did.unittitle: At a medical clearing station near Ettelbruck, Luxembourg, a Catholic chaplain from the 5th Infantry Division -- Maj. Harold O. Prudell -- administers last rites on 29 January to a soldier who was seriously wounded along the Bulge's southern shoulder.
In a POW stockade near Passau, Germany, on 7 May 1945, battered German soldiers stand in line after being identified as suspects in the Baugnez massacre.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: None of the men here, however, match photos of any defendants in the Malmédy trial. Their presence in Kampfgruppe Peiper would be surprising in any case, as most seem to be decidedly middle-ages.

did.unittitle: The flag-draped Malmédy Massacre Memorial at Baugnez, Belgium -- seen here on 27 July 1945 -- was a temporary structure, molded out of concrete.

On 9 April 1946, six of the massacre's survivors gather in front of the concrete monument (left to right): Virgil R. Lary, Kenneth Ahrens, Homer D. Ford, Carl R. Daub, Kenneth E. Kingston, and Samuel Dobyns.
The cover of the book containing the charges and evidence for the Malmédy trial.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the typed list of defendants immediately above.

did.unittitle: The building at Dachau where the General Military Government Court convened on 16 July, the day sentences for seventy-three of the defendants were announced.
The trial's antagonists -- Col. Willis M. Everett Jr., chief defense counsel, and Lt. Col. Burton F. Ellis, trial judge advocate -- in animated conversation during a court recess on 26 June 1946.
Former 6. Panzer-Armee commander Josef Dietrich, the highest-ranking defendant, stands to receive his number -- 11.
Romanian-born Volksdeutscher ex-Sturmmann Georg Fleps receives number 14 from the court.
First Lieutenant Lary declares, "This is the man (Fleps) that fired the first two pistol shots into the American prisoner of war."

Ex-Sturmmann Hans-Erick Lichtwarck of 2./SS-Panzer-Regiment 1 testifies for the prosecution and submits to cross-examination by Dr. Hans Hertkorn (standing) of the defense counsel on 21 May. To the left of Hertkorn is Hans Siptrott (number 60), Georg Fleps's tank commander.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Immediately behind the woman seated at the left end of the defense counsel's table is Joachim Peiper, wearing a pair of sunglasses.

did.unittitle: On 27 May, 1st Lt. William R. Perl -- war crimes and Malmédy investigator, who interrogated many of the accused -- answers questions posed by Lieutenant Colonel Ellis (left), trial judge advocate.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A translator sits at center.

did.unittitle: Kurt Framm, ex-Untersturmführer and adjutant an Werner Pötschke's staff offers testimony on 27 May on behalf of the prosecution.

Ex. Pfc. Samuel Dobyns, former ambulance drivers for the 575th Ambulance Company, 99th Infantry Division, points out the crossroads at Baugnez where he witnessed the massacre of members of the 285th Field Artillery Observation Battalion.

At the behest of the defense, Dobyns scans the seventy-four defendants to find the man who saved him from being shot at Baugnez, Defendant number 1 and the trial's official namesake, Valentin Bersin, sits on the first row of defendants.
Capt. Rafael Schumacker of the prosecution team show ex-Sgt. Kenneth Ahrens an overlay map of the massacre site.
Ahrens demonstrates how he surrendered to elements of Kampfgruppe Peiper.
Homer D. Ford, an ex-MP who was on duty at Baugnez at the time of the massacre, relates his story to the court.
Called to testify for the defense, Gerhardt Engel -- former commanding general of the 12. Volksgrenadier-Division during the Ardennes Offensive-testifies on 19 June.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note that while the SS prisoners were not permitted to wear any insignia, Engel's tunic still retains its red general officer collar tabs and epaulets.

did.unittitle: An emaciated Hermann Priess, former commander of the I. SS-Panzerkorps, takes the stand and undergoes cross-examination by Morris Elowitz, the U.S. civilian assistant trial judge advocate.
The star of the Malmédy trial, ex-Obersturmbannführer Joachim Peiper takes his seat on the witness stand on 21 June.
Defendants on the officers' end of the dock listen to Dr. Otto Leiling (German defense counsel) translate Colonel Everett's concluding appeal for the defense.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Front row, left to right: Dietrich (hidden by Leiling), Krämer, Priess, Peiper, and Friedrich Christ (number 7). Other Kampfgruppe company commanders are (second row immediately above Peiper) Vernoni Junker (number 29), commander of 6./SS-Panzer-Regiment 1, (third row) Erich Rumpf (number 54), commander of 9. Pionier-Kompanie, and (top row, directly above Krämer) Heinz Tomhardt (number 67), commander of 11./SS-Panzer-Regiment 1.

did.unittitle: Following a recess on June wives of defendants Dietrich and Peiper return to the courtroom to hear the court's verdict.
Dietrich and Krämer sit prepared to take notes during the final court session prior to sentencing on 16 July.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contemplating his fate on the third row, Gustav Knittel stares at Signal Corps photographer Pfc. Harry Bergmann. Note that Dietrich and Krämer have almost no shoelaces, most likely an anti-suicide measure.

did.unittitle: Spectators at the court in Dachau await the sentencing that would conclude the trial.
While Colonel Everett looks on at right, Priess receives a sentence of twenty years.
Oswald Siegmund (number 58) leaves the courtroom at Dachau after being sentenced to death by hanging. National Archives 111-SC-249319
The last three defendants -- (left to right) Paul Zwigart, Otto Wickmann, and Erich Werner -- await their respective sentences of death, ten years and life imprisonment.
Signal Corps photographer Genot visits Bastogne on 2 April 1950 and takes a photo (undoubtedly with a deliberate comparison in mind) from the same vantage point as photo 8-47.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Five intervening years appear to have erased most of the war's damage.

did.unittitle: In July 1950, the people of Belgium dedicated the Bastogne Memorial to the memory of all American troops killed in the Battle of the Bulge.
Maj. Gen. Anthony McAuliffe delivers a speech to the people of Bastogne, July 1950.
McAuliffe places a wreath of flowers commemorating "Bastogne Day" in 1955.
On 14 June 1954, Belgian Lt. Henri LaFaut examines the turret of a Sherman tank mounted in a pedestal near Bastogne.
The American Military Cemetery and Memorial at Ardennes, Belgium, dedicated on 11 July 1960.
The American eagle watches over the fallen. 111-SC-578277
American defenders of Belgium at peace. 111-SC-578274
Extras
Photocopied

unittitle.title: Rain of Ruin: A Photographic History of Hiroshima and Nagasaki

did.unittitle: Published Images
The mushroom cloud continues its climb toward the stratosphere. See 5-24
(clockwise from) Fat Boy 5-4, Nagasaki 5-91, injured woman 8-6, the Enola Gay 3-12.
Dr. Albert Einstein.
President Franklin D. Roosevelt (center), with Stalin (left) and Churchill (right) at the Yalta Conference during early February 1945.
Dr. Vannevar Bush.
Dr. John B. Conant, president of Harvard University.
Dr. Karl Compton (third from left) at the first meeting of the War Resources Board on August 17, 1939.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Other members are, seated (l-r): Dr. Harold S. Moulton, acting secretary of the Navy; Charles Edison; board chairman Edward R. Stettinius; and Assistant Secretary of the Navy Louis Johnson. Standing: Commander Anton B. Anderson, USN; Admiral Harold R. Stark, USN; Compton; John L. Pratt; General George C. Marshall, USA; and Colonel Harry K. Rutherford, USA.

did.unittitle: Dr. Arthur Compton.
Dr. Ernest O. Lawrence (left), Dr. Enrico (center), and Isidor I. Rabi.
Henry L. Stimson, secretary of war, was directly responsible to the president for the entire atomic bomb undertaking.
Major General Leslie R. Groves, in executive charge of the Manhattan Project.
Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer.
The rear entrance to the Alamogordo, New Mexico, test site during July 1945. Note watchtower at left.
A lonely MP stands watch in one of the watchtowers at the test site.
Main camp at Alamogordo.
Oak Ridge, Tennessee, seen from the "Oliver Spring" Gate

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An anonymous observer said of this entrance to the facility: "The first view the visitor has of Oak Ridge itself … (is) not very impressive, but that's the way it was."

did.unittitle: Shoulder patch worn by personnel of the Manhattan Engineering District.
The Hanford, Washington, facility.
President Harry S Truman speaks at the White House on April 17, 1945, five days following the death of President Roosevelt.
The University of Chicago's Physics Building.
The Argonne Laboratory, a research facility near Chicago for the Metallurgical Project.
The University of Chicago's New Chemistry Building, a part of the Metallurgical Laboratory.
Scientific Group at the University of Chicago.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Front (left to right): Enrico Fermi, Walter Zinn, Albert Wattenberg, Herbert Anderson. Center: Harold Agnes, William Sturm, Harold Lictenberger, Leona Marshall, Leo Szilard. Back: Norman Hilberry, Samuel Allison, Thomas Brill, Robert Nobles, Warren Nyer, Marvin Wilkening. [Goldstein 40]

did.unittitle: Wendover Field in 1941

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Tibbets selected this site in Utah as the training base for the 509th Composite Group. Before its assignment to the 509th, the 393rd Bombardment Squadron trained at Fairmont Field, Nebraska.

did.unittitle: Colonel Paul W. Tibbets, Jr., commanding officer, 509th Composite Group, upon his promotion to full colonel. Note the cardboard eagles on his shoulders.
Two Boeing B-29s on Saipan stand poised for takeoff on the first Tokyo raid of the bombing offensive against Japan, November 24, 1944.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the tail-gun position of the aircraft at right.

did.unittitle: Major General Uzal Ent, Second Air Force.
Captain William S. Parsons, senior weaponeer, on loan to the 509th Composite Group from the U.S. Navy.
General Henry H. (Hap) Arnold, commander of the U.S. Army Air Forces, chats with Major General Louis E. Woods, USMC, commander of the Nineteenth Army Tactical Air Force on Okinawa during 1945.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This organization had both Army and Marine aircraft. Arnold was responsible for B-29 modification, ballistic tests, and organization and training of the field unit selected to deliver the bomb.

did.unittitle: 509th Composite Group Organization

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Not a photograph; a list.

did.unittitle: Major Thomas W. Ferebee, the group's lead bombardier under Colonel Tibbets.
Major Charles W. Sweeney, commanding officer, 393rd Bombardment Squadron.
Eglin Field, Florida, shown here on April 4, 1942.
The operations building and aircraft parking area at Batista Airport on December 26, 1943, located about ten miles south-southwest of Havana.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the tile roof of the operations building in the foreground. In the parking area beyond lie a C-47 and two B-25s, likely G and C versions.

did.unittitle: B-29s parked on the hardstand at North Field on the island of Tinian in 1945.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The field was developed on the location of the former Japanese Ushi Point airfield. The Americans used the beaches in the foreground in the invasion of the island.

did.unittitle: Ralph A. Bard (right) chats with Fleet Admiral Chester W. Nimitz during the U.S. Naval Academy's centennial ceremonies in the second week of October 1945.

James F. Byrnes (third from left) attends a meeting in 1945 with (l-r) Navy joint Chief Fleet Admiral William D. Leahy, former Chief of Naval Operations Admiral Harold R. Stark, Ambassador to Belgium Sawyer, President Harry S Truman, General Dwight D. Eisenhower, and naval aide to the president Captain James K. Vardaman, Jr.

General George C. Marshall (left center) chats with Lord Halifax, Admiral Ernest J. King, and Bernard M. Baruch during the Navy Day Dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, New York City, on October 27, 1944.
Fleet Admiral William D. Leahy, a great skeptic concerning the atom bomb project.
The Manhattan Project's deputy director, Brigadier General Thomas F. Farrell, in his office on Tinian in 1945.
Tent quarters at North Field, March 28, 1945.
Quonset huts near North Field on Tinian. Similar buildings found use as offices and briefing rooms.
Colonel Elmer E. Kilpatrick, Twentieth Air Force engineer, who expedited construction at Tinian.
Iwo Jima, May 26, 1945, looking toward Mount Suribachi. Note the B-29s parked on the airfield.
Aircraft from USS White Plains (CVE-66) sink a Japanese transport off Rota in the Marianas on June 24, 1944.
Aerial reconnaissance photo of Truk taken by a PB4T-1 patrol bomber on February 4, 1944.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Eten Island airfield lies at the center, with a multitude of warships and merchantmen anchored in the vicinity.

did.unittitle: Aircraft Commanders, 509th Composite; list
Major General Curtis E. LeMay, deputy commander, Twentieth Air Force.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: He took over as General Spaatz's chief of staff on August 1, 1945.

did.unittitle: Former ambassador to Japan Joseph C. Grew conducts a press conference at Pearl Harbor on November 16, 1944.
Firebomb damage to a residential and commercial section of Tokyo.
Destruction in downtown Tokyo of the older wood structure is total; only concrete masonry buildings survive.
Further devastation in Tokyo as a result of incendiary bombing raids.
President Truman debarks from USS Augusta (CA-31) at Antwerp, Belgium, en route to the Potsdam Conference, July 15, 1945, followed by Secretary of State James F. Byrnes.
Control house and observation post at Almogordo.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The test bomb, transported via the roadway at right, would be detonated from this point. Note the shadow of the aircraft carrying the Signal Corps Photographer who took this picture.

did.unittitle: Five-thirty A.M., July 16, 1945. Success – explosion of the test device at Alamogordo.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Unless there should be some last-minute capitulation by the Japanese, the mushroom cloud rendered moot further discussions of war options. [111-SC-217504]

did.unittitle: Crater and scorch marks left behind by the world's first nuclear detonation. Note the road at left, which terminates at ground zero.
H.I.M. Hirohito, Emperor of Japan.
Combat crews of the 393rd Bombardment Squadron during a target-study class on August 1, 1945.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In the front-row seats are (l-r) Captain Norman W. Ray; Second Lieutenant John E. Cantlon; Captain Frederick C. Bock, Jr.; and Second Lieutenant Paul W. Gruning.

did.unittitle: The men have shifted their seating somewhat.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Identified officers are (l-r) Major Ralph R. Taylor, Jr.; Lieutenant Cantlon; Major John A. Wilson; Lieutenant Gruning; First Lieutenant Michael Angelich (behind Gruning's knee), Second Lieutenant Jacob Y. Bontekoe, and First Lieutenant Williamson (scribbling in his notepad).

did.unittitle: Captain Joseph D. Buscher, from group headquarters, continues his lecture while the photographer moves to the back of the Quonset hut.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Lieutenant Gruning is relaxed, his leg slung onto the table at right.

did.unittitle: Lieutenant Charles Levy takes over to discuss a different target.
General Carl A. (Tooey) Spaatz, the field commander responsible for delivery of the atomic bomb.
Letter from General Thomas T. Handy to Spaatz, authorizing use of the atomic bombs then on Tinian.
Lieutenant General Nathan F. Twining, commanding general, Twentieth Air Force.
The "Big Three" at Potsdam

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: (l-r): Prime Minister Clement Attlee; President Harry S Truman; and Premier Joseph Stalin. China signed the Potsdam Declaration; the U.S.S.R. did not.

did.unittitle: Shigenori Togo, Japan's foreign minister.
General Korechika Anami, minister of war.
General Yoshijiro Umezu, army chief of staff.
Admiral Baron Kantaro Suzuki, prime minister of Japan.

With mind made up, if not completely at ease, in the wake of Japan's rejection of the Potsdam Declaration, President Truman works in his wardroom on board Augusta during the return trip to the United States.
USS Indianapolis (CA-35) off Mare Island Navy Yard on July 10, 1945.
Captain Charles F. H. Begg, whose 1st Ordnance Squadron, Special (Aviation) acted as custodian of the bombs and their components on Tinian.
Last known photograph of Indianapolis.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Taken as she prepared to depart Tinian after delivering atomic bomb components.

did.unittitle: Track of Indianapolis on the voyage to Leyte that ended in her sinking.
Former lieutenant commander Mochitsura Hashimoto, commander of kaiten submarine I-58, examines a navigation chart at the court-martial of Captain McVay.
Japanese submarine I-58 at Sasebo after the war, January 28, 1946.
Forward torpedo room of I-58.
USS Ringness (APD-100).
Indianapolis survivors en route to a hospital (probably on Guam) in early August 1945.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The ambulance in the background is marked "U.S.N. Base Hospital Nº 20."

did.unittitle: Following his voyage to Guam on board high-speed transport Ringness, Captain McVay recounts the sinking of Indianapolis to war correspondents in August 1945.
Manhattan Project and mission leaders meet on Tinian in August 1945

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: (l-r): Rear Admiral William R. Purnell, technical adviser; Brigadier General Thomas F. Farrell, deputy director of the Manhattan Project; Colonel Paul W. Tibbets, Jr., commanding officer, 509th Composite Group; Captain William S. Parsons, USN, weaponeer on the Hiroshima mission.

did.unittitle: Crew of group commander Tibbets.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Standing (l-r): Second Lieutenant Morris Jeppson; Captain Robert A. Lewis; Brigadier General John H. Davies (commanding general, 313th Bombardment Wing); Colonel Tibbets; Major Thomas W. Ferebee; Captain Parsons. Kneeling (l-r): Staff Sergeant Wyatt E. Duzenbury; Sergeant Joseph A. Stiborik; Captain Theodore J. Van Kirk; Staff Sergeant George R. Caron; Sergeant Robert R. Shumard; Private First Class Richard H. Nelson. Not pictured is First Lieutenant Jacob Beser, radar countermeasures officer.

did.unittitle: Crew Members for Hiroshima Mission – August 6, 1945; list.
New York Times correspondent William L. Laurence stands by the group public relations officer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Laurence would ride in The Great Artiste on the mission to Nagasaki. He would become a Pulitzer Prize winner.

did.unittitle: An unidentified officer chats with Ferebee, Tibbets, and Van Kirk.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: All seem in good spirits except for Bombardier Ferebee, who appears rather somber – perhaps because of the pressure and responsibility of personally delivering the bomb.

did.unittitle: Bathed in the glare of klieg lights, Colonel Tibbets's crew poses with Major John W. Porter (ground operations officer and commanding officer of the 390th Air Service Group) before boarding Enola Gay early in the morning of August 6.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Those present are, standing (l-r): Major Porter, Captain Van Kirk, Major Ferebee, Colonel Tibbets, Captain Lewis, and First Lieutenant Jacob Beser, in charge of radar countermeasures. Kneeling (l-r): Sergeant Stiborik, Staff Sergeant Caron, Private First Class Nelson, Sergeant Shumard, Staff Sergeant Duzenbury.

did.unittitle: Perhaps pausing in his bomb-bay activities with Captain Parsons, Lieutenant Jeppson smiles for the cameraman and posterity before bombing.
The Hiroshima bomb, Little Boy, being placed in the bomb bay of Enola Gay at North Field on Tinian, August 5, 1945.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Present (l-r) are Rear Admiral Purnell, Brigadier General Farrell, and Captain Parsons. At center, with hands on hips, is Dr. Norman Ramsey of the Los Alamos Technical Group.

did.unittitle: Corporal Robert Behr assists with the takeoff broadcast.
Tibbets waves from the cockpit of Enola Gay just prior to takeoff.
Enola Gay prepares to taxi onto the runway at North Field, Tinian.[Maxwell 31]
Enola Gay prepares to taxi onto the runway at North Field, Tinian. [Maxwell 32]
The Targets; map.
Hiroshima stretches out like the fingers of a giant hand in this prestrike mosaic of reconnaissance photographs.
This map displays various features marking Hiroshima as a legitimate military target.
During the Sino-Japanese War, Emperor Meiji made his headquarters in this building.
Ujima Harbor, developed as a port for Hiroshima, was a major point of embarkation for the Japanese Army.
View looking northeast down Tera-machi, the Street of Temples.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The road here was considerably wider than in most of the residential areas. No buildings in this area survived.

did.unittitle: Aerial view of the very densely built-up area of the city on the Motoyasu River looking upstream.

An early photograph looking upstream on the Motoyasu River toward what would become the most famous of all Hiroshima landmarks – the domed City Commercial Display Building, immediately adjacent to ground zero.
An older photo looking north from the vicinity of the T-Bridge.
Radio station JOFK. This main building housed studios, offices, and transmitters.
View looking east into Hiroshima's shopping district.
The living room in an upper-middle-class Hiroshima house.
Another living room, showing straw mats (tatami) and low table (dai).
A Hiroshima kitchen, which its owner described as modern.
This view of a house under construction shows workers mixing straw into the plaster for this house's exterior walls. Note the split-bamboo lathing.
The plaster-and-bamboo lathing typical of exterior walls in Japanese domestic architecture.
A hand-drawn water pumper.
Another smaller pumper.
Two young females firefighters demonstrate movement of their equipment.
This annotated aerial photograph, taken August 8, 1945, shows Major Ferebee's aiming point and various landmarks within the city.
Little Boy, the Hiroshima bomb that Major Ferebee toggled out of Enola Gay at 8:15 A.M. Hiroshima time on August 6, 1945.
Map of Hiroshima, showing ground zero and the city's geographical features.
Far end of the T-bridge.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The buckled brickwork and misaligned trolley tracks attest that the structure was moved over approximately one foot to the right.

did.unittitle: A fiery cloud boils skyward from Hiroshima at about 8:18
Ten to twenty minutes after the detonation, a mushroom cloud stands over Hiroshima, leveled out at about 60,000 feet by the stratosphere inversion.
The last halting steps of an unknown Hiroshima inhabitant.
This young soldier's face was burned when he looked toward the explosion: his cap protected the top of his head.
Tattered clothing recovered from bomb victims after the explosion [253-HP-731567-38]
Tattered clothing recovered from bomb victims after the explosion [253-HP-731567-39]
Hiroshima; map.
Looking toward the city center from directly over ground zero.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the absence of rubble above ground level, the wooden structures having been reduced to ashes.

did.unittitle: Ground zero at Hiroshima (indicted by the arrow), looking east.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Only reinforced-concrete buildings remain and all have sustained significant structural damage. The T-bridge and the City Commercial Display Building, both ground zero landmarks, are visible in the upper portion.

did.unittitle: Near ground zero, masonry or brick structures failed to stand up to the blast.
The searing heat of the explosion manifested itself even inside buildings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Here, a window's outline is scotched onto three chairs.

did.unittitle: This view of Hiroshima reveals the extent of damage.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note until 11/4 miles from ground zero are structures standing without apparent damage, even seen from this relatively high altitude.

did.unittitle: An example of the ghosting phenomenon.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Lattice at a gas storage tank produced the effect seen here.

did.unittitle: The shadow of a ladder seared into the same gas storage tank bears witness to the intensity of the heat and radiation from the bomb explosion.
The image produced by a valve and hand wheel documents the precise direction of the radiation/heat source.
Ghostly outlines of guard rails on one Hiroshima's many bridges.
Human beings vaporized by the intense heat left ghostly traces of their last moments.
Chart – The most dreaded symbol of the twentieth century.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The development of a mushroom cloud, as analyzed by the U.S. Strategic Bombing Survey.

did.unittitle: Enola Gay returns to Tinian on August 6.
An excited crowd of 509th Composite Group personnel huddles close to Enola Gay.
General Spaatz greets Colonel Tibbets and awards him the Distinguished Services Cross.
Spaatz returns Tibbets's salute, as Brigadier General John H. Davies, commander of the 313th Bombardment Wing, looks on.
Immediately following the decoration ceremony on the hardstand, Tibbets's men were debriefed by a stellar assembly.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Including (l-r): Rear Admiral Purnell, General Spaatz, Lieutenant General Barney M. Giles (Spaatz' deputy commander), and Lieutenant General Twining, shown here waiting for the debriefing to commence.

did.unittitle: An unidentified officer questions Tibbets's navigator, Captain Van Kirk.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Others seated at the table (clockwise from Van Kirk) are: Colonel Tibbets, Rear Admiral Purnell, Lieutenant General Twining, Lieutenant General Giles, General Spaatz, Captain Parsons, Lieutenant Beser, Major Ferebee, and Brooklyn Dodger fan Staff Sergeant Caron. Brigadier General Davies looks on from behind and to the right of General Giles. [Maxwell 29]

did.unittitle: A large assemblage of 509th personnel attended the ceremony held on August 9 to honor Tibbets's men.
Members of Tibbets's crew were decorated by Brigadier General Davies.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Present at the ceremony are (l-r): Colonel Tibbets, Captain Parsons, Brigadier General Davies, Captain Lewis (face hidden), Lieutenant Beser, Lieutenant Jeppson, Staff Sergeant Duzenbury, Staff Sergeant Caron, Sergeant Stiborik, Sergeant Shumard, Private First Class Nelson.

did.unittitle: Boeing F-13 reconnaissance aircraft, which was a B-29 modified to carry photographic equipment.
Japanese army barracks 4,200 feet north of ground zero, close by the old castle complex.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Partly because of the blast pressure from the outside, and partly because of debris from collapsed roofs and floors, masonry and brickwork were blasted into the interiors of structures, rather than flying outward in the pattern associated with hits sustained during conventional bombing.

did.unittitle: Hiroshima's war industries located away from the city center naturally suffered less, but still sustained considerable damage such as that seen in the munitions plant here.
Hiroshima railroad station.
Ruins of the Imperial Castle and army headquarters compound at center, half a mile from ground zero, looking southwest.
Imperial Castle and army headquarters compound. This photo is undated.
Looking west past the castle compound.
Captain Mitsuo Fuchida, air operations officer of the Japanese navy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: As a commander, he had led the air attack on Pearl Harbor.

did.unittitle: Marquis Koichi Kido, Lord Keeper of the Privy Seal.
Dr. Yoshio Nishina, Japanese authority on atomic energy.
Hiroshima from high altitude, August 7, 1945, exhibits few details, except for its roadnet.
Photograph offered as a comparison in the Strategic Bombing Survey study of Hiroshima, after the bomb explosion, showing the City Commercial Display Building. [243-HP-731568-72]
Five overlapping photographs provide a stark, wide-angle view of Hiroshima from the vicinity of ground zero (indicated by the arrow).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The City Commerce Display Building is at center. At right is the T-Bridge, near the divergence of the Matoyan and Ota rivers. [3A-03450, 3A-03454, 3A-03452, 3A-03443, 3A-03442]

did.unittitle: Ground zero at Hiroshima (indicated by the arrow), looking south.
View of the island straddled by the Tenma and Fukushima rivers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The tip of the island is at lower right.

did.unittitle: Looking south toward the ground zero area from a point 3/4 mile farther north.
View looking west across the breadth of the city, half a mile from ground zero.
View of the ruined city from atop the Red Cross building, one-half mile from ground zero. [3A-3439]
View of the ruined city from atop the Red Cross building, one-half mile from ground zero.
Although many of Hiroshima's bridges survived the explosion, some lighter ones did not.
Modern structures within half a mile of ground zero suffered severe damage, most often in the form of walls buckled away from the direction of the explosion.
Hiroshima Gas Company, 800 feet south of ground zero.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This structure also appears along the far left edge of 4-50. The City Commercial Display Building stands at far right in the fist photo of the pair. [3A-3446]

did.unittitle: Hiroshima Gas Company, 800 feet south of ground zero.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This structure also appears along the far left edge of 4-50. The City Commercial Display Building stands at far right in the fist photo of the pair. [3A-3444]

did.unittitle: Koa Fire Insurance Company, 1,300 feet from ground zero.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Brick buildings did not fare as well as those of concrete and steel.

did.unittitle: Chugokyu Electric Company's Minami substation, before the bombing, 1,500 feet from ground zero. [243-H-955] [243-HP-731568-299]
Chugokyu Electric Company's Minami substation, after the bombing, 1,500 feet from ground zero. [3A-03460]
Shimomuna Watch Shop, a steel-frame building 2,000 feet from ground zero.
Hiroshima Telephone Company, 2,500 feet from ground zero.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Here, the switch and relay rack room lies destroyed. This picture was taken on October 28, 1945.

did.unittitle: Hiroshima's forlorn city hall stands empty, gutted by fire some 3,000 feet from the hypocenter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This photo was taken on November 1, 1945.

did.unittitle: At a branch of the Hiroshima Fire Department, the city's only hook-and-ladder truck lies charred alongside two other vehicles, 4,000 feet from ground zero.
The earth-and-log air-raid shelter at center survived the blast intact 5,000 feet northeast of ground zero, although other buildings did not.
Farther south, looking northwest. Hiroshima Red Cross Hospital lies at center near the river, about one mile from ground zero.
Beyond 1 1/2 miles from ground zero, some wooden buildings, such as this one 7,600 feet away, survived badly buckled and knocked about.
At the Misawa Credit Association Warehouse, the walls stand but the ceiling and the entire second floor have been pushed down to ground level.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Where the ceilings have held, they appear as if battered by a demolition ball. [3A-03464]

did.unittitle: At the Misawa Credit Association Warehouse, the walls stand but the ceiling and the entire second floor have been pushed down to ground level.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Where the ceilings have held, they appear as if battered by a demolition ball. [3A-03463]

did.unittitle: At the Misawa Credit Association Warehouse, the walls stand but the ceiling and the entire second floor have been pushed down to ground level.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Where the ceilings have held, they appear as if battered by a demolition ball. [243-H-174] [243-HP-731567-384]

did.unittitle: The blast carried away portions of the Chugokyu Power Company's downspouts.
A reinforced concrete smokestack lies on its side.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the power pole in the distance leaning in the opposite direction.

did.unittitle: Near the Commercial Display Buildings, trees still stand at right with branches charred, but intact.
The rubble-strewn courtyard of the Commercial Display Building.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Unfortunately, the text on the board bound to the concrete post at lower right is illegible.

did.unittitle: The annex adjacent to the Commercial Display Building.
A Hiroshima street. Note the drainpipe, which the vacuum created by the atomic blast has pulled up through the pavement.
A cemetery in disarray, possibly the army burial grounds about 1 1/2 miles from ground zero.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The only legible stone, that of army captain Akira Sasaki, is at lower right.

did.unittitle: Christianity was (and remains) very much a minority religion in Japan. Ruins of churches in Japan seem to have been of particular interest to Americans.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This particular church caught the eyes of at least three different photographers – one each from the U.S. Army Air Forces, the U.S. Strategic Bombing Survey (USSBS), and the U.S Navy. [3A-3363]

did.unittitle: Christianity was (and remains) very much a minority religion in Japan. Ruins of churches in Japan seem to have been of particular interest to Americans.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This particular church caught the eyes of at least three different photographers – one each from the U.S. Army Air Forces, the U.S. Strategic Bombing Survey (USSBS), and the U.S Navy. [243-HP-II-401] [243-HP-73167-362]

did.unittitle: Christianity was (and remains) very much a minority religion in Japan. Ruins of churches in Japan seem to have been of particular interest to Americans.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This particular church caught the eyes of at least three different photographers – one each from the U.S. Army Air Forces, the U.S. Strategic Bombing Survey (USSBS), and the U.S Navy. [80-G-473742]

did.unittitle: Admiral Soemu Toyoda (left), navy chief of staff, examines a chart at the headquarters of the Imperial Combined Fleet in April 1944. On the right sits Captain Mitsuo Fuchida.
Crew Members of Nagasaki Mission – August 9, 1945; list
Captain Frederick L. Ashworth, USN, as a commander circa 1943.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: He served as weaponeer for the Nagasaki bomb.

did.unittitle: Second Lieutenant Philip M. Barnes, Ashworth's assistant weaponeer.
Fat Man, the Nagasaki bomb, toggled out of Bock's Car by Captain Kermit K. Beahan at 10:58 A.M. Nagasaki time on August 9, 1945.
Crew of squadron commander Sweeney.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Standing (l-r): Captain Kermit K. Beahan; Captain James F. Van Pelt, Jr.; First Lieutenant Charles D. Albury; Second Lieutenant Fred J. Olivi; Major Charles W. Sweeney. Kneeling (l-r): Staff Sergeant Edward R. Buckley; Master Sergeant John D. Kuharek; Sergeant Raymond G. Gallagher; Staff Sergeant Albert D. DeHart; Sergeant Abe M. Spitzer. Not pictured are First Lieutenant Jacob Beser, radar countermeasures; Captain Frederick L. Ashworth, USN weaponeer; Second Lieutenant Philip M. Barnes, assistant weaponeer.

did.unittitle: Irwin talks with copilot Albury, while behind Irwin, radio operator Spitzer passes the moment with cigar-toting Sweeney.
First Lieutenant Ralph N. Devore.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: One of the airplane commanders from the 393rd Bombardment Squadron, talks with Sweeney before takeoff.

did.unittitle: One last check on the navigation charts by Van Pelt, Sweeney, and Olivi.
Armed with flashlight and cigar, Sweeney checks out Bock's Car before takeoff in the early-morning hours of August 9.
An annotated aerial view of Nagasaki.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This is a reconnaissance mosaic.

did.unittitle: Customs House from the port of Nagasaki.
Nagasaki Prefecture Courthouse.
Ohato Street, Nagasaki. Note the electric streetcar.
Typical residential quarter in Nagasaki.
This particular firehouse in Nagasaki proudly displays "No. 3," a modern pumper unit.
One of Nagasaki's downtown shopping area.
Nagasaki's main police station (right) in the city's mercantile district.
Small boats lie nestled together in a tributary of the Nakeshima River.
Nagasaki, 10:58 A.M., August 9, 1945; map.
Seen from one of the B-29s, the fireball boils upward from Nagasaki one minute after Beahan dropped the bomb. [3A-03637]
Seen from one of the B-29s, the fireball boils upward from Nagasaki one minute after Beahan dropped the bomb. [3A-03638]
From two different vantage points, the mushroom cloud continues its climb toward the stratosphere.
From two different vantage points, the mushroom cloud continues its climb toward the stratosphere.
Nagasaki; map.
This view of the port facility of Nagasaki, 7,500 feet from the hypocenter, provides a graphic illustration of the "acoustics" of the bomb blast.
Annotated aerial mosaic of Nagasaki several days after the bombing.
Aerial photo of the city showing ground zero and concentric circles half a mile and one mile from the hypocenter.
The featureless plain of the Urakami River valley within half a mile of ground zero.
At 5,000 feet from the hypocenter, a residential area on the west bank of the Urakami borders a logging operation slightly downriver from the Mitsubishi complex.
Japanese soldiers rummage through the ruins of the city.
A panorama of four photos taken from ground zero, west at center.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The two large schools near the hypocenter, Chinzei, and Shiroyama, lie at the left and center, respectively. [243-NP-I-1-34; 243-NP-I-1-35; 243-NP-I-1-36; 243-NP-I-1-37]

did.unittitle: A panorama of four photos taken from ground zero, northeast at center.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: At left center is the Urakami River valley. Just out of the panorama at right is the Nagasaki Medical College. [243-NP-I-1-26; 243-NP-I-1-27; 243-NP-I-1-32; 243-NP-I-1-33]

did.unittitle: Nagasaki from near ground zero.
The vicinity of ground zero on the Urakami River looking northwest.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The athletic complex here served Chinzei School (just out of the picture at left) and Shiroyama Elementary School at upper left.

did.unittitle: Northeast of ground zero, 1,00 feet out.
A reinforced - concrete chimney stack snapped off by the explosion lies 1/4 mile from the center of the blast.
Beam, ceiling, and column failure as seen in a school's interior 1/4 mile from the explosion.
At 1,500 feet from the hypocenter a streetcar sits, blown six feet off the track.
At 2,500 feet out, steel-and-concrete buildings stand, but little else does.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The roof of the small church at center (note the adjacent cemetery) has collapsed, along with one of the gables.

did.unittitle: An entire row of small trees lies flat, snapped off close to the ground at 2,700 feet.
A roofing tile blistered by intense heat at ground zero.
This bridge sustained damage reminiscent of the sort suffered at Hiroshima.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the concrete guardrails resting in the streambed at some distance from the bridge.

did.unittitle: Reinforced concrete walls of certain buildings near ground zero exhibited an uncanny windblown appearance.
Underground bomb shelters dug into an earthen mound near ground.
Fire destroyed entire residential areas of the city, including some sheltered areas.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Here, a firebreak saved the houses on the hillside from suffering the same fate as those on the other side of the firebreak.

did.unittitle: At 9,600 feet, areas, directly in the path of the blast coming down the river valley were destroyed, by both fire and blast damage.
Nagasaki's old police station sits amid devastation, 8,200 feet from ground zero. Note the intact housing at right.
All wooden buildings in the vicinity of Nakamachi Church were destroyed, 8,800 feet from the center.
Wooden houses still stand at approximately 1 1/2 miles from ground zero.
View looking south east toward the mouth of the Urakami where the river widens to an estuary at Nagasaki's port facility at far right. [3A-3598; 3A-3599]
Wreckage of an ordnance factory 750 feet from ground zero.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The stacks standing at the center are visible at right in 5-32.

did.unittitle: This storage tank at the Yachiyo-Machi Gas Works collapses under the force of the blast at 6,600 feet from ground zero.
Even from more than a mile distant, the terrific downward pressure wave caved in the tops of tanks not collapsed.
A collapsed row of gas bottles shoved to the right at this container-manufacturing facility testifies to the direction of the blast.
The sprawling Mitsubishi Steel and Armament Works, 3/5 mile downriver from ground zero.
The Mitsubishi Works along the eastern shore of the Urakami River 2/3 mile south.
The great Mitsubishi complex, looking north up the Urakami River.
The wrecked machine shop of the Mitsubishi complex lay at approximately the 4,000-foot mark.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the machines torn from their foundations by collapsing steel members from the ceiling.

did.unittitle: Note how the uptight girders have been pushed over at about 10 degrees at the Mitsubishi torpedo-assembly plant.
Torpedo-assembly equipment.
Collapsed ceilings and walls in the torpedo plant.
Downriver, 5,000 feet south from the hypocenter, this electrical switchboard lies upended and damaged by fire.
At 5,000 feet out from the center, an occasional wooden structure survived, although damaged by blast and fire.
Structure 11,120 feet south of ground zero exhibit only blast damage.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In the foreground is a firebreak, likely constructed with the aid of the grader at right.

did.unittitle: At 12,000 feet southeast there is superficial damage, including roofing tiles and fascia board knocked away.
At 13,000 feet southeast: an occasional light wall blown over.
At 14,000 feet southeast: loosened roofing on this well-built foreign-style house.
At 14,125 feet southwest of ground zero; at last, undamaged dwellings, nearly 2 2/3 miles from the hypocenter.
Urakami Cathedral, one of Nagasaki's prominent landmarks, stands on a hill amid the rubble of a residential district east of ground zero.
View looking southwest toward ground zero and the Urakami River from a point 1/4 mile distant.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the terraced ground at left in one of the city's residential areas. In the foreground are the ruins of Urakami Prison.

did.unittitle: Looking east across the Urakami River valley toward the ruins of Nagasaki Medical College nestled against the hills beyond.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Ground zero is almost out of the photo at left.

did.unittitle: Closer view of the Nagasaki Medical College complex, 2,500 feet from ground zero.
Another scene of ruin, 500 yards south of the cathedral, this time at Nagasaki Medical College.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Shiroyama School lies across the valley.

did.unittitle: The photographer turns left, walks out of the previous picture at right, moves down the hill, turns and takes another photo.
Ending his trek down the hill, the photographer walks between the two far buildings at center in 5-75 to record yet more devastation.
Nothing remains of the college's wooden storehouse here, except for ashes and a low mound of melted glass.
Here, debris crashed into an operating room from several floors above.
Fire completely destroyed the contents of this examination and record-storage room.
An athletic complex in the vicinity of the Mitsubishi Armory, one mile north of ground zero.

On September 29, 1945, an unnamed Signal Corps photographer strolled out to the arch, faced northwest, and took this picture of the Mitsubishi factory at left and Shiroyama School in the background against the hills at right.
A sad spectacle indeed greeted the photographer who, from the cathedral steps, peered across the Urakami River valley and through the mist toward ruined Chinzei School.
Chinzei School from the east bank of the Urakami River.
A view from the air shows that, although from a distance Chinzei School appears to be intact, the entire roof has fallen in onto the building's third floor.
Before the bombing, munitions work proceeded apace, as evidenced by the machine tools seen here on Cinzei's first floor.
A residential area just east of ground zero, 1,000 feet out from the hypocenter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Urakami Cathedral lies in the distance.
