did.unittitle: Residential structures at the mile mark, with their plaster-and-bamboo-lath exterior walls, were still no match for Fat Man's power.
In the shadows of the cathedral, Nagasaki citizens bereft of regular housing have erected impromptu hovels from the debris around the. Note the tarpaulin on the "house" at right.
Farther down the estuary from 5-26, approximately two miles from ground zero, fires consumed a large area behind the waterfront.
At 2 1/4 miles from the hypocenter, on the west bank of the estuary, residential areas away from the shipyard and dry-dock area remain intact.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Structures along the estuary received the lion's share of the bomb's wrath.

did.unittitle: Nagasaki's bewildered and stunned citizens trudge down a city street in the wake of the atomic explosion.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This is a Japanese photograph.

did.unittitle: Facing northeast, a photographer looked across the platform toward Nagasaki Medical College at far right.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Just under the college buildings is a signboard bearing the two kanji characters for the station's place name, Ura-kami. Also note the Shinto arch, left of the sign, which aroused the curiosity of at least one other photographer.

did.unittitle: Passengers line up, waiting for the train at Urakami Station, which lay to the rear of the gutted Mitsubishi armaments factory, looking west from the platform. [3A-3675; 3A-3676]
Prince Fumimaro Konoye (left) and Vice Admiral Mitsumasa Yonai (right), navy minister in Suzuki's cabinet.
Vice Admiral Mitsumasa Yonai Suzuki's navy minister.
Vice Admiral Matome Ugaki, commander-in-chief, Fifth Air Fleet.
Vice Admiral Takijiro Onishi, deputy chief of staff, Imperial Japanese Navy.
V-J Day in Times Square, New York City, August 14, 1945.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Americans celebrate their hard-won victory over the Japanese empire.

did.unittitle: Every American town rejoiced at the news of the Japanese acceptance of the surrender terms.
The headlines if this Washington Times-Herald extra for August 15, 1945, said it all.
A sailor enfolds a young nurse in an impromptu embrace.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Many people have claimed to be the couple shown here. Although very similar to the photo by Albert Eisenstaedt appearing in the August 27, 1945, issue of Life magazine, this one was actually taken by a Navy photographer, one Lieutenant Jorrensen. Jorrensen stood about two steps to the right of Eisenstaedt. The sailor in whites behind the embracing pair also appears in the Life photo.

did.unittitle: Women kneel and pray in St. Patrick's Cathedral on Fifth
Women kneel and pray in St. Patrick's Cathedral on Fifth
The 22nd Special Naval Construction Battalion celebrates the end of the war at the naval amphibious base on Manus, Admiralty Islands.
Men on the destroyer escort Wileman (DE-22) voice unanimous joy that their days of cramped quarters will soon be at an end.
On Tinian, Father Toomey (close-up) celebrates Mass with the 509th Composite Group on August 16, 1945. [Maxwell 2]
On Tinian, Father Toomey celebrates Mass with the 509th Composite Group on August 16, 1945.
Published Images
Foreign Minister Mamoru Shigemitsu

Vice Admiral John S. McCain, commanding Task Force 38, comes on board Missouri (BB-63) via boatswain's chair for a conference with Admiral William F. Halsey, Commander, Third Fleet, on August 15, 1945.

Her naval ensign fluttering form the mainmast, the Japanese destroyer Hatsuzakura steams alongside USS Nicholas (DD-449) on August 27, 1945, before the transfer of naval officers and harbor pilots to Missouri for discussions regarding entry of the Third Fleet into Tokyo Bay.
Nicholas's whaleboat comes aboard Hatsuzakura to take on board the Tokyo Bay emissaries.
On board Nicholas, the Japanese harbor delegation offers a sword for examination by two American naval officers.
Encumbered by chart cases, Commander Furatani clambers on board Missouri at 8:55, "welcomed" by a lieutenant (right) and a member of the ship's Marine detachment (left).
Halsey's chief of staff, RADM Robert B. Carney (wearing a baseball cap at left) goes over charts of Sagami Bay and Tokyo Bay with Captain Takasaki, Captain Otani, and the interpreter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Missouri state seal is at left. Note the sweat-soaked American officer with binoculars at center. [80-G-490401]

did.unittitle: August 27, 1945, 6:16 P.M. Sunset over Fujiyama, seen from Missouri's bridge as she lay at anchor on the evening of her arrival in the Sagami Sea.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Other vessels lie in the distance, including (at center) two Royal Navy battleships, Duke of York and King George V.

did.unittitle: Halsey welcomes Fleet Admiral Chester W. Nimitz on board the USS South Dakota (BB-57) in Tokyo Bay, August 29, 1945.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The purpose of the visit was to discuss early recovery of Americans from the prisoner-of-war camps around Tokyo.

did.unittitle: Flying Halsey's four-star flag, Missouri lies at anchor in Tokyo Bay on August 30, 1945.
Pearl Harbor survivor USS West Virginia (BB-48) rests in Tokyo Bay offer arriving on August 30.
U.S. naval officers and their interpreter pose in the front of a Japanese J1N1-R "Irving" fighter after landing the first U.S. combat aircraft at Atsugi airfield near Tokyo on August 29, 1945.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Those present are (l-r): Lieutenant Commander Don Thorburn, Lieutenant Commander E. V. Wedell, interpreter Toda, Lieutenant Commander John N. MacInnes, Lieutenant W. V. Ballew, and Lieutenant Commander Cliff McDowell.

did.unittitle: Naval officers with members of the Soviet legation of Atsugi (left to right) Lieutenant Commander MacInnes, Lieutenant Commander Thorburn, Mr. Samiloff of the Soviet legation, Cmdr. Anatoly Rodinov of the Soviet Navy, and Lieutenant Commander Wedell. [80-G-490419]
General of the Army Douglas MacArthur talks with Allied and Japanese newsmen upon his arrival at Atsugi airfield on August 30, 1945.
Members of the Japanese delegation board USS Lansdowne (DD-486) at 6:33 A.M. on September 2, 1945, for the 1-hour-45-minute voyage to Missouri.
An honor guard presents arms at Yokohama as Mac-Arthur arrives for the voyage to surrender site.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Buchanan lies moored at right.

did.unittitle: Admiral Sir Bruce Fraser, the United Kingdom's signatory to the surrender, steps onto Missouri after the short hop from Duke of York.
General Joseph W. Stillwell (left) talks to a group of American officers while awaiting the surrender ceremony.
Missouri's graceful bow frames Mount Fuji.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note anchor chain and Union Jack. Either Duke of York or King George V lies in the distance at left.

did.unittitle: The scene on Missouri just moments before the surrender ceremony.
Her crew mustered in dress whites, Missouri stands ready to receive the Japanese delegation on the morning of September 2, 1945.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the Gleaves-class destroyer (likely Buchanan) standing by on her starboard beam.

did.unittitle: Missouri from astern. Note the Curtiss SC-1 Seahawk scout planes on her catapults.
Accompanied by Nimitz, MacArthur strides by the barbette of Number 2 turret toward the cloth-bedecked mess table, on which lies the Instrument of Surrender.
MacArthur and Nimitz board USS Missouri (BB-63) to receive the Japanese surrender September 2, 1945. [NH 49707]
Missouri's welcoming party comes to attention and salutes as Foreign Minster Shigemitsu, visible at left in the top hat, struggles to board the battleship at 8:56.
Shigemitsu's credentials. The Japanese were not asked to present them. [80-G-70150]
Shigemitsu's credentials. The Japanese were not asked to present them.
The Japanese delegation presents itself to MacArthur.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In the group are (front row left to right) Mamoru Shigemitsu, Foreign Minister; General Toshijiro Umezu, Chief of Staff; (second row Lt. Gen. Shinichi Miyazaki, Director of the 1st Department of the Army Division of General Headquarters; Katsuo Okazaki, Director General of the Central Liaison Office; RADM Sadatoshi Tomioke, Director of the 1st Department of the Navy Division of General Headquarters; Toshikazu Kase, Director of the 3rd Department of the Board of Information; Maj. Gen. Yatsuji Nagai, Army Staff Officer of General Headquarters; (third row) hidden, RADM Ichiro Yokoyama, Navy Minister; hidden Saburo Ohta, Director of the 3rd Department of the Central Liaison Office; Capt. Katsuo Shiba, Navy Staff Officer of General Headquarters; Col. Ichiji Sugita, army Staff Officer of General Headquarters. Lt. C. F. Wheeler took this and many Navy photographs from this vantage point. [80-G-348365]

did.unittitle: At 9:02 A.M., MacArthur, representing all the Allied nations, steps to the microphone and addresses the gathering.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: From his perch on Missouri's bridge, Navy photographer Lieutenant C.A. Poots preserved for posterity the entire ceremony, creating a unique record of one of history's truly memorable events.

did.unittitle: At 9:04 A.M., the Japanese are invited to sign the Instrument of Surrender.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Confused as to where to sign, Shigemitsu fumbles for his fountain pen, while Kase points out the correct place on the English copy. The delegation appears somewhat more relaxed. Saburo Ohta in his white suit, hidden in 7-28, stands at left on the third row, hat in hand. Note the scaffolding at right, built for the military and press photographer.

did.unittitle: Stooped over the table despite the discomfort of his artificial leg, Shigemitsu signs the Japanese copy of the surrender.
At 9:06, General Umezu signs for Imperial General Headquarters.
At 9:08, MacArthur signs for all the Allied nations while a solemn assembly of officers looks on.
At 9:12, Nimitz signs the Japanese copy of the surrender for the United States of America while MacArthur looks on from behind the microphone.
At 9:13, General Hsu Yung-chang signs for China.
At 9:14, Admiral Sir Bruce Fraser signs for the United Kingdom.
At 9:16, Lieutenant General Kuzma Nikolaivich Derevyenko signs for the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics.
At 9:17, General Sir Thomas Blamey signs for Australia. [80-G-332707]

At 9:18, Colonel L. Moore Cosgrave signs for Canada signed the Japanese copy; he inadvertently skipped one space, displacing the last four signatures – an error the Japanese caught at the last minute. [80-G-332708]
At 9:20, General Jacques Leclerc signs for France.
At 9:21, Admiral Conrad Helfrich signs for the Netherlands. Last to sign was Air Vice Marshall Sir L.M. Isitt for New Zealand.
A nervous footnote to the ceremony. As Shigemitsu and Kase look on, Sutherland corrects the Japanese copy of the surrender, marred by the Canadian signatory's error.
American aircraft appear over Missouri following the surrender ceremony.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the victory tally on the bridge and the thirty-star flag, the same banner raised by Commodore Perry at Tokyo on July 14, 1853. It was too fragile to fly, so was displayed on the bulkhead. [111-SC-211875; 111-SC-210644]

did.unittitle: Naval aircraft fly over Missouri after the surrender.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the destroyers standing by to take off the press and dignitaries.

did.unittitle: Aircraft over Ancon (AGC-4), hardy veteran of amphibious operations off Morocco, Sicily, Normandy, and Okinawa.
The Japanese delegation receives honors as it leaves Missouri at the conclusion of the surrender ceremony shortly before 9:30.
Japanese on Lansdowne return to Yokohama.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note Saburo Ohta in his white suit, at center.

did.unittitle: MacArthur departs Missouri at 9:58.
Plaque affixed over the surrender site on the deck of Missouri in October 1945.
The Instrument of Surrender that ended World War II [80-G-701058; 80-G-701057]
Colonel Bernard Thielen presents the Instrument of Surrender to President Truman after escorting the document during its long flight from Japan.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Also present are (l-r): Secretary of the Navy James Forrestal, Secretary of War Henry Stimson, General George C. Marshall, Fleet Admiral Ernest J. King, Acting Secretary of State Dean Acheson, General A.A. Vandegrift, USMC, Fleet Admiral William D. Leahy, and Lieutenant General Ira C. Eaker.

did.unittitle: Japanese soldiers returning to their Tokyo homes, pushing a cart loaded with their gear, passing one of the hundreds of demolished areas in the city.
Lieutenant General Tomoyuki Yamashita (left center wearing dark coat and white shirt) is arraigned before the War Crimes Commission in Manila.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The members of this tribunal are (l-r): Brigadier General E.F. Bullens, Major General C.L. Sturdevant, Major General Russell B. Reynolds, Major General J.A. Lester, and Brigadier General W.G. Walker.

did.unittitle: Helena Rodriguez testifies concerning a Japanese atrocity.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Prosecuting attorney is Captain Delmas Wamege.

did.unittitle: Children orphaned in the bombing of Kumamoto pose with a nurse.
Two women and a small child attend a Shinto memorial services held in the bank building for the blast victims.
An Atomic bomb survivor awaits treatment at a temporary hospital.
Blast victims rest on straw mats in a Hiroshima bank, Kango Ginku.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Navy lieutenant Wayne Miller took this and the following three photos.

did.unittitle: A man rests while reading in the bank building.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note the bowl and chopsticks beside his mat.

did.unittitle: Flies cover everything in the makeshift hospital.
A number of bombing victims – mostly soldiers occupy Hiroshima's main train station.
Two nurses and a doctor treat less seriously burned individuals in Hiroshima's Red Cross Hospital.
Many patients at the Red Cross Hospital had to be treated outside.
A young man from Nagasaki exhibits scars typical of many burn victims.
Note that while this man's clothing protected him in part, his shirt, open at the neck, exposed him to burns which resulted in the keliod on his chest.
The road to recovery was difficult for the many who suffered serious burns around their joints.
In the case of this woman, grafting was only partly successful and led to extensive scarring.
Major General Orvil A. Anderson, head of the USSBS Military Analysis Division.
Rear Admiral Ralph J. Ofstie, head of the USSBS Naval Analysis Division.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Shown here as a captain in February 1944, while commanding USS Essex (CV-9) during strikes on Truk.

did.unittitle: Two American Strategic Bombing Survey officers examine damage in Hiroshima.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Commercial Display Building is in the background.

did.unittitle: A Japanese soldier walking through a leveled portion of Hiroshima.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Lieutenant Wayne Miller, USNR, took this picture during September 1945.

did.unittitle: On September 26, 1945, Photographer's Mate Third Class George Almarez, USS Appalachian (AGC-1) snapped an attempt to return to normalcy in Hiroshima.
Australian prisoners of war en route home.
Nurses from the 308th General Hospital sleep on the ground pending construction of proper quarters.
An Army delegation greets Danny Kaye at Hiroshima on October 25, 1945.
Members of the Atomic Bomb Casualty Commission gather for a luncheon given by the assistant mayor of Hiroshima on December 6, 1946.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Kneeling (l-r) are a city official, Lieutenant F. Ullrich, Lieutenant J. Neel, Dr. Tsuzuki. Standing (l-r) are Mr. Saida, a city official, Colonel H. Johnson, Dr. R. S. Hinshaw, Dr. A. Brues, Dr. H. Volk, Dr Matsubayashi, Lieutenant Block, Dr. Omura.

did.unittitle: Officers from the USSBS huddle together near ground zero and examine the devastation in Nagasaki.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Compare this scene with the left portion of the panorama in 5-33.

did.unittitle: Survey personnel inspect a double-track railroad bridge lying across a small tributary of the Urakami River near ground zero.
An American officer points to capitals on a wall of Urakami Cathedral from which two columns were blown away at left.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note Chinzei School on the hill beyond.

did.unittitle: First Lieutenant D.A. McGovern of Buffalo, New York (port of the newsreel pool), prepared to take some movie footage amid the devastation of Nagasaki.
Nagasaki, spring 1946.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: New shoots grow from a chestnut 2,000 feet from ground zero.

did.unittitle: View looking north up the Urakami River toward Nagasaki on August 3, 1946.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note new construction in the area east of the old Mitsubishi Steel and Armament Works. The wreckage of the plant has not yet been cleared.

did.unittitle: Slowly, a portion of the cultural infrastructure of Hiroshima and Nagasaki experienced a resurrection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Here, the rebuilt Urakami Church stands complete on May 29, 1949.

did.unittitle: Two years after the explosion over Nagasaki, agricultural expert Takeo Furuno holds up a sesame stalk at left, grown in a field 300 yards from the hypocenter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The results presaged human genetic disorders extending out for generations.

did.unittitle: A portion of the command crew of the 509th Composite Group after the war

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: (l-r): Major Van Kirk, navigator; Lieutenant James W. Anderson copilot (he actually flew in No. 91 on August 6, 1945); Major Ferebee, bombardier; Colonel Tibbets, pilot. Ferebee, looking substantially older, has shaved off his mustache.

did.unittitle: The atomic bomb pilots and their bombardiers (l-r): Sweeney, Seaham, Ferebee, and Tibbets.
Nagasaki pilot and copilot after the war – Captain Charles Albury (left; promoted from first lieutenant since the mission), and Major Sweeney.
Enola Gay enjoys a spot on center stage at the National Air Fair at O'Hare Field in Chicago, July 3, 1949.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Present (l-r) are Mr. Carl Mitman of the Smithsonian Institution; Tibbets; Ferebee; and Major General Emmett J. O'Donnell.

did.unittitle: In the 1952 movie Above and Beyond, Hollywood produced a mix of wartime romance and a great story of American ingenuity and heroics.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Note that Tibbets (Robert Taylor) has not yet been promoted to full colonel, an event which (in the movie) elicited a tantrum from the moody Mrs. Tibbets (Eleanor Parker).

did.unittitle: A view looking across the Motoyasu River toward the Hiroshima Commercial Display Building.
Exposed to the elements, the supporting framework of the dome slowly rusts away.
Likewise open to the weather, the masonry walls crumble with the passage of time.
Japanese tourists pause in front of the dome and ponder the past and future.
Just across the Motoyasu River from the A-bomb Dome, youngsters cluster around the Peace Bell at Hiroshima.
Solemn observes gather in the rain at the Children's Peace Monument.
Atop the monolithic sculpture stands a young girl with a representation of an origami bird supported in her hands.
Eerie and surreal, the Children's Peace Monument sculptures are reminiscent of the corpses found by the thousands in the aftermath of the explosions.
Still farther south, the Memorial Monument for Hiroshima is dedicated to all victims of the first atomic bomb.
The Memorial Monument with the Commercial Display Building ruin in the background. [Goldstein 30]
The Memorial Monument is a popular place for reflection, and draws many groups of Japanese students, easily identified here by their school garb.
The Hiroshima Peace memorial Museum houses a diverse collection of artifacts and photography from the bombing's aftermath.
A child's jumper in the museum display. [Goldstein 31]
A child's jacket shows the effect of the blast on individuals within a mile and a half of the hypocenter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Those closer in frequently had clothing burned away or blown off. [Goldstein 8]

did.unittitle: The crushed remains of bicycle recovered from the ruins of Hiroshima.
The older generation, with physical and mental scars, and firsthand memories of the A-Bomb, dwindles with every passing year.
Japanese schoolgirls at the memorial. [Goldstein 5]
Younger generations have been inculcated with the history of the Hiroshima bombing from a very early age.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This series contains oversized materials that have been removed from the first twelve series for storage purposes. Many of the files relate to World War II and consist of publications, photographs, maps, and diagrams. Files were also separated from the Whitehead series that discuss his military career. Also of note, this subseries contains the scrapbook of a distinguished Japanese military family and covers both World Wars.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The documents contained in this series were added to the collection in 2012. The subseries are meant to roughly correspond to the existing categories that are found in Series I through Series XIV. It contains several unpublished manuscripts written by Gordon Prange and Katherine Dillon.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The documents contained in this series were added to the collection in 2013. The subseries are meant to roughly correspond to the existing categories that are found in Series I through Series XIV. A large majority of the documents in this series are related to Goldstein's writings and research on World War II and his teaching materials as a professor at the University of Pittsburgh. In addition, this series also contains Goldstein's research documents on Amelia Earhart, Korea, and Ennis Whitehead.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The files in this subseries date from 1937 to 2007 and contain research materials and manuscript drafts relating to World War II amassed and created by Donald Goldstein, Gordon Prange, and Katherine Dillon. This subseries is divided into the following sections: Publication Materials, Research Materials, and Pearl Harbor Survivor Interviews and Unpublished Manuscript. More information regarding these records can be found in each section's scope notes.

did.unittitle: Manuscripts and Publication Materials

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The files in this section date from 1964 to 2007 and contain manuscript drafts, correspondence, and other publication materials relating to World War II that were generated by Donald Goldstein, Gordon Prange, and Katherine Dillon. Much of the correspondence contained in these files is between Goldstein and Dillon and is concerned with the compiling and editing of manuscripts. Additional correspondence consists of communication between Goldstein and publishers or perspective publishers. The files in this section are arranged alphabetically by publication title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The files in this section date from 1937 to 2002 and contains primary and secondary sources concerning World War II that were amassed by Gordon Prange and Donald Goldstein. These files include correspondence written by U.S. service men, interviews, maps, and documents relating to the Pearl Harbor investigations. Of particular note, there are handwritten maps with Japanese text that depict the Battle of the Java Sea (February 27, 1942) and the Battle of Sunda Straight (February 28 to March 1, 1942). For more information on these maps, see the contents notes of the appropriate file.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: These maps are handwritten maps that depict the Battle of the Java Sea (Surabaya Bay Night Battle), February 27, 1942, and the Battle of Sunda Straight (Bantam Bay Night Battle), February 28-March 1, 1942. In the Battle of the Java Sea, American, British, Dutch, and Australian Forces attempted to stop the Japanese invasion of Java and subsequently encountered and engaged a Japanese covering force of roughly equal strength. The Allied fleet lost three destroyers and two light cruisers. On February 28, the USS Houston and the HMAS Perth—after surviving the Battle of the Java Sea and retiring en route to the Sunda Strait—decided to engage Japanese landing forces and its accompanying convoy. Both the USS Houston and the HMAS Perth were sunk in the early morning of March 1.

This subseries contains course materials from his classes on the United States, Russia, world history, international relations, and American minorities. These course materials primarily consist of syllabi, exams, supplementary readings, and lecture outlines.

did.unittitle: Deshazer

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The documents in this subseries contain the research materials compiled by Donald Goldstein for the publication of Return of the Raider: A Doolittle Raider's Story of War & Forgiveness. The book focuses on Jacob Deshazer, a bombardier with the Army Air Corps who took part in the famous Doolittle Raid over Japan shortly after the bombing of Pearl Harbor. The book chronicles Jacob Deshazer's experiences as a Japanese Prisoner of War and his missions work in Japan following World War II. The materials in this collection are organized into correspondence, newspaper clippings and articles, images, research materials, and manuscripts.
